and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding such special mandatory redemption date.

**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION**

**The Issuers**

The Issuers were incorporated on January 28, 2021 to facilitate the Transactions. As of the date of this
offering memorandum, the Issuers had no material assets or liabilities, did not have any revenuegenerating activities of their own and had not engaged in activities other than those related to their
incorporation and in preparation of the Transactions. As a result, no historical financial information of the
Issuers is included in this offering memorandum.

**LSI Business**

The LSI Business has been, and as at the date of this offering memorandum remains, part of Lonza Group.
It has not historically existed as a separate reporting group, but rather formed part of a larger Lonza
Group of companies. In prior years, the LSI Business was reported as a separate ‘‘Specialty Ingredients’’
segment in the relevant consolidated financial statements of Lonza Group. In order to facilitate the
Acquisition, all companies and operating activities that are part of LSI Business were carved out of Lonza
Group (the ‘‘Carve-out’’) as part of the divestment of the LSI Business. During the year ended
December 31, 2020, Lonza Group substantially completed the Carve-out by (i) implementing operational
changes to separate key functions, including supply chain activities, customer facing roles and other critical
functions; and (ii) establishing certain additional legal entities to facilitate the organizational and legal
aspects of the Carve-out.

**Historical Financial Information**

As the LSI Business did not exist as a separate group and since all companies and operating activities
within the LSI Business were under the common control of Lonza Group, in each case, prior to the
finalization of the Carve-out, the historical financial information of the LSI Business presented in this
offering memorandum as at and for each of the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 has been
prepared on a combined and carve-out basis.

As a result, this offering memorandum presents the following financial information of the LSI Business
(the ‘‘Financial Statements’’):

- The audited combined and carve-out financial statements of the LSI Business as at and for the year
ended December 31, 2019, together with notes thereto (the ‘‘2019 Financial Statements’’) and the
audit report thereon, which include comparative numbers as at and for the year ended December 31,
2018.

- The audited combined and carve-out financial statements of the LSI Business as at and for the year
ended December 31, 2020, together with notes thereto (the ‘‘2020 Financial Statements’’, and
together with the 2019 Financial Statements, the ‘‘Financial Statements’’) and the audit report
thereon, which include comparative numbers as at and for the year ended December 31, 2019.

The Financial Statements exclude, for all relevant years, the assets, liabilities and results of operations of
Lonza Group’s ‘‘Consumer Health & Nutrition’’ and ‘‘Water Care’’ businesses, which were both previously
part of the ‘‘Specialty Ingredients’’ segment of Lonza Group. The ‘‘Consumer Health & Nutrition’’
business was transferred from the LSI Business to the Lonza Pharma Biotech & Nutrition (‘‘LPBN’’)
segment of Lonza Group effective as at January 1, 2019. However, certain assets, liabilities and results of
operations of a small portfolio of the legacy ‘‘Consumer Health & Nutrition’’ business, which are related to
the core LSI Business activities, were not transferred and are included in the Financial Statements. The
‘‘Water Care’’ business was sold by Lonza Group on February 28, 2019 to Platinum Equity and was
reported as discontinued operations in Lonza Group’s financial statements for the year ended
December 31, 2018.

The consolidated financial information of Lonza Group has not been included in this offering
memorandum.

In making an investment decision, investors must rely upon their own examination of our business, the
terms of the Offering and the financial information presented in this offering memorandum.

xv

**Basis of Preparation**

The Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting
Standards (‘‘IFRS’’) as issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), reflecting the fact
that the LSI Business has been carved-out from the larger Lonza Group. See Note 1 ‘‘Accounting Principles
_and Basis of Preparation’’ to the 2020 Financial Statements._

The preparation of the Financial Statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical
accounting estimates. IFRS also require management to exercise its judgment in the process of applying
accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where
assumptions and estimates are significant, are disclosed in the Financial Statements. IFRS differs in
various respects from generally accepted accounting principles in the United States (‘‘U.S. GAAP’’). We
have not prepared a reconciliation of our financial information to U.S. GAAP or a summary of significant
differences in the accounting and valuation methods of IFRS and U.S. GAAP and do not intend to do so
in the future. Potential investors should therefore consult their own professional advisors for an
understanding of the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP.

As IFRS does not provide guidelines for the preparation of combined and carve-out financial statements,
the preparation of the Financial Statements was subject to IAS 8 ‘‘Accounting Policies, Changes in
_Accounting Estimates and Errors,’’ particularly IAS 8.12, which required management of Lonza Group to_
consider recent pronouncements of other standard-setting bodies, other financial reporting requirements
and recognized industry practices in connection with the preparation of the Financial Statements.
Accordingly, in preparing the Financial Statements, the LSI Business applied Lonza Group’s accounting
approach in accordance with recognized industry practices and rules on business combinations under
common control. In general, the LSI Business used the same accounting policies and measurement
principles in preparing the Financial Statements as were used in preparing the IFRS consolidated financial
statements of Lonza Group (the ‘‘extraction approach’’). This approach has been adjusted with respect to
transactions with Lonza Group companies and to ensure compliance with IFRS. Transactions between the
LSI Business and Lonza Group were recognized in accordance with IFRS and classified as related party
transactions as defined in IAS 24 ‘‘Related Party Disclosures.’’

In the year ended December 31, 2020, Lonza Group reallocated certain assets and liabilities between its
continuing business and the LSI Business, resulting in certain changes to the asset and liability allocations
to the LSI Business in the carve-out approach applied in the preparation of the 2019 Financial Statements.
These revised allocations were presented to enhance comparability and were reflected in the 2020
Financial Statements, including in the comparative figures as of and for the year ended December 31,
2019. See Note 1.2 to the 2020 Financial Statements. Accordingly, figures as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2019 included in the 2020 Financial Statements may differ from those included in the 2019
Financial Statements. Figures in this offering memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31,
2019 have been extracted or derived from the comparative figures as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2019 included in the 2020 Financial Statements.

Additional information on the scope and basis of preparation of the Financial Statements and the
application of significant accounting policies is presented in Note 1 ‘‘Accounting Principles and Basis of
_Preparation’’ to the 2020 Financial Statements._

As a result, the Financial Statements included in this offering memorandum may not reflect what the
results of operations, financial position and cash flows would have been had the LSI Business operated as a
separate, stand-alone business without the shared resources of Lonza Group for the years presented, and
may not be indicative of our future results of operations, financial position and cash flows. The fact that
the companies and operating activities comprising the LSI Business did not historically exist as a separate
group limits the validity of the combined and carve-out financial information.

**IFRS 16 (Leases)**

On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), which replaced IAS 17 and the related IFRIC
and SIC interpretations and resulted in almost all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the
distinction between operating and finance leases was eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee
recognizes an asset (the right-to-use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments. The
only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases should a company elect to apply an available practical
expedient in order to reduce the transition effort. IFRS 16 became effective for fiscal years commencing
on or after January 1, 2019.

xvi


-----

The LSI Business adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on January 1, 2019, by using the modified retrospective
method, which means that the cumulative transition effects of initial applications are recognized in
retained earnings as at January 1, 2019. The LSI Business elected to use the transition practical expedient
allowing the standard to be applied only to contracts that were previously identified as leases applying
IAS 17 and IFRIC 4 as at the date of initial application. Accordingly, no adjusted comparative information
was disclosed.

The transition to IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019, gave rise to changes to our assets and liabilities. As a result,
figures as at and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 may not be comparable to the results
presented for prior periods. As at December 31, 2019 and 2020, our right-of-use assets (presented in
property, plant and equipment) amounted to CHF15 million and CHF14 million, respectively, and lease
liabilities amounted to CHF15 million and CHF14 million, respectively. The depreciation of right-of-use
assets for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, amounted to CHF5 million and CHF4 million,
respectively, and the interest expenses from lease liabilities amounted to CHF1 million and CHF1 million,
respectively.

The adoption of IFRS 16 had a positive impact on our Adjusted EBITDA, as the cost of operating leases
that were previously expensed above Adjusted EBITDA are now moved below Adjusted EBITDA and
included in depreciation of right-of-use assets and interest expense.

For an analysis of the impact of the first-time application of IFRS 16 (Leases) from January 1, 2019, see
‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting
_Comparability of Our Financial Statements—Changes to accounting standards—IFRS 16 (Leases)’’ and_
Note 1 ‘‘Accounting Principles and Basis of Preparation’’ to the 2020 Financial Statements.

Aside from IFRS 16, the adoption of the other accounting standards in any year ended December 31, 2018,
2019 or 2020 did not have any significant impact on the Financial Statements.

**Unaudited Pro Forma Financial Information**

This offering memorandum also includes certain unaudited _pro forma financial information of the SUN_
Issuer as at and for the year ended December 31, 2020, including pro forma indebtedness, pro forma senior
secured indebtedness and _pro forma interest expense, which has been prepared to illustrate the effect of_

calculating pro forma indebtedness and pro forma senior secured indebtedness and (ii) on January 1, 2020,

for the year ended December 31, 2020 has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not

December 31, 2020 or January 1, 2020, respectively; nor does it purport to project our financial results,
indebtedness or interest expense at any future date.

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

**_General_**

In this offering memorandum, we present certain financial measures that are not recognized by IFRS or
any other generally accepted accounting principles and that may not be permitted to appear on the face of
the Financial Statements or footnotes thereto. The primary non-IFRS financial measures used in this
offering memorandum include currency-adjusted sales to third parties, gross profit margin, Adjusted

xvii


-----

EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA margin, Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal of Carveout Adjustments,
Microbial Control Solutions Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal of Carveout Adjustments, Specialty
Chemical Services Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal of Carveout Adjustments, capital expenditures,
maintenance capital expenditure, growth capital expenditure, operational expenditures, trade net working
capital, change in trade net working capital, operating net working capital, change in operating net working
capital, Normalized Adjusted EBITDA, Normalized Adjusted EBITDA margin and _pro forma Adjusted_
EBITDA, and other figures for the year ended December 31, 2020 (our ‘‘Non-IFRS Measures’’). These
measures are presented in this offering memorandum because they are measures that our management
uses to assess our operating performance, and we believe that they and similar measures are widely used in
our industry as a means of evaluating a company’s operating performance and financing structure, and
because we believe they present helpful comparisons of financial performance between periods by
excluding the distorting effect of certain non-operational, non-recurring or exceptional items.

For an explanation and reconciliation of certain of these Non-IFRS Measures to the most directly
comparable IFRS measure, see ‘‘Summary—Summary Financial and Other Information—Other Financial,
_Operating and Pro Forma Information.’’_

Our primary Non-IFRS Measures are defined as follows:

**_Currency-adjusted sales to third_**
**_parties . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means the currency-adjusted basis sales amounts, percentages and
variances which are calculated using the average monthly foreign
exchange rate of the same period in the prior year and applying that
rate to the actual monthly foreign currency sales amounts in the
applicable period. The monthly amounts are then aggregated to
display the full-year currency-adjusted basis sales figures. This is done
in order to enhance the comparability of our sales to third parties, and
such figures are presented using a constant exchange rate across
periods presented.

**_Gross profit margin . . . . . . . . . ._** Means gross profit as a percentage of sales to third parties.

**_Adjusted EBITDA . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means profit for the period, as adjusted by adding back income taxes,
share of loss/(profit) of associates and financial expenses less financial
income and adding back depreciation of property, plant and
equipment, amortization of intangible assets and impairment and
reversal of impairment on property, plant and equipment and
intangibles.

**_Adjusted EBITDA margin . . . . . ._** Means Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of sales to third parties.

**_Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal_**
**_of Carveout Adjustments . . . . ._** Means Adjusted EBITDA, reflecting the reversal of carveout
adjustments originally made to allocate certain costs, primarily
corporate overhead function costs, of the Lonza Group to the LSI
Business. These adjustments, which are further explained in Note 1.3
Basis of Preparation to the 2020 Financial Statements, were necessary
to reflect the fact that the LSI Business has been carved out from the
larger Lonza Group. The allocated costs may not be indicative of the
actual expenses that would have been incurred had the LSI Business
been operating as a separate entity apart from Lonza Group.

**_Microbial Control Solutions_**
**_Adjusted EBITDA After_**
**_Reversal of Carveout_**
**_Adjustments . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal of Carveout Adjustments
for our Microbial Control Solutions business unit.

**_Specialty Chemical Services_**
**_Adjusted EBITDA After_**
**_Reversal of Carveout_**
**_Adjustments . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal of Carveout Adjustments
for our Specialty Chemical Services business unit.

xviii


-----

**_Capital expenditures . . . . . . . . . ._** Means the investments in property, plant and equipment and
intangible assets in the period.

**_Maintenance capital expenditure . ._** Means capital expenditure related to ensuring current production
levels, efficiency, cost improvements, health and safety and
compliance.

**_Growth capital expenditure . . . . ._** Means capital expenditure related to increasing production capacity
and sales.

**_Operational expenditures . . . . . . ._** Means the sum of marketing and distribution costs, research and
development costs and administration and general overhead costs.

**_Trade net working capital . . . . . ._** Means the sum of inventories and trade receivables less trade
payables.

**_Change in trade net working_**
**_capital . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means (increase) in inventories, _plus (increase)/decrease in trade_
receivables, plus (decrease)/increase in trade payables.

**_Operating net working capital . . ._** Means trade net working capital plus other operating receivables and
derivatives less other operating payables and derivatives.

**_Change in operating net working_**
**_capital . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means the change in trade net working capital _plus (increase) /_
decrease in other operating receivables and derivatives and other
operating payables and derivatives.

**_Normalized Adjusted EBITDA . . ._** Means Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted for standalone adjustments to
reflect the estimated cost savings of LSI operating as a standalone
business from Lonza Group and for certain other adjustments which
we believe to be of a non-operational or non-recurring or exceptional
nature or to reflect normalizations across periods.

**_Normalized Adjusted EBITDA_**
**_margin . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._** Means Normalized Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of sales to
third parties.

**_Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA . . . ._** Means Normalized Adjusted EBITDA, as adjusted for the ‘‘run rate’’
effect of certain customer contracts entered into during the first
quarter of 2021 or expected to be entered into during April 2021, and
for certain planned cost savings in connection with the Transformation
Program, described under ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting_
_Future Results of Operations—Transformation Program.’’_

analysis of our operating results or cash flows as reported under IFRS. Some of the limitations of
Non-IFRS Measures are that:

- they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital investments or contractual

- they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

- they do not reflect the significant interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest

be indicative of our ongoing operations;

- assets are depreciated or amortized over differing estimated useful lives and often have to be replaced
in the future, and these measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements;

- other companies in our industry and analysts may calculate these measures differently than we do,
limiting their usefulness as comparative measures; and

- each of the EBITDA-based and net income-based measures presented in this offering memorandum
is defined and calculated differently from the definition of ‘‘Consolidated Net Income’’ and

and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes’’of this offering memorandum and in the Indentures. Accordingly,
the EBITDA-based measures presented in this offering memorandum do not provide precise
indications as to the level of our adherence to the terms of the Indentures.

Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of
discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be
available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on
the Financial Statements and using these Non-IFRS Measures only to supplement evaluation of our

_The following summary contains basic information about us and this Offering and is qualified by, and should_
_be read in conjunction with, the more detailed information appearing elsewhere in this offering memorandum._
_This summary is not complete and does not contain all the information that you should consider before_

_offering memorandum carefully, including ‘‘Risk Factors,’’ ‘‘Management’s Discussion and Analysis of_

**Overview**

We are a leading global provider of microbial control solutions across various consumer and industrial
markets. We also offer specialty chemical products and services covering composites and specialty
chemicals. Headquartered in Basel, Switzerland, we are building on more than 120 years of the business’
history as a trusted specialty chemicals supplier.

With more than 670 individual products and services, we focus on attractive end markets with significant
growth potential. We serve more than 5,300 clients worldwide, and our products are deeply imbedded into
the value chains of our key customers, with many of whom we have long-standing relationships. We have 18
manufacturing facilities, supported by the market-leading expertise of our 13 research and development
(‘‘R&D’’) centers and a broad network of 35 sales offices across our key geographical regions of EIMEA,
APAC and the Americas. We have what we believe to be a market-leading regulatory expertise, including
on the European Union and the United States markets.

For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had total sales of CHF1,825 million,
CHF1,747 million and CHF1,716 million, respectively. Our profit for the period was CHF79 million,
CHF73 million and CHF98 million, respectively, for the same periods. Our pro forma Adjusted EBITDA
for the year ended December 31, 2020 was CHF431 million.

We report sales to third parties on a business unit level and a market field level. Our operations comprise
the following two business units:

- _Microbial Control Solutions business unit is a market-leading trusted and innovative supplier of_
microbial control solutions and chemical technologies used in a wide range of industrial and consumer
products to control harmful organisms including viruses and bacteria. Its product development and
application support is focused on six attractive addressable markets with significant growth potential.
Overall, it has broader market presence (in terms of product spectrum) than any competitor in the
microbial control industry. The business unit’s vast portfolio of over 470 individual products and
services is backed by market-leading technical expertise of nine major regional and two smaller R&D
sites employing 176 R&D specialists as at December 31, 2020. The business unit has a proven track
record of innovation with a total of 36 new products launched in the past three years. Our Microbial
Control Solutions business unit has what we believe to be an unmatched regulatory expertise in such
highly regulated markets as the European Union and the United States and, as at December 31, 2020,
it employed 75 regulatory specialists. In the United States, it currently has 42 biocidal active
ingredients registered or under review with the Environmental Protection Agency (‘‘EPA’’), as well as
412 federal registrations and 1,742 supplemental registrations for formulations. In the European
Union, it supports 20 different active ingredients under various product types under the Regulation
(EU) 528/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 22, 2012 (as amended)
concerning the making available on the market and use of biocidal products (‘‘BPR’’), the regulation
governing the manufacture and use of biocidal products, which results in 110 separate ingredients /
product type combinations supported by individual registration dossiers. The business unit also
supports 540 national registrations in various European countries, which are required for BPR
product authorizations. Its specialists remain on the forefront of the evolving regulatory environment
to help ensure that current and future products comply with varying regional specific regulations that
underpin the wide range of industries and markets it addresses. The business unit’s products are
manufactured on 17 sites in nine countries and it serves more than 4,300 customers through 29
dedicated sales offices strategically located across EIMEA, APAC and the Americas. Its direct sales
accounted for 91% of all its sales to third parties for the year.

For the year ended December 31, 2020, the Microbial Control Solutions business unit generated
CHF1,068 million sales to third parties, or 65% of our total sales to third parties for the year. For the

with approximately 700 customers, and is constantly expanding into formulations. For the year
ended December 31, 2020, this market field generated CHF265 million of sales to third parties.

� The _Home and Personal Care market field focuses on chemical solutions for home care_
(preservation of customer formulations), the beauty industry (hair care, including anti-dandruff

� The Wood Protection market field delivers solutions to protect and enhance wood with innovative
technologies so that its life is improved and its uses are expanded. Its key products include
pressure treatment solutions for residential, commercial and agricultural use, industrial treatment
for heavy duty applications and a variety of wood specialties, such as fire retardants. We are a
leader in wood protection solutions, with approximately 1,100 customers. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, this market field generated CHF313 million of sales to third parties.

anti-foulants on ships to reduce drag and improve fuel efficiency, and in aquaculture), polymer

nuts. It has particular expertise in solutions against slugs and snails and serves approximately 300

sales to third parties.

additives used in technically demanding industries, such as electronics and transportation. It also
comprises custom development and manufacturing and provides key performance intermediates and
chemicals for many industrial applications. Some of the business unit’s output is utilized for the

Specialty Chemical Services is an asset-based, process-oriented and efficiency-driven business

**Our Competitive Strengths**

We believe that the following are among our key competitive strengths:

**_Fundamental macro trends driving growth across highly attractive end markets_**

Our business focuses on highly attractive end markets that offer significant structural growth potential. We
operate in profitable niche markets within the high-growth microbial control market and attractive niches
within the specialty chemical services market.

The biocides market is supported by a broad range of global trends driving underlying growth across
diversified application areas, such as our customers’ shift to more complex formulated products in
response to consumer preferences and increasingly stringent regulatory requirements. It also benefits from
supportive demand as a result of the critical functions that biocides serve for our customers and their end
customers, which has been further evidenced by the increasing demand for our products due to changing
customer preferences induced by the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly in our Hygiene market field. The
Covid-19 pandemic has increased the need for protection of health and well-being and is creating a ‘‘new
normal’’ in the use of disinfectants, requiring us to stay ahead of the curve, defining and supporting the
‘‘new normal’’ and providing us with a significant opportunity, as well as with the responsibility for
educating customers and the public given our market leading position. Megatrends such as the growing
global population and, in particular, middle class, urbanization and rising living standards and other trends
such as changing lifestyles, increasing focus on the environment, safeguarding people’s wellbeing and
increasing regulation are aligned in favor of the Microbial Control Solutions business unit’s strengths,
creating attractive growth opportunities. In particular, the biocides market requires substantial research
and development investment and is a highly regulated market with lengthy registration processes and
regulatory reviews. We believe that our experience and expertise in this area would be difficult for new

3


-----

entrants to replicate. Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit is particularly well positioned to
navigate these processes and reviews to capitalize on favorable underlying consumer demand.

Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit is active in high-growth niches, such as composites. We have
a pipeline of innovative products in Specialty Chemical Services, including composite materials and
services related to our CDMO market field (sodium batteries, vegan collagen for cosmetics and nutrition,
other nutritional fermented products, and fragrances ingredients).

**_Leading and defendable market positions across an attractive and diversified product portfolio_**

We have well established, leading market positions supported by our attractive product and service
offerings to customers focused on formulation, coupled with a broad product offering and we believe that
this provides us with a sustainable competitive advantage. Further, we continuously evaluate our technical
capabilities, including R&D and manufacturing, to consider potential upgrades and to enable us to
maintain our leading market position and to meet market and customer needs.

Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit is a market leading business across a broad range of end
markets, with the most comprehensive portfolio of active and formulated solutions that provide
application-specific results for our customers. This scale allows us to have a broader end market presence
than any of our competitors across the microbial control industry, particularly in our Hygiene, Paints and
Coatings and Wood Protection market fields.

With 42 actives approved in the United States and 20 actives approved in the European Union, our
manufacturing of actives provides leading scale with the broadest active base in the market and in-house
production of quats and pyrithiones. Our formulated solutions offering is based upon our microbial labs
and research and development capabilities, extensive knowledge of end-use applications and access to our
proprietary registered formulations to our customers. This allows our customers to enter the market with
new products much quicker, avoiding regulatory approval processes of up to seven years and the collection
of relevant field data for specific markets of up to five years. While our customers need registrations to run
their own processes and to protect their products, they are generally not experts in the time-consuming
process of registering biocides.

Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit is focused on niches with high profitability and value
generation potential utilizing our highly specialized chemical and fermentation technologies. We provide
critical products and services to specialty end markets that are characterized by high resilience and provide
us with symbiotic relationships with our blue-chip customer base. In particular, we are a leader in Vitamin
B3 and a leading supplier of cyanate ester resins. We have a highly automated and efficient setup that
leverages complex chemistries and fermentation technologies across various end markets and use
innovative processes and systems focused on process development for exclusive synthesis projects of our
customers and for multi-customer products. Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit acts as a key
enabler for growth in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and we are increasingly finding
applications of the processes developed in our Specialty Chemical Services business unit in the Microbial
Control Solutions business unit.

**_Diversified, long-standing and loyal customer base_**

We operate a service-focused business model that provides a broad range of formulation capabilities and
regulatory support and customized solutions. This has allowed us to form close relationships with many of
our customers that have often lasted for decades.

We provide a highly sophisticated specialty chemicals offering with R&D, process development, regulatory
support and innovation capabilities that can be tailored to our customers’ specific requirements, resulting
in a unique customer proposition. Our 13 R&D centers across the globe allow us to develop new products
to meet the needs of our customers, with the regional set-up of our R&D organization enabling us to
establish close links and a high degree of customer intimacy. In addition, through our technical service
offerings, we offer specialized solutions for customer technology and application specifications and are
able to facilitate end-consumer safety expectations. This close cooperation and the deep integration in our
customers’ value chain has resulted in high customer retention, with several having started more than
50 years ago with one of our key customers being served via a co-located pipeline directly from our
facilities. Our customer base is also diverse, with over 5,300 customers and our top 10 customers

Our strong technical offering positions us well to address our customers’ continuous demands for
innovation and high-quality products. For example, our Hygiene market field was highly ranked in a survey
of our customers in the top key purchasing criteria for customers, including product quality, solution focus,
value for money, brand and reputation, innovation capabilities and existing relationships. In meeting these
key purchasing criteria, we are able to best serve our customer base and ensure long-term relationships
with our customers.

**_Industry-leading innovation platform and regulatory assurance expertise_**

We operate an innovative business proposition led by our regulatory assurance and research and
development capabilities. Our industry-leading regulatory assurance offering allows us to provide
customers with access to our portfolio of approved actives and team of regulatory specialists. Our research
and development organization has a regional footprint and application focus, with 13 R&D centers across
the globe putting us at the forefront of the sector’s innovation by anticipating and responding to market
developments. We also work with our customers on joint R&D, leveraging our technological capabilities
and unique regulatory expertise.

We consider our regulatory expertise and our significant portfolio of registered actives as a key
differentiator for our business. We have developed what we believe to be unmatched, market leading
regulatory expertise in highly regulated markets such as the European Union and the United States, with
75 regulatory specialists. This allows us to assist our customers through the complexities of various
regulatory processes across the globe and to proactively anticipate and address changes in the global
regulatory environment and to share this insight with our customers, allowing them to address regulatory
issues early in the product development processes. With our unique portfolio of registered actives in these
highly regulated markets we can assure our customers that the active and formulated solutions we provide
have already been approved, saving our customers both the time and cost associated with regulatory and
registration processes. Further, we anticipate that the introduction of new actives, such as biocides or
preservatives, will be a rare event in the industry going forward and that innovations will be focused on the
combination of existing registered actives and the documentation of their safe uses through registrations.
This regulatory expertise helps to drive and secure brand equity for our customers, reinforcing our strong
customer relationships.

We believe that our pipeline of innovative research and development projects generate attractive sales
potential driven by market and customer needs and a rigorous approach to optimize commercial success.
Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit’s R&D function has developed 36 new products in the past
three years, with 16 formulations approved by the EPA to combat the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The
business unit’s innovation pipeline, as of March 2021, included 87 projects in the pipeline at various
development stages (12 in the planning phase, 26 in the feasibility phase, 39 in the development phase and
10 in the commercialization phase). We are positioned to anticipate and respond to market developments
and customer needs. Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit’s R&D is focused on process
development for multi-customer products with 13 new products launched in the past three years. Examples
of our long track record of commercializing our R&D capabilities include: the Lonzagard� portfolio,
Sodium Omadine� antimicrobial, Lonzagard� BKC cGMP, BARamine�, the Bardac� range of

**_Well-invested global manufacturing footprint, leveraging multiple technology platforms across the portfolio_**

Our global presence and a well-invested asset base allow us to provide our customers with valuable
benefits from our broad range of technology platforms and skill sets and flexibility in our manufacturing
setup.

We operate an asset-based, process-oriented and efficiency-driven specialty business, with Visp being our
main site of operations, along with other key facilities located in the United States, China and the Czech
Republic. Our unique setup in Visp with its highly automated Cracker Core and the hydrogen cyanide
(‘‘HCN’’) and Ketene/Diketene networks, is optimized towards high-value niches. The Visp site includes
five highly flexible multi-purpose plants for custom manufacturing of specialty chemicals for various
applications and two multi-product chemical plants mainly serving the Composite Materials market field of
our Specialty Chemical Services business unit.

With our global footprint of 18 manufacturing sites across EIMEA, APAC and the Americas we can meet
the specific needs of customers across the globe. Currently, the Microbial Control Solutions business unit
is focused on and has its strongest sales in the Americas, while the Specialty Chemical Services business
unit is focused on and has its strongest sales in Europe. Given the focus of the sales distribution of these
business units in the US and Europe, we believe that our operations in Asia present a growth area for both
of our business units. We believe that our global presence combined with regional expertise provides us
with a significant competitive advantage, ensuring local, physical proximity to clients, which is a key for
many of the Microbial Control Solutions market fields, such as the Wood Protection market.

**_Attractive financial profile with strong cash flow generation_**

We have historically delivered resilient cash flows with growing sales to third parties (on a currencyadjusted basis), Normalized Adjusted EBITDA margin and cash conversion. In particular, our business
model, including our recent focus on directing our portfolio towards higher growth and higher margin
products, has proven its resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic, with strong performance in 2020.

Our diverse mix of products, end markets, customers and geographies results in stability through economic
and raw material cycles as demonstrated by our 2020 growth in sales to third parties of 3.5% on a constant
currency basis (decrease of 2.1% on an actual currency basis). We have a strong focus on continuous
operational improvements, for example our recent cost of goods sold improvement program that focused
on fixed cost reduction, alternative chemical routes, debottlenecking and variable cost reduction, and a
demonstrated pricing excellence as well as ability to pass through costs, driving our 2020 Normalized
Adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.4%. Our track record of delivering on productivity and operational
optimization opportunities has led to an attractive financial profile resulting in high cash conversion of
76.6% in 2020 (calculated as (i) Normalized Adjusted EBITDA _less capital expenditures_ _plus change in_
operating net working capital divided by (ii) Normalized Adjusted EBITDA). We believe that our business
has a significant opportunity to drive cost savings and increase profitability margins, particularly through
our new cost savings initiatives related to our Transformation Program and because, as a standalone
company, we will no longer be part of a more pharmaceutically oriented company.

We have a strong financial trajectory, underpinned by a clear portfolio strategy towards our high-margin
Microbial Control Solutions business unit and penetration of attractive Specialty Chemical Services niches.
We have clear strategies and initiatives to grow, optimize and protect our businesses with the Microbial
Control Solutions and Specialty Chemical Services business units, with increased focus on attractive
‘‘growth’’ businesses, such as the Hygiene market field. In particular, as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic
and trends in consumer preferences, we expect that the Hygiene market field will continue to grow as
products in this market field continue to serve a critical function for customers. These growth businesses
offer high and sustainable growth rates with higher margins, which drives overall profitability.

**_Highly experienced management team, leading talented workforce and highly committed financial sponsors_**

We benefit from a strong and experienced management team, consisting of our senior management and
heads of certain corporate and business functions, with a proven track record in the specialty chemicals
markets and over 140 years of combined experience in the specialty chemicals industry. Our Chief
Operating Officer, Antje Gerber, joined LSI in 2019 and was appointed as COO in 2020, bringing
substantial experience from previous positions at Venator Materials (formerly Huntsman), HB Fuller and
Evonik. In addition to our management team, we have a lean and efficient organizational structure
powered by talent, expertise and a passion to create real value as a market leader supported by a
well-trained global workforce with high employee satisfaction reflected in long tenures, low turnover and
strong performance.

**Our Strategies**

As a result of our recent carve-out from Lonza, the Acquisition and the resulting organizational changes
and strategy review, we are fully focused on delivering our growth strategy, which builds on four main
pillars:

**_Unlock growth_**

We are confident that we can unlock growth in our business through our numerous initiatives and are well
positioned to address and capitalize on current, fundamental market trends. These trends include
tightening regulatory landscapes, evolving customer preferences, increasing focus on the environment and
sustainability, increasing focus on safeguarding people and resources and growing end-customer base.

The tightening regulatory landscapes around the world, in particular in the United States and Europe, are
creating opportunities for us to utilize our regulatory expertise to grow our business. In particular, we
believe our Hygiene market field is well positioned for growth by expanding our complementary
formulation platform and supplemental registration model in North America and capitalizing on
significant upcoming BPR-related commercial opportunities in Europe.

Evolving customer preferences present opportunities for us to grow our business in new end markets. For
example, we are seeing an increased demand for low temperature laundry applications in Home and
Personal Care and have developed new products to address that market. Additionally, the implementation
of 5G telecommunications systems presents an opportunity for us to develop and market 5G-related
electronics applications within our Composites market field. Further, the increasing global focus on the
environment and sustainability has opened up new R&D-driven opportunities, particularly in our Paints
and Coatings market field, such as marine antifouling, and within our Composites market field for light
weight-related opportunities in aerospace applications. In addition, concerns about safeguarding people’s
wellbeing and resources is creating opportunities in Hygiene through forward integration of ingredients
into ready-to-use formulated solutions and in Wood Protection through demand for replacement
technologies that address environmental and regulatory concerns. For example, upcoming BPR regulations
in Europe will impact the production and use of creosote (which we do not produce) and we expect that
our substitute product, Tanasote, will be well positioned to address these upcoming regulations.

The growing middle class, particularly in South America, is leading to above average growth in consumer
related markets such as home and personal care and hygiene, and we have seen year-on-year growth in our
Microbial Control Solutions business unit in Latin America of greater than 42% in 2020. We expect growth
to continue in these markets and believe we are well positioned through our global manufacturing
footprint and our extensive R&D and regulatory capability to continue to address customer needs in these
markets.

**_Drive innovation_**

Our research and development operations are key to maintaining our sector-leading innovation and ability
to respond to market developments and customer needs and are a core component of our customer
offering. Our ability to anticipate and navigate the regulatory environments in key jurisdictions allows us to
commercialize our products. We have a full pipeline of innovation projects across market fields which we
manage rigorously through a stage-gated R&D process, which was implemented in 2020 to focus more on
market and customer driven innovations. This process aims to continuously evaluate projects to assess
their ability to deliver real value to our customers and ability to successfully make it to market.

Our innovation projects are driven by market and customer needs for applications that make a difference
and are a key driver of revenue growth, particularly for our Microbial Control Solutions business unit.
Many of our projects are joint R&D efforts with our customers, which are sometimes co-funded by our
customers. Some of our innovations use the capabilities of our cross-business unit network, for example,
the development and scale up of new antidandruff products by our Specialty Chemical Services business
unit for a customer need within our Microbial Control Solutions business unit. We expect to continue to

8


-----

invest in our R&D, maintaining similar levels of investment in R&D as in past years and to look for ways
to capitalize on cross-business unit capabilities to enhance our offerings.

Our ability to commercialize the knowledge we have from our years of regulatory experience sets us apart
from our competitors. We work closely with regulators throughout the entire development process to
ensure that we have solutions for upcoming regulatory challenges. We will continue to develop strong
relationships with key regulatory stakeholders and focus on and develop our regulatory expertise to
strengthen our customer relationships through joint projects with our customers.

**_Manage the portfolio_**

We will continue to focus on highly attractive end markets that offer significant structural growth potential
with an aim to expand our operations in profitable niche markets within the high-growth microbial control
market and attractive niches within the specialty chemical services market. We intend to utilize our
strengths in research and development and regulatory expertise to continue to develop and commercialize
new products for these end markets. We continue to actively manage our portfolio, with clear strategies for
each of the business units and market fields, particularly within our higher-growth businesses. We expect
these strategies will lead to topline and profitability increases going forward.

We are experiencing above-market growth rates in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit, which is
expected to exhibit strong underlying end-market growth of 4.3% CAGR over the period from 2019 to
2025, complemented by selected growth opportunities in other attractive market verticals. This market
growth is driven by a shift to more formulated and higher value products as a result of regulatory and
consumer preferences. Our strong R&D initiatives are particularly vital in our Hygiene, Home and
Personal Care, Paints and Coatings and Wood and Crop Protection market fields. We expect growth in end
markets served by our Hygiene market field, which accounted for 16% of our 2020 sales to third parties, to
be 9.1% over the period from 2019 to 2025 and to be largely driven by Covid-19 increasing the need for
protection of health creating a ‘‘new normal’’ in the use of disinfectants and a permanent shift to more
formulated and higher value products due to tightening regulatory landscapes. Growth in end markets
served by our Home and Personal Care market field, which accounted for 14% of our 2020 sales to third
parties, is expected to be 2.4% and is largely driven by increasing customer awareness of preservation
systems and smart formulations to reduce preservative concentrations and Covid-19 positively impacting
the home care market due to higher hygiene sensitivity and demand for cleanliness and germ-free
solutions. Growth in end markets served by our Wood Protection market field, which accounted for 19% of
our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be 3.5% and is largely driven by increasing popularity of wood
construction due to climate neutrality and sustainability and growth in North America due to higher usage
of wood in construction and greater variety in applications. Growth in end markets served by our Paints
and Coatings market field, which accounted for 7% of our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be
4.5% and is largely driven by positive sales mix-effect due to shifts from solvent-based paints to waterbased paints and increasing usage of high-performance paints in emerging markets. Growth in end markets
served by our Material Protection market field, which accounted for 6% of our 2020 sales to third parties,
is expected to be 4.2% and is largely driven by oil and gas exploration by fracking as well as the
fast-growing plastics industry.

For Specialty Chemical Services we are targeting steady GDP-linked growth, driven by fast growing niche
businesses, particularly in the Composite Materials and CDMO market fields. The strong growth in these
areas is largely driven by focused innovation initiatives. Our highly profitable Composite Materials market
field is focused on serving the growing demand in the industrial and electronics end markets, while CDMO
activities are shifting towards higher value products and improved capacity utilization. Growth in end
markets (e.g., base chemicals such as ethylene and acetylene and pharmaceutical and vitamin
intermediates) served by our PIC market field, which accounted for 24% of our 2020 sales to third parties,
is largely driven by a clear focus on the most attractive niches, including high-tech industrial applications,
and serving pharma and vitamin end markets and underlying Vitamin B3 consumption growth, particularly
growth in animal feed and supplements penetration. Growth in end markets served by our CDMO market
field, which accounted for 7% of our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be 2% to 3% per year from
2019 to 2025 and is largely driven by increasing outsourcing of agrochemical players as well as serving
customers across various industries in need for complex chemical processes or fermentation. Growth in
end markets (e.g., electronics, industrial and transportation) served by our Composite Materials market
field, which accounted for 4% of our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be 6.8% per year from 2019
to 2025 and is largely driven by growth of high performance composite materials in electronics and
industrial applications.

9

**_Business transformation and operational excellence_**

Our business plan includes organic initiatives based on sales and innovation projects to drive topline
growth. The portfolio shift towards high-margin Microbial Control Solutions end markets and
development of attractive Specialty Chemical Services niches is anticipated to drive growth and increase
sales to third parties to above CHF2.1 billion by 2025. We have already seen that our increased focus on
these markets in 2020 has contributed to higher growth, notably in areas with above average profitability
(e.g., Hygiene with fully fledge solutions compared to raw material sales). This has already contributed not
only to top line growth but also to substantial margin improvement for our Microbial Control Solutions
business unit in 2020. We believe our organic initiatives will secure our business plan as a standalone
company for the next five years. Additionally, under new ownership we expect to be able to tap into further
growth ideas and M&A beyond the current business plan.

The second part of our business transformation is operational excellence. Existing cost savings initiatives in
operations will continue to gain momentum over the medium term. ‘‘Pivot’’ is an established program
aimed at cost of goods sold improvements, including fixed cost reduction, alternative chemical routes,
debottlenecking and variable cost reduction. Pivot initially started in Visp and has since been rolled out to
other sites and has, for example, enabled our Mapleton facility to implement its Covid-19 related ramp up
in record time. ‘‘Blackbird’’ is a focused program for operational excellence at our four main Microbial
Control Solutions sites in the US with tailored projects for each facility and is already delivering benefits at
our site in Rochester. We began implementing a global supply chain integration and network optimization
in 2019, with a focus on inventory management and plan to increase customer focus supply chain
initiatives. We will also continue to improve our Visp manufacturing site with a focus on automation,
control room and plant consolidation and digitization measures. Finally, there are numerous initiatives in
operations supporting business growth in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit, with the key
initiatives being improving efficiency gains by streamlining our asset footprint and further increasing our
quat production output. Our operations organization has delivered significant gross profit improvements
and we believe it will continue to do so going forward.

In addition, following the completion of the Acquisition, we intend to implement the Transformation
Program, which is focused on cost savings opportunities related to (i) manufacturing; (ii) raw materials
procurement; (iii) indirect spend control; (iv) sales and marketing costs; (v) G&A costs; and (vi) R&D
costs. We expect to realize cost savings of CHF69 million within 18 months after the Acquisition Closing
Date and an additional CHF2 million from IT cost savings, assuming, among other things, that the
program will be implemented beginning on the Acquisition Closing Date and driven by key management.
We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to approximately CHF103 million between 2021 and 2023 in
connection with these initiatives, comprising: (i) approximately CHF58 million in expected one-off costs,
including severance costs, IT costs and program delivery costs, including consulting, financial and legal
advisory fees in connection with implementing our Transformation Program; and (ii) approximately
CHF45 million in expected capital expenditure related to manufacturing savings.

**The Transactions**

**_The Acquisition_**

On February 8, 2021, Swiss Holdco, an entity indirectly owned by Bain Capital and the Cinven Funds,
entered into the Sale and Purchase Agreement to acquire the LSI Business from the Seller. We currently
expect the Acquisition to complete during the course of the second half of 2021. The consummation of the
Acquisition is, however, subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including customary
antitrust and regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. Under the terms of the
Sale and Purchase Agreement, Swiss Holdco has agreed to take all necessary steps to obtain the required
clearances following the signing of the Sale and Purchase Agreement. If closing has not occurred on the
date falling twelve months after the signing date of the Sale and Purchase Agreement, the Sale and
Purchase Agreement may be terminated.

The estimated sources and uses of funds necessary to consummate the Transactions are shown in the table
below. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the actual
Acquisition Closing Date, and the actual purchase price for the Acquisition, fluctuations in currency
exchange rates for amounts not denominated in Swiss francs, the amount of the Equity Contribution (as
defined below) or other sources made available and differences between estimated and actual fees and
expenses. In particular, the purchase price under the Sale and Purchase Agreement as shown below
reflects the agreed purchase price of CHF4,225 million, less estimated purchase price adjustments under

(7) Represents estimated fees and expenses associated with the Transactions, including net interest expense that will accrue on
proceeds of the Notes deposited into escrow, underwriting, financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other
transaction costs and professional fees.

All related party financing arrangements between Lonza Group and the LSI Business will be terminated
prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, except for certain related party loan receivables denominated in US
dollars which will be acquired on the Acquisition Closing Date, in each case, pursuant to the terms of the
Sale and Purchase Agreement. In addition, the Sale and Purchase Agreement provides for a set-off
mechanism, pursuant to which, following such termination of related party financing arrangements, certain
net related party receivables or certain related party net payables with Lonza Group may remain
outstanding. Such related party receivables or payables with Lonza Group, if any, will then be off-set
against the purchase price for the Acquisition.

The Sale and Purchase Agreement contains customary warranties given by the Seller as to capacity, title
and certain business matters as well as customary signing to closing covenants given by the Seller

regarding, among other things, the conduct of the business and the affairs of the LSI Business pending

certain actions to facilitate the ability of the LSI Business to operate on a standalone basis, including,

engage in the development, manufacture, marketing, sale or supply of products currently produced by the
LSI Business (or substantially or substantively similar to any such products) in any geographies where the
LSI Business is active or where the LSI Business had already invested, or had made substantial plans to
move into immediately prior to the Acquisition Closing Date.

The Seller and the LSI Business each respectively agreed that they would not induce or attempt to induce
any supplier of each other’s business to cease to supply, or to restrict or vary the terms of supply, to the
other’s business. Also, the Seller and the LSI Business each agreed that, for two years from the Acquisition
Closing Date, neither party would induce or attempt to induce any employee from the other party’s
respective business to enter into employment with it.

Prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuers and their subsidiaries will not have control over the

**_Escrow Accounts_**

Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from
the offering of the Notes into the Escrow Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow
Agent. See ‘‘—The Offering—Collateral.’’

The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied
promptly (and in any event within three business days). See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—
_Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of_
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.’’ If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow_
Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special
mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of
the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to,
but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured
_Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of_
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the_
_conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to_
_redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Account may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without_
_relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.’’_

In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes,
and Luxco 3, in the case of the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate
amounts as are required in order to enable such Issuer to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow
Account fees, negative interest on the Escrow Account balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest
and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption
date (the ‘‘Escrow Equity Commitment’’), pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter. The holders of the
Notes will not have any direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the
Issuers’ rights to enforcement under the Escrow Equity Commitment. See ‘‘Description of the Senior
_Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—_
_Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—_

**Sustainability-Linked Features of the Notes**

As a part of our overarching commitment to sustainability, we are embedding material sustainability
performance indicators during our formation as an independent entity following the Acquisition. By
defining our sustainable performance targets (initially based on the targets set by Lonza Group as applied
to the LSI Business), we are sharing our commitment to reducing environmental impact with the
stakeholders, as well as taking the necessary steps to maintain a competitive advantage in the markets
where we operate.

As part of our commitment to sustainability initiatives, our Sustainability-Linked Financing Framework
(the ‘‘Framework’’) has been developed to provide a single robust methodology for sustainability-linked
financing instruments. The Framework is developed in alignment with the International Capital Market
Association’s Sustainability-Linked Bond Principles (‘‘SLBP’’), as well as the Sustainability-Linked Loan
Principles (‘‘SLLP’’) administered by the Loan Market Association. We have selected key performance
indicators (‘‘KPIs’’) and calibrated our sustainable performance targets in this context.

Our sustainability improvement initiatives focus on reducing greenhouse gas (‘‘GHG’’) emissions and waste
intensity. The reference base has been set at 2018.

GHG emissions intensity (which includes emissions from sources owned or controlled by LSI and
emissions from the generation of electricity and steam purchased by LSI) is measured in tons of CO2
equivalent based on total sales (tons CO2 equivalent / CHF millions). In 2018, the LSI Business’ GHG
emissions intensity was 484.0 tons CO2 equivalent / CHF millions. We aim to reduce GHG emissions
intensity by 36% by 2030, compared to that 2018 baseline. An interim target to reduce GHG emissions
intensity by at least 18% by 2024 has been set using our annualised 3% reduction target. Such KPI and
sustainable performance target contribute to the EU environmental objective ‘‘Climate Change
Mitigation’’, as well as the United Nations Sustainable Development Goal 13.

Waste intensity is measured in waste generated in tons based on total sales (tons / CHF millions). In 2018,
the LSI Business’ waste intensity was 49.5 tons / CHF millions. We aim to reduce waste intensity by 24% by
2030, compared to that 2018 baseline. An interim target to reduce waste intensity by at least 12% by 2024
has been set using our annualised 2% reduction target. Such KPI and sustainable performance target
contribute to the EU environmental objective ‘‘Transition to a Circular Economy’’, as well as the United
Nations Sustainable Development Goal 12.

The Indentures will require us to report no later than March 31, 2025 to the Trustee our GHG emissions
intensity and waste intensity for 2024 in accordance with the above sustainable performance targets. From
and including, 2025, the interest rate on the Notes shall be increased by up to 0.25%, unless the
Group has achieved such sustainable performance targets (which shall be confirmed by an Assurance
Letter (as defined under ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Interest’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior
_Notes—Interest’’) from a qualified provider of third-party assurance or attestation services (i.e., an auditing_
firm)). See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Interest’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—
_Interest.’’ The verification of the Group’s actual sustainable performance for 2024 relative to such_
sustainable performance targets will be made publicly available. Notwithstanding anything in this offering
memorandum to the contrary, neither our sustainability report delivered to the Trustee as described above,
nor the Framework is or will be incorporated by reference in this offering memorandum.

**The Sponsors**

_Bain Capital_

Bain Capital is a leading global private investment firm which advises and manages capital across several
asset classes, including private equity, venture capital, public equity and leveraged debt assets. Since its
inception in 1984, Bain Capital and its affiliates have completed over 1,000 transactions and have made
investments in more than 330 companies in a broad range of industries, including consumer/retail,
financial and business services, healthcare, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications.
Bain Capital’s global team of approximately 485 investment professionals creates value for its portfolio
companies through its global platform and depth of expertise, managing approximately US$120 billion of
assets in total and leveraging the firm’s shared platform to capture opportunities in strategic areas of focus.
Bain Capital has investors from across the world that include sovereign wealth funds, public pension funds,
foundations, insurance companies, family offices, high-net-worth individuals and funds of funds. Bain has a
strong track record of executing carve-out transactions across sectors, including its investments in Apex
Tool Group, Diversey, Trinseo, Brenntag, Italmatch and IMCD. Headquartered in Boston, Bain Capital
and its affiliates have offices in Chicago, Dublin, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, London, Luxembourg, Madrid,
Melbourne, Mumbai, Munich, New York, Palo Alto, San Francisco, Seoul, Shanghai, Sydney and Tokyo.

_Cinven_

Cinven is a leading international private equity firm with offices in London, Frankfurt, Guernsey, Hong
Kong, Luxembourg, Madrid, Milan, New York and Paris. Since 1988, the Cinven Funds have invested in
over 130 companies and led transactions totaling more than A100 billion. The firm’s investment focus is on
six key sectors: healthcare, business services, consumer, financial services, industrials, and technology,
media and telecommunications. Cinven’s investment strategy targets companies that are well positioned in
their respective markets and require an equity investment of A200 million or more. Using its long-standing
experience and proven economic growth strategies (such as buy and build), Cinven works closely with
management teams to facilitate growth and help its portfolio companies reach their full potential. Cinven
has a strong track record of executing carve-out transactions across sectors, including its investments in
Chryso, Ceramtec, Barentz, ThyssenKrupp Elevator, allegro, hotelbeds Group, Eurovita Holding and
Fucithamalic.

**Ranking of Notes and Guarantees**

Senior Secured Notes . . . . . . . . . . The Senior Secured Notes will:

              - be general, senior obligations of the SSN Issuer;

              - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the SSN Issuer’s
existing and future senior indebtedness, including the Senior
Facilities;

              - rank senior in right of payment to all of the SSN Issuer’s
existing and future indebtedness that is expressly subordinated
in right of payment to the Senior Secured Notes, including its
obligations in respect of its guarantee of the Senior Notes;

              - be effectively subordinated to all existing and future
indebtedness or other liabilities of the SSN Issuer that are
secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes,
to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing
such indebtedness or liabilities; and

indebtedness and other liabilities of the subsidiaries of the

Secured Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . The Note Guarantees of the Senior Secured Notes will:

              - be general, senior obligations of each relevant Guarantor;

              - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the existing and
future senior indebtedness of such Guarantor, including the

indebtedness of such Guarantor that is expressly subordinated
in right of payment to the Note Guarantee of such Guarantor;

secured by liens that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes
or the Notes Guarantees thereof, to the extent of the value of
such property and assets securing such indebtedness or

indebtedness and other liabilities of the subsidiaries of such

              - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the SUN Issuer’s

              - rank senior in right of payment to all of the SUN Issuer’s

in right of payment to the Senior Notes;

**Use of Proceeds . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The proceeds from the Offering of the Notes, together with
borrowings under the Senior Term Facilities and the Equity
Contribution will be used to: (i) fund the consideration payable for
the Acquisition, (ii) refinance certain existing debt and (iii) pay the
fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. See
‘‘Use of Proceeds.’’

**Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . .** Any payments made by the Issuers or any Guarantor with respect
to the Notes or Note Guarantees will be made without withholding
or deduction for taxes unless required by law. If such withholding

or deduction is required by law in any ‘‘relevant taxing
jurisdiction,’’ the relevant Issuer or the relevant Guarantor, as
applicable, will pay the additional amounts necessary so that the
net amounts received after the withholding or deduction is not less
than the amount that would have been received in the absence of
the withholding or deduction, subject to certain exceptions. See
‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Additional Amounts’’ and
‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Additional Amounts.’’

**Optional Redemption . . . . . . . . . .** At any time prior to, 2024, the Issuers may redeem some
or all of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the
principal amount of the Notes redeemed, _plus, in each case,_
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the
applicable redemption date plus the applicable ‘‘make whole’’
premium.

Prior to, 2024, the Issuers may, during each twelve month
period following the Issue Date, redeem up to 10% of the
aggregate principal amount of each series of the Notes (including
any additional Notes of the same series) at a redemption price
equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and
unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding,
the redemption date.

At any time prior to, 2024, the Issuers may redeem up to
40% of the aggregate principal amount of each series of Notes
using the net cash proceeds of certain equity offerings, at the
redemption price of % and % of the principal
amount of the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes
redeemed, respectively, in each case, plus accrued and unpaid
interest and additional amounts, if any, to the redemption date,
_provided that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal_
amount of such series of Notes remain outstanding after the
redemption (unless all Notes of such series are redeemed
substantially concurrently).

At any time on or after, 2024, the Issuers may redeem
some or all of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth in
‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption’’
and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption.’’

**Optional Redemption for Taxation**
**Reasons . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** If certain changes in the law (or in its interpretation) of any
relevant taxing jurisdiction impose certain withholding taxes or
other deductions on the payments on any series of Notes, the
relevant Issuer may redeem the applicable series of Notes in whole,
but not in part, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal
amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional
amounts, if any, to the redemption date. See ‘‘Description of the
_Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption for Taxation Reasons’’_
and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption for
_Taxation Reasons.’’_

change of control or upon certain asset sales, each holder of any
series of Notes may require the relevant Issuer, as applicable, to
repurchase all or a portion of the Notes of the relevant series at a
price equal to 101% of their principal amount plus accrued and
unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding,
the redemption date. However, a change of control will not be
deemed to have occurred if, pro forma for such change of control, a
specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in

_Notes—Change of Control’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—_

**Escrow Proceeds; Special**
**Mandatory Redemption . . . . . . .** Concurrently with the closing of the Offering, and pending
consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will
deposit the gross proceeds of the Offering into the Escrow
Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow
Agent. The release of the proceeds deposited in the Escrow
Accounts will be subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions,
including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the
Acquisition will be applied promptly (and in any event within three
business days). Upon delivery to the Trustee and the Escrow Agent
of an officer’s certificate stating that the conditions to the release
of the proceeds from escrow are satisfied, the Escrowed Property
will be released to the Issuers and utilized as described in ‘‘Use of
_Proceeds,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of_
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption’’ and ‘‘Description of the_
_Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.’’_
If the conditions to the release of the Escrowed Property have not
been satisfied on or prior to the business day immediately following
the Escrow Longstop Date, or upon the occurrence of certain other
events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory
redemption.

The special mandatory redemption price of the Notes will be equal
to 100% of the aggregate issue price of the Notes, plus accrued and
unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding,
such special mandatory redemption date.

In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in
the case of the Senior Secured Notes, and Luxco 3, in the case of
the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in
such aggregate amounts as are required in order to enable the
Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow Account fees,
negative interest on the Escrow Accounts’ balances and costs and
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, owing
to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption
date (the ‘‘Escrow Equity Commitment’’), pursuant to the Equity
Commitment Letter. The holders of the Notes will not have any
direct right to enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must
rely on the Issuers’ respective rights to enforcement under the
Escrow Equity Commitment.

In addition, the conditions applicable to the special mandatory
redemption may be waived by holders of the Notes representing a
majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding.

See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds;
_Special Mandatory Redemption,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—_
_Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,’’ and ‘‘Risk_
_Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions_
_precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the_
_Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Accounts_
_may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying_
_on the Escrow Equity Commitment.’’_
