**_The Notes and the Note Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to the claims of creditors, including depositors,_**
**_trade creditors and preferred stockholders (if any), of our non-Guarantor subsidiaries._**

Generally, claims of creditors, including depositors, trade creditors and preferred stockholders (if any) of
non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the Issuers, are entitled to payments of their claims from the assets of such
subsidiaries before these assets are made available for distribution to their respective parent entity or the
creditors of the Issuers and the Guarantors. Accordingly, in the event that any non-Guarantor subsidiary of
the Issuers becomes insolvent, is liquidated, reorganized or dissolved or is otherwise wound up other than
as part of a solvent transaction:

- the creditors of the Issuers and the Guarantors (including the holders of the Notes) will have no right
to proceed against the assets of such non-Guarantor subsidiary; and

- creditors of such non-Guarantor subsidiary, including depositors, trade creditors and preferred
stockholders (if any) will generally be entitled to payment in full from the sale or other disposal of the
assets of such subsidiary before the Issuers or any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder (as
applicable), will be entitled to receive any distributions from such subsidiary.

As such, the Notes and the Note Guarantees will be structurally subordinated to the creditors, including
depositors, trade creditors and any preferred stockholders (if any) of the non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the
Issuers. In addition, the Indentures will, subject to certain limitations, permit these non-Guarantor
subsidiaries to incur substantial additional indebtedness without such incurrence constituting a default
under the Indentures, and such indebtedness may also be secured. The Indentures will not contain any
limitation on the amount of other liabilities, such as deposits and trade payables, that may be incurred by
these subsidiaries.

**_Investors may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations._**

The Issuers and the Guarantors (other than US Holdco and US Bidco) (together, the ‘‘Non-U.S.
**Obligors’’) are organized or incorporated outside the United States, and their business is substantially**
conducted outside the United States. The directors and executive officers of the Non-U.S. Obligors are
non-residents of, and substantially all of their assets are located outside of, the United States. Although the
Non-U.S. Obligors will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action
under U.S. securities laws, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on the
directors and executive officers of Non-U.S. Obligors. In addition, as a substantial portion of the assets of
the Non-U.S. Obligors and their subsidiaries and those of their directors and executive officers are located
outside of the United States, you may be unable to enforce against them judgments obtained in U.S.
courts. Moreover, in light of recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Non-U.S. Obligors
may not be subject to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States.

Additionally, there is uncertainty as to whether the courts of foreign jurisdictions would enforce
(i) judgments of United States courts obtained against the Non-U.S. Obligors and the directors and
executive officers who are not residents of the United States predicated upon the civil liability provisions of
the United States federal and state securities laws or (ii) in original actions brought in such foreign
jurisdictions against us or such persons predicated upon the United States federal and state securities laws.

The United States is not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement
of judgments, other than arbitral awards, rendered in civil and commercial matters, with Switzerland,
Luxembourg and England and Wales. For further information see ‘‘Service of Process and Enforcement of
_Civil Liabilities.’’_

**_The Issuers may not be able to repurchase the Notes upon a change of control. In addition, under certain_**
**_circumstances, the Issuers may have the right to purchase all outstanding Notes in connection with a tender offer,_**
**_even if certain holders do not consent to the tender._**

If a change of control (as defined in the respective Indenture) occurs, the Issuers will be required to make
an offer to purchase all the outstanding respective Notes at a price equal to 101% of the principal amount
thereof, plus any accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of
purchase. In such a situation, the Issuers may not have enough funds to pay for all of the Notes that are

84


-----

tendered under any such offer. If a significant principal amount of Notes is tendered, the Issuers will likely
have to obtain financing to pay for the tendered Notes. However, the Issuers may not be able to obtain
such financing on acceptable terms, if at all. A change of control may also result in a mandatory
prepayment under the Senior Facilities Agreement and agreements governing any future indebtedness and
may result in the acceleration of such indebtedness. Any failure by the Issuers to offer to purchase the
Notes upon a change of control would constitute a default under the Indentures, which would, in turn,
constitute a default under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

The change of control provision contained in the Indentures may not necessarily afford you protection in
the event of certain important corporate events, including reorganizations, restructurings, mergers,
recapitalizations or other similar transactions involving us that may adversely affect you, because such
corporate events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may
not constitute a change of control as defined in the Indentures.

In addition, the occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a change of control will be
deemed not to be a change of control, provided that upon consummation thereof, a certain consolidated
net leverage ratio of the relevant Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries is met.

In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in
aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such
Notes in such tender offer and the relevant Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of
such Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the relevant
Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not
in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See
‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—
_Optional Redemption.’’_

**_The term ‘‘all or substantially all’’ in the context of a change of control has no clearly established meaning under_**
**_relevant law and is subject to judicial interpretation such that it may not be certain that a change of control has_**
**_occurred or will occur._**

Upon the occurrence of a transaction that constitutes a change of control under the respective Indenture,
the relevant Issuer will be required to make an offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes tendered. The
definition of ‘‘change of control’’ in the Indentures will include (with certain exceptions) a disposition of all
or substantially all of the assets of the relevant Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (taken as a whole), to
any person. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase ‘‘all or substantially all,’’ it
has no clearly established meaning under relevant law, varies according to the facts and circumstances of
the subject transaction and is subject to judicial interpretation. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there
may be a degree of uncertainty in ascertaining whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition
of ‘‘all or substantially all’’ of the assets of a person, and therefore it may be unclear whether a change of
control has occurred and whether the relevant Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the Notes.

**_We may dispose of certain assets or capital stock of entities in the Group._**

We may have an interest in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings, or other transactions that, in our
judgment, would be beneficial to us, even if such transactions might involve risks to you as noteholders. For
example, pursuant to a carve-out from the restriction on assets sales for ‘‘specified asset dispositions’’ and
other provisions of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Indentures, we may, under certain
circumstances, sell, convey, transfer or otherwise dispose of material assets of the Group and, if meeting
certain leverage ratios on a pro forma basis, distribute some or all of the proceeds therefrom to our
shareholders. Such a transaction would not constitute a change of control or a default under the terms of
the Notes. See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restricted
_Payments,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Definitions—Permitted Specified Asset_
_Disposition,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restricted Payments’’ and_
‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Certain Definitions—Permitted Specified Asset Disposition’’. Additionally,
we may issue, sell, transfer or otherwise dispose of the capital stock of entities in the Group for purposes of
taking a dividend or distribution that would benefit us but not benefit you as a noteholder.

**_Holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences in the event of an IPO Debt Pushdown._**

Under certain circumstances, we may undertake an IPO Debt Pushdown (as described in ‘‘Description of
_the Senior Secured Notes—IPO Debt Pushdown’’ and in ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—IPO Debt_

85


-----

_Pushdown’’), pursuant to which the Issuers are entitled to give notice that the terms of the Indentures and_
the Intercreditor Agreement (or any Additional Intercreditor Agreement (as defined in ‘‘Description of the
_Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Additional Intercreditor Agreements’’ and in ‘‘Description of the_
_Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Additional Intercreditor Agreements’’)) will automatically operate so that,_
among other things, the references to such Issuer and Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in ‘‘Description of
_the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Definitions’’ and in ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Certain_
_Definitions’’) (and all related provisions) shall apply only to the IPO Pushdown Entity (as defined in_
‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—IPO Debt Pushdown’’ and in ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—
_IPO Debt Pushdown’’) and its Restricted Subsidiaries. In such event, each holding company of the IPO_
Pushdown Entity would be released from its obligations under the applicable Indenture.

In either case, such modifications to the terms of the Notes could be treated for U.S. federal income tax
purposes as a deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to such modifications for (ii) new Notes
as in place after such modifications (the ‘‘New Notes’’). If such modifications result in a deemed exchange
for U.S. federal income tax purposes, it would generally be treated as a taxable transaction for U.S. federal
income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the Notes would be required to recognize any gain or
loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the New Notes deemed issued in such a deemed
exchange could be treated as issued with original issue discount. In such event, U.S. Holders (as defined
under ‘‘Certain Tax Consequences—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations’’) would be required to
include the original issue discount in their income as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash
corresponding to such income. In addition, the determination of whether the New Notes are treated as
‘‘contingent payment debt instruments’’ as a result of the possibility of additional payments, as further
described under ‘‘Certain Tax Consequences—Certain United States Federal Income Tax Considerations—
_Characterization of the Notes,’’ would be made at the time of the modification. U.S. Holders should consult_
their own tax advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating to potential modifications
of the Notes in connection with the IPO Debt Pushdown.

It is also possible that the IPO Debt Pushdown could result in a taxable event for tax purposes other than
U.S. federal income tax purposes.

**_Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to_**
**_revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time._**

One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings
address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining
the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the
potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed above and
other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or
hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time.
No assurances can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a
credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment,
circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit
rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and
terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

**_Certain covenants and events of default will be suspended if we receive investment grade ratings._**

Each Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the date of such Indenture, the Notes issued
under such Indenture receive an investment grade rating of Baa3 or better by Moody’s and BBB or better
by S&P, and no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, then beginning that day and
continuing until such time as such Notes are no longer rated investment grade by either ratings agency,
certain covenants will cease to be applicable to such Notes. See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—
_Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status’’ and ‘‘Description_
_of the Senior Notes—Certain Covenants—Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade_
_Status.’’ At any time when these covenants are suspended, we will be able to, among other things, incur_
additional indebtedness, pay cash dividends and redeem subordinated indebtedness without restriction,
each of which may conflict with the interests of holders of the Notes. There can be no assurance that the
Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating if achieved will be maintained.

**_The Notes may not become or remain listed on the Exchange._**

Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited for the listing of and
permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. However, there can be no assurance
that the Notes will become or remain listed. If the Issuers cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and
the admission to dealing on the Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or
maintain such listing, the Issuers may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the
Exchange. Listing of any of the Notes on the Exchange does not imply that a public offering of any of the
Notes in the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man has been authorized. Although no assurance is made as to
the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized
listing exchange for comparable issuers, failure to be approved for listing of the Notes on the Official List
of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange or the delisting of the Notes from the Official List
of the Exchange or another listing exchange may have an adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes
in the secondary market.

**_You may face foreign currency exchange as a result of investing in the Notes._**

The Senior Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the
Senior Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant
changes in the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors
over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in
the effective yield of the Senior Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a
U.S. dollar basis.

**_The Indentures will not be qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended._**

The Indentures will not be required to, and will not be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of
1939, as amended (the ‘‘TIA’’) and will not incorporate or include and will not be subject to any of the
provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided
under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting
preferential collections by the trustee or conflicting interests of the trustee. See ‘‘Description of the Senior
_Secured Notes’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes.’’_

**THE TRANSACTIONS**

**_The Acquisition_**

On February 8, 2021, Swiss Holdco, an entity indirectly owned by Bain Capital and the Cinven Funds,
entered into the Sale and Purchase Agreement to acquire from the Seller the LSI Business. We currently
expect the Acquisition to complete during the course of the second half of 2021. The consummation of the
Acquisition is, however, subject to the satisfaction of certain closing conditions, including customary
antitrust and regulatory approvals and the performance of certain closing actions. Under the terms of the
Sale and Purchase Agreement, Swiss Holdco has agreed to take all necessary steps to obtain the required
clearances following the signing of the Sale and Purchase Agreement. If closing has not occurred on the
date falling twelve months after the signing date of the Sale and Purchase Agreement, the Sale and
Purchase Agreement may be terminated. See ‘‘Use of Proceeds’’ for the estimated sources and uses
necessary to consummate the Acquisition.

Under the Sale and Purchase Agreement, all related party financing arrangements (except for certain
related party loan arrangements denominated in U.S. Dollars) between Lonza Group and the LSI Business
will be terminated prior to the Acquisition Closing Date. In addition, the Sale and Purchase Agreement
provides for a set-off mechanism, pursuant to which, following such termination of related party financing
arrangements, certain net related party receivables or certain related party net payables between Lonza
Group and the LSI Business may remain outstanding. Such related party receivables or payables, if any,
will then be off-set against the purchase price for the Acquisition.

The Sale and Purchase Agreement contains customary warranties given by the Seller as to capacity, title
and certain business matters as well as customary signing to closing covenants given by the Seller
regarding, among other things, the conduct of the business and the affairs of the LSI Business pending
closing of the Acquisition. The Seller’s liability for any breach of a warranty is subject to certain thresholds
and limitations. In addition, pursuant to the Sale and Purchase Agreement, the Seller has agreed to take
certain actions to facilitate the ability of the LSI Business to operate on a standalone basis, including,
subject to certain exceptions, the provision of a number of services pursuant to the Global Services
Agreement, Site Services Agreements and Supply and Tolling Agreements, including relating to accounting
and risk services, IT, procurement, real estate, human resources, compliance, tax (in certain jurisdictions)
and others, to the LSI Business, following the Acquisition. See ‘‘Business—Material Agreements—
_Post-Acquisition Arrangements with Lonza.’’_

Further, the Seller has agreed that, for three years from the Acquisition Closing Date, neither it nor its
affiliates will engage in the territory in which LSI will directly or indirectly acquire, own, participate or
engage in the development, manufacture, marketing, sale or supply of products currently produced by the
LSI Business (or substantially or substantively similar to any such products) in any geographies where the
LSI Business is active or where the LSI Business had already invested, or had made substantial plans to
move into immediately prior to the Acquisition Closing Date.

Prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, the Issuers and their subsidiaries will not have control over the
boards of directors of the Target Companies. Such boards of directors of the Target Companies and their
management will be required, prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, to manage the LSI Business under
their own responsibility and in a manner that is in the best interests of the LSI Business. See ‘‘Risk
_Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—The Issuers do not currently control the LSI Business and will not_
_control the LSI Business until the Acquisition Closing Date.’’_

**_Escrow Accounts_**

Pending the consummation of the Acquisition, the Initial Purchasers will deposit the gross proceeds from
the offering of the Notes into the Escrow Accounts. The Escrow Accounts will be controlled by the Escrow
Agent. See ‘‘Summary—The Offering—Collateral.’’

The release of the Escrowed Property from the Escrow Accounts is subject to the satisfaction of certain
conditions, including that the funds required to pay the consideration for the Acquisition will be applied
promptly (and in any event within three business days). See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—
_Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption’’ and ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of_
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.’’ If these conditions are not satisfied on or before the Escrow_
Longstop Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special
mandatory redemption. The special mandatory redemption price for the Notes will be equal to 100% of
the aggregate issue price of the Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to,

88


-----

but excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured
_Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of_
_Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the_
_conditions precedent to the release of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to_
_redeem the Notes, but the Escrow Account may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without_
_relying on the Escrow Equity Commitment.’’_

In the event of a special mandatory redemption, the SUN Issuer, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes,
and Luxco 3, in the case of the Senior Notes, will be required to fund the relevant Issuer in such aggregate
amounts as are required in order to enable the Issuers to pay any funding shortfall, including Escrow
Account fees, negative interest on the Escrow Account balances and costs and accrued and unpaid interest
and additional amounts, if any, owing to the holders of the Notes on such special mandatory redemption
date, pursuant to the Equity Commitment Letter. The holders of the Notes will not have any direct right to
enforce the Escrow Equity Commitment, and must rely on the Issuers’ rights to enforcement under the
Escrow Equity Commitment. See ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special
_Mandatory Redemption,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory_
_Redemption,’’ and ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Transactions—If the conditions precedent to the release_
_of the Escrowed Property are not satisfied, the Issuers will be required to redeem the Notes, but the Escrow_
_Account may not have sufficient funds to cover such redemption without relying on the Escrow Equity_
_Commitment.’’_

**Overview**

We are a leading global provider of microbial control solutions across various consumer and industrial
markets. We also offer specialty chemical products and services covering composites and specialty
chemicals. Headquartered in Basel, Switzerland, we are building on more than 120 years of the business’
history as a trusted specialty chemicals supplier.

With more than 670 individual products and services, we focus on attractive end markets with significant
growth potential. We serve more than 5,300 clients worldwide, and our products are deeply imbedded into
the value chains of our key customers, with many of whom we have long-standing relationships. We have 18
manufacturing facilities, supported by the market-leading expertise of our 13 R&D centers and a broad
network of 35 sales offices across our key geographical regions of EIMEA, APAC and the Americas. We
have what we believe to be a market-leading regulatory expertise, including on the European Union and
the United States markets.

For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had total sales of CHF1,825 million,
CHF1,747 million and CHF1,716 million, respectively. Our profit for the period was CHF79 million,
CHF73 million and CHF98 million, respectively, for the same periods. Our pro forma Adjusted EBITDA
for the year ended December 31, 2020 was CHF431 million.

We report sales to third parties on a business unit level and a market field level. Our operations comprise
the following two business units:

- _Microbial Control Solutions business unit is a market-leading trusted and innovative supplier of_
microbial control solutions and chemical technologies used in a wide range of industrial and consumer
products to control harmful organisms including viruses and bacteria. Its product development and
application support is focused on six attractive addressable markets with significant growth potential.
Overall, it has broader market presence (in terms of product spectrum) than any competitor in the
microbial control industry. The business unit’s vast portfolio of over 470 individual products and
services is backed by market-leading technical expertise of nine major regional and two smaller R&D
sites employing 176 R&D specialists as at December 31, 2020. The business unit has a proven track
record of innovation with a total of 36 new products launched in the past three years. Our Microbial
Control Solutions business unit has what we believe to be an unmatched regulatory expertise in such
highly regulated markets as the European Union and the United States and, as at December 31, 2020,
it employed 75 regulatory specialists. In the United States, it currently has 42 biocidal active
ingredients registered or under review with the EPA, as well as 412 federal registrations and 1,742
supplemental registrations for formulations. In the European Union, it supports 20 different active
ingredients under various product types under the BPR, the regulation governing the manufacture
and use of biocidal products, which results in 110 separate ingredients / product type combinations
supported by individual registration dossiers. The business unit also supports 540 national
registrations in various European countries, which are required for BPR product authorizations. Its

95


-----

specialists remain on the forefront of the evolving regulatory environment to help ensure that current
and future products comply with varying regional specific regulations that underpin the wide range of
industries and markets it addresses. The business unit’s products are manufactured on 17 sites in nine
countries and it serves more than 4,300 customers through 29 dedicated sales offices strategically
located across EIMEA, APAC and the Americas. Its direct sales accounted for 91% of all its sales to
third parties for the year.

For the year ended December 31, 2020, the Microbial Control Solutions business unit generated
CHF1,068 million sales to third parties, or 65% of our total sales to third parties for the year. For the
same year, it represented 64% of our total Adjusted EBITDA after reversing carve out adjustments
for the year. See ‘‘Summary—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Business Unit
_Information—Adjusted EBITDA After Reversal of Carveout Adjustments’’ and ‘‘Presentation of Financial_
_and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.’’_

The Microbial Control Solutions business unit operates the following six market fields focused on end
market applications, ordered in descending order of their respective profit contribution:

� The Hygiene market field provides critical hygiene and disinfection solutions for professional use
in workspace or public environments, the healthcare industry (hospitals and production facilities
of pharmaceutical companies) and other ready-to-use products, such as concentrates and wipes,
as well as household use, including sanitation and disinfection of bathrooms and kitchens and
washing, disinfecting wipes and hand sanitizers. This market field is a global active-heavy leader,
with approximately 700 customers, and is constantly expanding into formulations. For the year
ended December 31, 2020, this market field generated CHF265 million of sales to third parties.

� The _Home and Personal Care market field focuses on chemical solutions for home care_
(preservation of customer formulations), the beauty industry (hair care, including anti-dandruff
agents, and skin care) and food emulsifier ingredients. This market field is a leader in the
anti-dandruff business and serves approximately 900 customers. For the year ended December 31,
2020, this market field generated CHF238 million of sales to third parties.

� The Wood Protection market field delivers solutions to protect and enhance wood with innovative
technologies so that its life is improved and its uses are expanded. Its key products include
pressure treatment solutions for residential, commercial and agricultural use, industrial treatment
for heavy duty applications and a variety of wood specialties, such as fire retardants. We are a
leader in wood protection solutions, with approximately 1,100 customers. For the year ended
December 31, 2020, this market field generated CHF313 million of sales to third parties.

� The Paints and Coatings market field provides solutions that protect coated surfaces from algae,
fungi or fouling or preserve products in storage. Its key products include in-can preservatives
(especially for water-based paints), dry-film applications in paints (including for use as
anti-foulants on ships to reduce drag and improve fuel efficiency, and in aquaculture), polymer
emulsions and other specialties. This market field is an active-heavy leader in its segment, with
approximately 700 customers. For the year ended December 31, 2020, this market field generated
CHF119 million of sales to third parties.

� The Material Protection market field produces specialty biocides and chemical additives to protect
various materials and increase end product efficiency. It is focused on solutions for the plastics,

**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

We believe that the factors discussed below have significantly affected our results of operations, financial
condition and cash flow in the historical periods for which financial information is presented in this
offering memorandum, and that these factors will continue to have a material influence on our results of
operations, financial condition and cash flow in the future.

**_General economic conditions and demand in our end markets_**

The chemical industry generally and our addressable markets are impacted by general economic
conditions. Historically, demand has been generally correlated to GDP growth in our addressable markets
both regionally and globally.

We produce a diverse array of product types and specialize in microbial control for personal care as well as
for the protection of homes, schools, workplaces and environment from mold and other potential
pathogens and also offer custom development and manufacturing of specialty chemicals and composites to
support the electronics, aerospace, food and agrochemical industries. Our products have applications in a
variety of end markets, including electronics, agrochemicals, pharmaceuticals and oil and gas. While the
level of demand for each of our product types and in each of our end markets is affected by factors specific

97


-----

to that product type and that particular end market, certain overarching global trends have an impact
across the product types and end markets. These include demographic changes such as population growth,
longer life expectancies and urbanization, as well as the impact of an increasing global focus on energy
conservation and green products. Demand for our customers’ end products is also affected by
macroeconomic factors, such as the correlation between demand for construction products and
infrastructure spending and economic conditions. The fluctuations in demand for our customers’ end
products in turn affects the demand for our products. For example, 2019 was a challenging year for our
electronics business, as a combination of slower economic activity and ongoing reduction in demand for
electronics depressed demand for our composite material products, as well as for our vitamin B3 sales due
to reduced demand for nutritional feeds due to African swine fever impacting livestock populations in
China.

Demand for our products also varies in the geographic regions that we serve. Historically, demand in
Europe and North America has been driven by changes in demographics, customer requirements for
high-quality products and stringent health and safety regulations. Demand in developing regions has been
driven by demographic factors, such as population growth (through a growing middle class, in particular),
ongoing industrialization and urbanization, as well as infrastructure spending.

**_Raw materials and product pricing_**

Raw material prices can be volatile and comprise the largest portion of our costs of goods sold,
contributing 65.8%, 63.6% and 62.2% for the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively.
The nature of our markets, as well as our market positions and differentiated product offerings, allow us to
manage the majority of our exposure to raw material price fluctuations by generally passing through
increases in the prices of raw materials to our customers.

Key raw materials are based on petrochemical feedstocks (predominantly liquefied petroleum gas propane
and naphtha, durene, PMDA, acetone, acetic acid and beta picoline), ethylene (predominantly synthetic
fatty alcohols and ethylene oxide), copper (predominantly copper metal, copper carbonate, and copper
oxide), and chrome ore (predominantly chromic acid). Many suppliers operate globally with some focusing
on a regional approach. Prices of the majority of raw materials (by cost) are in part dependent on crude oil
prices but are also influenced by supply and demand of each product. Supply contracts are normally
entered into on a one to three-year basis with price adjustments on a monthly or annual basis. We buy raw
materials either under these supplier contracts or via the spot market, depending on which is more
favorable. In the year ended December 31, 2020, our top five raw materials by expenditure were LPG/
LVN, acetone, chromic acid, copper carbonate and copper metal, which comprised 4.5%, 3.9%, 3.9%,
3.8% and 3.5%, respectively, of our total raw material costs for the period.

Our pricing approach and the pricing provisions in our customer agreements vary across businesses and
market fields. Depending on the market field and customer, our customer agreements may include price
adjustment provisions which allow us to adjust prices based on certain factors, including without limitation
raw material prices and energy costs. In these cases, we may be able to pass through corresponding
increases in selling prices subject to lag time, and on the other hand, declines in raw material prices have a
direct impact on our sales to third parties. Some of our customer agreements include pricing terms which
restrict our ability to adjust pricing if certain purchase volumes are achieved.

Generally, in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit, our product pricing is based on the value we
provide to customers, including with regards to regulatory approvals, and therefore not necessarily directly
correlated with raw material costs. For products in our Specialty Chemicals Services business unit, for
which product pricing tends to be more directly correlated with raw material costs, we may have price
adjustment provisions to allow us to adjust prices based on certain factors such as raw material prices.

In order to minimize the risk of higher raw material prices, we hedge the commodity price risk for propane
and naphtha via financial hedges, whereas for other areas we rely on our ability to pass on raw material
price increases to customers through sales price adjustments. Approximately 20-30% of our naphtha and
propane raw material expenditure is not hedged.

**_Regulatory requirements_**

In all jurisdictions in which we operate, our products and services are subject to laws, rules, regulations and
technical standards at international, supranational, national, state and municipal levels. In particular, this
regulatory framework governs the design, manufacture, installation, operation and product safety of our

98


-----

products and services, and is mainly outlined in applicable industry standards and industry-made
regulations, including ISO and cGMP standards. In addition, we are subject to regulatory requirements
concerning product standards for energy efficiency and sustainability.

These and other applicable laws are amended and revised from time to time, typically in ways that increase
the technical and safety standards applicable to products manufactured after their effective date. Such
amendments and revisions may require us to update our product designs and creation procedures to
ensure our products qualify for the necessary operating licenses and otherwise comply with the new
requirements. The cost of compliance with these laws can be significant, impacting our operating and
compliance costs and thereby our results of operations.

The costs of regulatory compliance are incurred throughout our business, such as in new product
development, product registrations and product modifications to adapt to regulatory requirements in
various jurisdictions.

Changes in regulations affecting our customers’ wide range of activities often have an impact on demand
for our products. For instance, sales volumes of molluscicides have decreased in the EU since regulations
have reduced the concentration of metaldehyde allowed in their formulations since February 2020.
Regulators have also increased scrutiny of zinc pyrithione, which is used in anti-dandruff products, in
particular in the EU and Canada.

At the same time, regulation is a key driver of sales in our Microbial Control Solutions business, as we
believe we have a leading regulatory expertise in all of our key markets. For instance, in the Hygiene
market field, regulatory developments in Europe and North America are expected to lead to a reduced
number of suppliers in the market and further strengthen our position. In the Paints and Coatings market
field, we have strong regulatory competency in keeping markets open for customers in an environment of
decreasing numbers of permitted biocides. See also ‘‘Regulation—EU and UK Regulations—Industry and
_Product Related Regulations—Biocides and cosmetics—BPR and the Cosmetics Directive.’’_

**_Environmental considerations_**

Our operations are subject to extensive and continuously evolving environmental laws and regulations.
These requirements govern, among other things, the manufacture, storage, handling, treatment,
transportation and disposal of hazardous substances and wastes, wastewater discharges and air emissions
including greenhouse gases. We have invested, and will continue to invest, financial and technical resources
in order to achieve and maintain compliance with environmental requirements. Environmental
considerations can also impact the markets in which we operate, including our position with respect to our
competitors.

The main regulations relating to the safe use of substances and chemicals affecting our industry are the
BPR regulation in the European Union and FIFRA in the United States, and to a lesser degree the
REACH regulation in the European Union and TSCA in the United States, which impose significant
obligations on the chemicals industry with respect to the testing, evaluation, assessment and registration of
substances. The obligations imposed by these and other regulations are expensive and time-consuming and
lead to increased production costs and reduced operating margins for chemical products. In addition, we
may also incur costs in connection with the restoration and decommissioning of former manufacturing
sites. For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, our aggregate capital expenditures on
compliance with environmental laws and regulations amounted to CHF7 million, CHF16 million and
CHF16 million, respectively, which represented 7%, 17% and 18% of our capital expenditures for the
relevant years. For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, our aggregate operational expenses
on environmental, health and security (‘‘EHS’’) concerns amounted to CHF9 million, CHF11 million and
CHF15 million, respectively, while our capital expenditures on EHS amounted to CHF20 million,
CHF30 million and CHF31 million, respectively.

We are committed to principles of environmental responsibility and are at the forefront of sector
innovation by responding to market developments, delivering tailored solutions. This includes an
increasing focus on the environment and sustainability, including, for example, the production of the
Tanasote preservative, an innovative oil-based alternative to traditional creosote. We have invested and
plan to continue to invest in a catalytic converter at a continuously running plant at our Visp site to reduce
our nitrous oxide emissions at that plant by 98% per annum by the end of 2021. We expect this investment
to total approximately CHF12 million between 2019 and 2022, with CHF6 million of this investment
conducted in the year ended December 31, 2020. See also ‘‘Regulation.’’

**_Coronavirus pandemic_**

The outbreak of Covid-19 and measures to prevent its spread, including restrictions on travel, imposition
of quarantines, prolonged closures of workplaces and other businesses, and the related impact from
closure of supply chains, customers and associated disruptions in consumer demand has had various
impacts on our performance.

Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit has generally performed well during the Covid-19
pandemic, as many of its products are actively used in the global effort to control this ongoing public health
crisis. In particular, 16 of our formulations have been recently approved by the EPA to be labelled
‘‘efficacious against SARS-CoV-2’’. In 2020, the Covid-19 pandemic was the primary driver of growth in
sales to third parties of the Hygiene market field from CHF170 million for the year ended December 31,
2019 to CHF265 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, or by 55.9%. In addition, the Home and
Personal Care market field saw increased interest in its preservation and laundry offerings. However,
various social restrictions resulted in reduced market demand for skin care, hair care and food products, all
of which are addressable end markets of the business unit’s Home and Personal Care market field.
Paintings and Coatings, Material Protection and Crop Protection market fields all had reduced sales to
third parties due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit has been more severely affected by the Covid-19 pandemic.
The pandemic’s negative impacts on transportation and demand for electronics were the main drivers of a
decrease in its Composite Materials market fields’ sales to third parties by CHF18 million, or 20.2%,
year-on-year in 2020, and declines in PMDA also contributed to a decrease in sales of the PIC market field
of CHF26 million, or 6.1%, year-on-year in 2020.

At the same time, primarily driven by reduced activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic, our total
operational expenditure as a percentage of sales to third parties decreased from 20.6% for the year ended
December 31, 2019 to 18.5% for the year ended December 31, 2020 (with particular decreases in
marketing and distribution costs, as well as administration costs and general overheads, driven by lower
spend on travel, consulting services, trade shows and conferences). See also ‘‘Risk Factors—The outbreak of
_Covid-19 has had and may continue to have a negative impact on the sales and operations of some of our_
_market fields.’’ On the other hand, we incurred CHF2.3 million of direct costs, such as purchasing masks_
and performing temperature checks. We received governmental support, mainly in China, with a value of
CHF1.4 million.

In addition, these corporate cost allocations do not fully reflect our contractual relationships with Lonza

**_Operational improvement measures_**

We operate in an industry where efficiency improvements and cost savings are crucial in order to maintain
or improve competitiveness and profitability. In the years under review, our operational improvement
measures focused broadly on the following key areas: (i) optimizing our cost of goods sold by reducing
fixed costs, pursuing alternative chemical formulations, removing bottlenecks in our manufacturing
processes and reducing variable costs; (ii) improving operational excellence at four key manufacturing
sites; (iii) integrating our global supply chain; (iv) increasing automation and digitalization to enable
efficiency at our Visp site; and (v) improving operational leverage and economies of scale in our Microbial
Control Solutions business. We have incurred certain restructuring costs in connection with our
operational improvement measures, amounting to CHF5 million, CHF22 million and CHF6 million for the
years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively.

**_Currency fluctuations_**

We are exposed to translation and transactional foreign exchange risks. Due to the broad scope of our
international operations, a substantial portion of our assets, liabilities, sales and expenses are denominated
in currencies other than the Swiss franc. Our predominant exposures are the U.S. dollar and the euro.
Further main foreign exchange exposures relate to British pounds sterling and Chinese yuan. Changes in
the exchange rates between these currencies can affect our operations and financial position as a result of
translational exchange rate effects. These effects arise because the financial results of our subsidiaries are
measured in the currency of the primary economic environment in which the subsidiary operates (our
functional currency). The results of operations and assets and liabilities of a number of our global
subsidiaries are, therefore, measured in currencies other than the Swiss franc and are then translated into
Swiss francs for presentation of our financial results, assets and liabilities in our Financial Statements.
Consequently, fluctuations in the applicable foreign currency exchange rates may increase or decrease the
Swiss franc value of our non-Swiss franc assets, liabilities, sales, costs and order intake, even if their value
has not changed in the local functional currency.

Exchange rate fluctuations have had a significant impact on our reported sales to third parties in the past.
For example, in the year ended December 31, 2020 our reported sales to third parties of CHF1,655 million
were significantly lower than our sales to third parties on a currency-adjusted basis of CHF1,750 million,
which was attributable in large part to a depreciation of the U.S. dollar relative to the Swiss franc.

We are also exposed to transactional risk to the extent our subsidiaries and we execute transactions in a
currency other than their functional currency, which arises mainly when we import components from one
jurisdiction, incurring a cost in that jurisdiction’s currency, and invoice for our products and installation in
the local currency.

The exchange rates between the functional currencies of our global subsidiaries and the Swiss franc have
fluctuated significantly in recent years and may continue to do so in the future. We apply a natural hedging
strategy, which aims to proportionally match revenues and costs for each currency we use. For certain
currencies, a natural hedging strategy is not commercially feasible. In such cases, we aim to hedge our
exposure. Through their impact on sales and costs, foreign exchange movements may impact our reported
profitability. For additional information on how currency fluctuations affect our results of operations, see
_‘‘—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management—Market Risk.’’_

**Factors Affecting Comparability of Our Financial Statements**

**_Changes to accounting standards—IFRS 16 (Leases)_**

On January 13, 2016, the IASB published IFRS 16 (Leases), which replaced IAS 17 and the related IFRIC
and SIC interpretations and resulted in almost all leases being recognized on the balance sheet, as the
distinction between operating and finance leases was eliminated. Under the new standard, the lessee
recognizes an asset (the right-to-use the leased asset) and a financial liability to pay lease payments. The
only exceptions are short-term and low-value leases should a company elect to apply an available practical
expedient in order to reduce the transition effort. IFRS 16 became effective for fiscal years commencing
on or after January 1, 2019.

The LSI Business adopted IFRS 16 (Leases) on January 1, 2019, by opting to apply the modified
retrospective method, which means that the cumulative transition effects of initial applications are
recognized in retained earnings as at January 1, 2019. The LSI Business elected to use the transition
practical expedient allowing the standard to be applied only to contracts that were previously identified as

101


-----

leases applying IAS 17 and IFRIC 4 as at the date of initial application. Accordingly, no adjusted
comparative information was disclosed.

The transition to IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019, gave rise to changes to our assets and liabilities. As a result,
figures as at and for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020 may not be comparable to the results
presented for prior periods. As at January 1, 2019, December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020, our
right-of-use assets (presented in property, plant and equipment) amounted to CHF18 million,
CHF15 million and CHF14 million, respectively, and lease liabilities (presented in other non-current
liabilities and other current liabilities) amounted to CHF18 million, CHF15 million and CHF14 million,
respectively. The depreciation of right-of-use assets for the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020,
amounted to CHF5 million and CHF4 million, respectively, and the interest expenses from lease liabilities
amounted to CHF1 million and CHF1 million, respectively. The adoption of IFRS 16 had a positive impact
on our Adjusted EBITDA, as the cost of operating leases that were previously expensed above Adjusted
EBITDA are now moved below Adjusted EBITDA and included in depreciation of right-of-use assets and
interest expense. See Note 1 ‘‘Accounting Principles and Basis of Preparation’’ to the 2020 Financial
Statements.

**_The Transactions_**

expenses. As a result of purchase accounting, the goodwill that is reflected on the balance sheet as of

**_Transformation Program_**

In connection with the Acquisition, the Sponsors commissioned a third-party due diligence report from a
global consulting firm to analyze the financial condition and operations of the LSI Business and its
potential for achieving cost savings. This report identified up to CHF99 million in potential ‘‘run rate’’ cost

102


-----

savings within five years of the Acquisition Closing Date, based on the cost base pursuant to LSI’s target
operating model, that may be achievable through the implementation of various transformation measures
over a period of five years (not including potential revenue upside from certain pricing initiatives identified
in the report). This cost savings potential is also supported by other due diligence and detailed cost
assessments undertaken by the Sponsors in connection with the Acquisition as well as by benchmarking
LSI’s profitability against that of its public peer companies. It is also comparable to profitability
improvements achieved in other corporate carve-outs in the chemicals sector under sponsor ownership. In
addition, we expect to achieve cost savings of CHF2 million from the outset in relation to IT costs included
in the target operating model, largely related to the non-hiring of initially planned employee hires.

Following the completion of the Acquisition, we intend to initiate a transformation program to implement
these transformation measures (the ‘‘Transformation Program’’) and expect to realize cost savings of
CHF69 million within 18 months after the Acquisition Closing Date and an additional CHF2 million from
IT cost savings described above, assuming, among other things, that the program will be implemented
beginning on the Acquisition Closing Date and driven by key management, although we believe that some
of these measures can be initiated even prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, because they are a
continuation of LSI’s existing and ongoing efficiency measures or involve not filling positions that were
initially contemplated by the target operating model for the LSI standalone business, or filling these
positions in lower cost locations than initially planned.

The Transformation Program focuses on cost savings opportunities related to: (i) manufacturing; (ii) raw
materials procurement; (iii) indirect spend control; (iv) sales and marketing costs; (v) G&A costs; and
(vi) R&D costs. We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to approximately CHF103 million between
2021 and 2023 in connection with these initiatives, comprising: (i) approximately CHF58 million in
expected one-off costs, including severance costs, IT costs and program delivery costs, including consulting,
financial and legal advisory fees in connection with implementing our Transformation Program; and
(ii) approximately CHF45 million in expected capital expenditures related to manufacturing savings. Our
estimates of cost savings opportunities are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the
information available to us and our management’s judgments based on such information, and reflect our
assumptions about the cost base of our target operating model. The assumptions used in estimating costs
savings are inherently uncertain and are subject to a wide variety of significant business, economic, and
competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained
in these estimates. We may not be able to realize these cost savings, either in the amount or within the
timeframe we currently anticipate, and the costs of achieving these cost savings may be higher than
expected. See ‘‘Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We may fail to achieve the
_targeted benefits from restructuring and operational improvement measures.’’_

As part of manufacturing cost savings initiatives, we intend to streamline our manufacturing operations,
including implementing personnel optimization and organizational efficiency measures. These include
further automation and digitalization at our manufacturing sites, setting more ambitious productivity
targets and increasing productivity through higher utilization and workforce rationalization. We also intend
to implement efficiency measures, such as increases in the proportion of direct workforce, such as
operators, at our manufacturing sites compared to our indirect workforce, such as supervisors, engineers
and maintenance workers.

As part of raw materials cost savings initiatives, we intend to optimize our raw materials procurement. This
includes optimizing the balance of raw materials sourced directly versus through distributors, reviewing
supplier relationships and implementing sourcing efficiencies. In terms of basic chemicals (such as caustic
soda and ammonia), we intend to rebalance direct and distribution purchases to optimize pricing and
terms and conditions, including more favorable pricing for regionally sourced commodities. For specialty
chemicals (such as amines and glycerin), which are sourced from a small number of large suppliers, we
expect to focus on establishing long-term agreements, price indexing, bundling with non-oligopoly products
and volume incentives. For critical sole-sourced raw materials (such as pyridine), we expect to work
proactively with suppliers to establish flexible strategies. We also expect to generate cost savings by
optimizing procurement of certain specialty products and external production spend on finished goods for
resale and tollers.

As part of indirect spend cost savings initiatives, we intend to generate cost savings in logistics, repair,
maintenance, travel and telecommunication services. We expect to focus on centralizing management of
these costs, which are currently addressed at local level, to generate procurement synergies.

103


-----

As part of sales and marketing cost savings initiatives, we intend to reduce the existing complexity of the
sales and marketing function, such as substantial role duplication, generating expected cost savings from
personnel-related initiatives. The remaining cost savings are expected to be generated by non-personnel
related initiatives, such as cost supervision.

As part of G&A cost savings initiatives, we intend to implement a number of initiatives targeting our
general and administrative costs, primarily a leaner operating model that is more consistent with what we
understand to be the operating model of our peers. These initiatives include organizational simplification,
optimizations through attrition savings and non-hiring of new employees initially contemplated by our
target operating model, as well as organizational efficiency through increased automation, and retaining
higher-performing employees. We also intend to reduce the number of shared service centers we operate
from ten to three (with one in each of EIMEA, APAC and Americas), as well as to shift employees to
lower cost countries.

As part of R&D cost savings initiatives, we intend to implement various initiatives related to streamlining
our research and development operations.

As part of our Transformation Program, we also intend to implement various working capital optimization
initiatives. These include increased focus on quarter- and year-end collections, enhanced collections and
billing strategies, product line rationalizations, selling slow-moving or obsolete stock at a discount,
improving the accuracy of sales forecasting, and other related improvement initiatives focused on
optimizing our net working capital balance and smoothing working capital requirements. A third-party due
diligence report commissioned by the Sponsors in connection with the Acquisition has identified working
capital optimization potential that could lead to estimated higher balances of cash and cash equivalents of
up to CHF136 million within an 18 to 24-month period.

See also ‘‘Summary Financial and Other Information—Other Financial, Operating and Pro Forma
_Information—Pro forma Financial Metrics’’ and ‘‘—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Working Capital.’’_

**Key Line Items in Our Income Statement**

Set forth below is a description of the key line items presented in our Financial Statements and discussed
in this ‘‘Management Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations’’ section.

**_Sales to third parties_**

Sales to third parties include revenue generated from contracts with third-party customers. Revenue from
sales of products to such third-party customers is recognized when they obtain control of the underlying
goods and thus have the ability to direct the use and obtain the benefits from such goods. Revenue from
sales of services is recognized in the accounting periods in which the underlying services are rendered.

**_Sales to related parties_**

Sales to related parties include revenue generated from contracts with Lonza Group. In the years under
review, these included other parts of Lonza Group’s business, including LPBN and, for the year ended
December 31, 2018, the Water Care business, which was disposed of by Lonza Group on February 28, 2019.
We apply the same approach to revenue recognition for our sales to related parties, as described in
‘‘—Sales to third parties’’ above.

**_Total sales_**

Total sales include sales to third parties and sales to related parties.

**_Cost of goods sold_**

Cost of goods sold includes the production and purchase costs incurred to generate our total sales. In
addition to direct cost of inventories, which represent the majority of our cost of goods sold, it also includes
ineffective portions of cash flow hedges and changes in fair value hedges. Expenses for doubtful trade
receivables and a portion of expenses related to short-term leases and low value assets are also recognized
within the cost of goods sold.

**_Gross profit_**

Gross profit is total sales less cost of goods sold.

104


-----

**_Marketing and distribution_**

Marketing and distribution expenses primarily relate to costs incurred in respect of marketing, advertising,
promotional expenditure and subscriptions to associated trade bodies.

**_Research and development_**

Research and development expenses include expenses in connection with research and development
activities not eligible for capitalization and other costs related to the functional area of research and
development. We typically capitalize only a minor portion of our R&D expenses.

**_Administration and general overheads_**

Administration and general overheads expenses include corporate administration costs, such as indirect
wages and salaries with our employees, as well as indirect overheads, including insurances costs, legal and
professional fees and office supplies. Amortization of intangibles and a portion of expenses related to
short-term leases and low value assets are also included in administration and general overheads. Finally,
administration and general overheads include corporate administration costs, royalty fees and
environmental remediation costs allocated to us while we are operating as part of Lonza Group, including
costs allocated to us in respect of the Lonza Group LTIP, which is settled with Lonza shares and does not
involve cash payments.

**_Other operating income_**

Other operating income include items not assignable to other functions of the income statement. Other
operating income mainly include gains from the disposal of intangible assets, property, plant and
equipment and other non-current assets, income from the release and recognition of provisions, income
related to restructuring, gains from currency-related operating derivative instruments, as well as operating
exchange rate gains.

**_Other operating expenses_**

Other operating expenses include items not assignable to other functions of the income statement. Other
operating expenses mainly include losses from the disposal of intangible assets, property, plant and
equipment and other non-current assets, expenses from the release and recognition of provisions, expenses
related to restructuring, losses from currency-related operating derivative instruments, as well as operating
exchange rate losses.

**_Result from operating activities_**

Result from operating activities comprises total sales, less cost of goods sold, marketing and distribution
costs, research and development costs and administration and general overhead costs, plus other operating
income less other operating expenses.

**_Financial income_**

Financial income consists of interest income from financial receivables, income from valuation of interest
derivatives, other interest and similar income. It includes loan interest, foreign exchange rate effects from
loans and interest on bank accounts.

**_Financial expenses_**

Financial expenses consist of net interest on the net defined benefit liability, interest expenses on financial
debt, interest costs included in lease payments and other interest and similar expenses. Interest expenses
primarily comprise interest on external debt, interest on related party loans with Lonza Group, interest on
employee benefit liabilities and interest on our factoring program, as well as on an accounts receivable
securitization program that was discontinued in 2020.

**_Share of (loss)/profit of associates_**

Share of (loss)/profit of associates represents the share of net results of associated undertakings.

105


-----

**_Profit before income taxes_**

Profit before income taxes is the net sum of result from operating activities, net financial result and share
of (loss)/profit of associates.

**_Income taxes_**

Income taxes for the year comprises current and deferred tax. Current tax is calculated on the basis of the
tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the balance sheet date in the countries in which we operate
and generate taxable income. Deferred income tax is recognized, using the liability method, on temporary
differences arising between the tax basis of assets and liabilities and their carrying amounts in our Financial
Statements. Deferred income tax is determined using tax rates (and laws) that have been enacted or
substantially enacted by the balance sheet date and are expected to apply when the related deferred
income tax asset is realized or the deferred income tax liability is settled. As we operate globally, we are
subject to income taxes in several different tax jurisdictions. From January 1, 2020, we have applied, as the
carve-out tax rate, the ordinary tax rate of 13% applicable in the Canton of Basel in Switzerland, the
location of Lonza Group’s headquarters. Before 2020, and prior to a tax reform implemented in
Switzerland, we applied the ordinary tax rate of our operating entity in the Canton of Valois in Switzerland
of 21.6% as the carve-out tax rate. Our effective tax rate was 20.9% in the year ended December 31, 2018,
26.1% in the year ended December 31, 2019 and 25.8% in the year ended December 31, 2020.

**_Profit for the period_**

Profit for the period is the sum of profit before income taxes and income taxes.

_Microbial Control Solutions_

Sales to third parties of our Microbial Control Solutions business unit increased by CHF38 million, or
3.7%, to CHF1,068 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF1,030 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 11.1% to
CHF1,144 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Hygiene_

Sales to third parties in the Hygiene market field increased by CHF95 million, or 55.9%, to
CHF265 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF170 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to a structural shift in the market related to significantly increased
demand driven by Covid-19. The sales growth was partially offset by the appreciation of the Swiss franc
compared to the U.S. dollar and other currencies. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties
increased by 65.9% to CHF282 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Home and Personal Care_

Sales to third parties in the Home and Personal Care market field increased by CHF4 million, or 1.7%, to
CHF238 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF234 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to strong demand in laundry/HC Preservation and new business in
laundry. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 9.4% to CHF256 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020.

107


-----

_Wood Protection_

Sales to third parties in the Wood Protection market field decreased by CHF3 million, or 0.9%, to
CHF313 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF316 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to the impact of foreign currency exchange rate movements. On a
currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 5.7% to CHF334 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020. Lower demand during COVID-19 lockdown in the first half of 2020 was offset by
higher sales to third parties in the second half of 2020, particularly in do-it-yourself markets in Americas
and EIMEA. Additionally, supply issues at one of our competitors in the second half of 2020 allowed us to
win additional business at the end of 2020.

_Paints and Coatings_

Sales to third parties in the Paints and Coatings market field decreased by CHF17 million, or 12.5%, to
CHF119 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF136 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to lower demand for a number of products as a result of Covid-19 (such
as a decrease in demand for marine antifouling paints in the shipping industry) and regulatory pressure
restricting the use of zinc pyrithione in Canada. On a currency-adjusted basis, the decrease in sales to third
parties was less pronounced, amounting to 5.9%, with sales to third parties of CHF128 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020.

_Material Protection_

Sales to third parties in the Material Protection market field decreased by CHF32 million, or 24.4%, to
CHF99 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF131 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to softer demand from the oil and gas industry as well as the automotive
sector. Softer demand in the oil and gas industry was mainly caused by the collapse of crude oil prices at
the end of the first quarter of 2020, whereas softer demand from the automotive sector was primarily due
to a slow-down in the sector caused by COVID-19. On a currency-adjusted basis, the decrease in sales to
third parties was less pronounced, amounting to 19.1%, with sales to third parties of CHF106 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Crop Protection_

Sales to third parties in the Crop Protection market field decreased by CHF8 million, or 18.6%, to
CHF35 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF43 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to lower demand in Agro Specialties due to unfavorable weather
conditions, regulatory challenges and reduced availability of quats (antimicrobial actives), as quats
production capacity was mainly allocated to Hygiene products. On a currency-adjusted basis, the decrease
in sales to third parties was less pronounced, amounting to 11.6%, with sales to third parties of
CHF38 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_Specialty Chemical Services_

Sales to third parties of our Specialty Chemical Services business unit decreased by CHF74 million, or
11.2%, to CHF587 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF661 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 8.3% to
CHF606 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_PIC_

Sales to third parties in the PIC market field decreased by CHF26 million, or 6.1%, to CHF403 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF429 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily
due to lower raw material prices for the key raw material PMDA, which were passed on to customers
under price formula—based contracts, the regular maintenance shutdown of the cracker in Visp, which
occurs every 2.5 years, and the exit from the Cyanuric Chloride business at the end of 2019. This was partly
offset by a positive trend in Vitamin B3 in 2020 due to higher price level driven by higher raw material
price of beta-picoline. On a currency-adjusted basis, the decrease in sales to third parties was less
pronounced, amounting to 2.8%, with sales to third parties of CHF417 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020.

108


-----

_Composite Materials_

Sales to third parties in the Composite Materials market field decreased by CHF18 million, or 20.2%, to
CHF71 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF89 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to softer demand from the aerospace and electronics market caused by
COVID-19, partly offset by stronger demand from the industrial market. On a currency-adjusted basis, the
decrease in sales to third parties was less pronounced, amounting to 16.9%, with sales to third parties of
CHF74 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

_CDMO_

Sales to third parties in the CDMO market field decreased by CHF24 million, or 16.8%, to
CHF119 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF143 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019, primarily due to the loss of a large CDMO project in 2019 to a competitor from a
lower-cost country and ongoing rejuvenation of project pipeline with a number of projects phasing out or
ending and new projects only ramping up, which we expect to continue during 2021. Additionally, we
experienced delays in some CDMO campaigns which led to sales shifts into 2021. Foreign exchange rates
had little effect on sales to third parties in the CDMO market field, mainly because a large share of the
sales was denominated in Swiss francs. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by
16.1% to CHF120 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

**_Sales to related parties_**

Our sales to related parties increased by CHF5 million, or 8.9%, to CHF61 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF56 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to higher
demand from Lonza Group for a number of products.

**_Total sales_**

Our total sales decreased by CHF31 million, or 1.8%, to CHF1,716 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF1,747 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the reasons
discussed above.

**_Cost of Goods sold_**

Our cost of goods sold decreased by CHF39 million, or 3.2%, to CHF1,213 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF1,252 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to the
decrease in sales, as well as cost management measures and favorable prices of certain raw materials.

**_Gross profit_**

Our gross profit increased by CHF8 million, or 1.6%, to CHF503 million for the year ended December 31,
2020 from CHF495 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the reasons discussed above.

**_Marketing and distribution_**

Our marketing and distribution expenses decreased by CHF6 million, or 5.3%, to CHF107 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF113 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due
to cost savings measures, lower activity due to the Covid-19 pandemic and favorable foreign exchange rate
impact.

**_Research and development_**

Our research and development expenses decreased by CHF13 million, or 27.1%, to CHF35 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF48 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due
to a hiring delay due to the Covid-19 pandemic, as well as the full-year impact of restructuring measures
undertaken in 2019 and reduced costs for external experiments and expertise.

**_Administration and general overheads_**

Our administration and general overheads decreased by CHF23 million, or 12.2%, to CHF165 million for
the year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF188 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily
due to lower allocations from Lonza Group corporate administration costs, royalty fees and environmental
