remediation costs. These allocations amounted to CHF42 million and CHF18 million for the years ended
December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively.

**_Other operating income_**

Our other operating income increased by CHF3 million, or 16.7%, to CHF21 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF18 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to gains
from exchange rate fluctuations, disposal of property, plant and equipment and sundry income.

**_Other operating expenses_**

Our other operating expenses decreased by CHF1 million, or 3.7%, to CHF26 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF27 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to losses
from exchange rate fluctuations, restructuring expenses, impairment of assets and sundry expenses.

**_Result from operating activities_**

Our result from operating activities increased by CHF54 million, or 39.4%, to CHF191 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020 from CHF137 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the reasons
discussed above.

**_Financial income_**

Our financial income increased by CHF6 million, or 120%, to CHF11 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to increased
income from related party loans with Lonza Group.

**_Financial expenses_**

Our financial expenses increased by CHF24 million, or 57.1%, to CHF66 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF42 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to increased
interest on related party loans with Lonza Group.

**_Net financial result_**

Our net financial result increased by CHF18 million, or 48.6%, to CHF55 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF37 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the reasons discussed
above.

**_Share of (loss)/profit of associates_**

Our share of (loss)/profit of associates increased by CHF3 million, or 300%, to CHF4 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020 from a loss of CHF1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily
due to three equity investments into early stage companies.

**_Profit before income taxes_**

Our profit before income taxes increased by CHF33 million, or 33.3%, to CHF132 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020 from CHF99 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the reasons
discussed above.

**_Income taxes_**

Our income taxes increased by CHF8 million, or 30.8%, to CHF34 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF26 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to an
increase in current taxes by CHF17 million, which was partially offset by deferred tax income of
CHF6 million resulting from tax rate changes. Our effective tax rate for the year ended December 31, 2020
was 25.8%, compared to 26.1% for the year ended December 31, 2019.

**_Profit for the period_**

Our profit for the period increased by CHF25 million, or 34.2%, to CHF98 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF73 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, for the reasons discussed
above.

**_Sales to third parties_**

Our sales to third parties decreased by CHF57 million, or 3.3%, to CHF1,691 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF1,748 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. Sales to third parties
were adversely affected by foreign currency exchange movements. On a currency-adjusted basis, our sales
to third parties were CHF1,705 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, representing a
CHF43 million, or 2.5%, decrease from our sales to third parties for the year ended December 31, 2018.
The development of Sales to third parties in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit was driven by
an increasingly competitive environment in wood protection products offered by the business unit’s Wood
Protection market field and weaker demand in the business unit’s Home and Personal Care market field,
offset by strong growth in sales of products offered by the business unit’s Hygiene market field. Sales to
third parties in Specialty Chemical Services was driven by CDMO sales decline, competitive pressures due
to the ongoing consolidation in the agrochemicals industry and a more rigid regulatory environment
resulting in less actives and increasing cost focus, which was partially offset by increased sales of
fermentation products and due to decreases in global prices of vitamin B3 due to African swine fever and
reduced composite volumes in electronics due to competitive pressure.

_Microbial Control Solutions_

Sales to third parties of our Microbial Control Solutions business unit decreased by CHF4 million, or
0.4%, to CHF1,030 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF1,034 million for the year
ended December 31, 2018. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 0.4% to
CHF1,038 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_Hygiene_

Sales to third parties in the Hygiene market field increased by CHF9 million, or 5.6%, to CHF170 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF161 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to a combination of favorable regulatory changes introduced in North America that enabled
us to gain new customers, a high level of negotiation power with regards to certain registered products and
an increase in customer demand. LSI typically benefits from the regulatory environment in North America,
where we offer the customers regulatory support and sale of products through sub-registration contracts.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 6.2%, to CHF171 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Home and Personal Care_

Sales to third parties in the Home and Personal Care market field decreased by CHF11 million, or 4.5%, to
CHF234 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF245 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, primarily due to supply chain disruptions, caused by a factory fire at a supplier in the
U.S. and increased price competition in the food business, as well as changes in customer sentiment
affecting two key customers.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 3.7%, to CHF236 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Wood Protection_

Sales to third parties in the Wood Protection market field decreased by CHF4 million, or 1.3%, to
CHF316 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF320 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, primarily due to an increasingly competitive environment in the Americas region due

112


-----

to market consolidation, as a result of which we initially lost some market share and were able to regain
customers only by reducing prices.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 0.6%, to CHF318 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Paints and Coatings_

Sales to third parties in the Paints and Coatings market field increased by CHF10 million, or 7.9%, to
CHF136 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF126 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, primarily due to a supply chain disruption resulting from an explosion at Xiangshui
Chemical Park in China, which resulted in the shutdown of several suppliers, caused a supply shortage in
the market and allowed us to increase prices and generate higher sales to third parties, despite lower sales
volumes, in certain products.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 9.5%, to CHF138 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Material Protection_

Sales to third parties in the Material Protection market field increased by CHF2 million, or 1.6%, to
CHF131 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF129 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, primarily due to favorable market conditions of customers in the oil and gas business
in the Americas, partly offset by a negative impact of the US-China trade conflict.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 1.6%, to CHF131 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Crop Protection_

Sales to third parties in the Crop Protection market field decreased by CHF13 million, or 23.2%, to
CHF43 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF56 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, primarily due to regulatory restrictions (product bans) in the EU and increased
competition from China.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 21.4%, to CHF44 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Specialty Chemical Services_

Sales to third parties of our Specialty Chemical Services business unit decreased by CHF53 million, or
7.4%, to CHF661 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF714 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018. On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 6.9% to
CHF665 million for the year ended December 31, 2019.

_PIC_

Sales to third parties in the PIC market field decreased by CHF56 million, or 11.5%, to CHF429 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF485 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to lower raw material prices, which were passed on to customers as a result of formula—
based pricing under customer agreements and discontinuation of the fertilizer business.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 10.9%, to CHF432 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_Composite Materials_

Sales to third parties in the Composite Materials market field decreased by CHF5 million, or 5.3%, to
CHF89 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF94 million for the year ended
December 31, 2018, primarily due to price decreases for two main product categories. We experienced a
high level of demand for diethyl toluenediamine in 2018 as one of our competitors experienced issues with
supplying its customers. In 2019, the competitor resolved the supply issues and tried gain back market
share by reducing prices. We also lowered prices in order not to lose volumes. Additionally, we also
experienced a decline in demand for Primaset from industrial sectors.

113


-----

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties decreased by 5.3%, to CHF89 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

_CDMO_

Sales to third parties in the CDMO market field increased by CHF5 million, or 3.6%, to CHF143 million
for the year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF138 million for the year ended December 31, 2018,
primarily due to growth in the Fermentation business with two key customers.

On a currency-adjusted basis, sales to third parties increased by 4.3%, to CHF144 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019.

**_Sales to related parties_**

Our sales to related parties decreased by CHF21 million, or 27.3%, to CHF56 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF77 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to due to
lower demand from Lonza Group for certain raw material and intermediates manufactured by LSI.

**_Total sales_**

Our total sales decreased by CHF78 million, or 4.3%, to CHF1,747 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF1,825 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons
discussed above.

**_Cost of Goods sold_**

Our cost of goods sold decreased by CHF51 million, or 3.9%, to CHF1,252 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF1,303 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the
decrease in overall sales described above, while gross profit margin remained relatively stable.

**_Gross profit_**

Our gross profit decreased by CHF27 million, or 5.2%, to CHF495 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF522 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons discussed
above.

**_Marketing and distribution_**

Our marketing and distribution expenses decreased by CHF12 million, or 9.6%, to CHF113 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF125 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due
to a decrease in expenses for our STIP as a result of the business performance and implementation of
organizational efficiency measures at the end of the first half of 2019.

**_Research and development_**

Our research and development expenses decreased by CHF2 million, or 4.0%, to CHF48 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF50 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due
to restructuring measures put in place during 2019.

**_Administration and general overheads_**

Our administration and general overheads decreased by CHF4 million, or 2.1%, to CHF188 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF192 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due
to lower costs allocated from the Lonza Group, royalty fees, environmental remediation costs and lower
short-term incentive payments for LSI employees due to underperformance of the LSI Business compared
to our 2019 financial targets.

**_Other operating income_**

Our other operating income decreased by CHF1 million, or 5.3%, to CHF18 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF19 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a
decrease in gain from foreign exchange rate differences, partially offset by an increase in sundry income
related to year-end accruals.

114


-----

**_Other operating expenses_**

Our other operating expenses decreased by CHF6 million, or 18.2%, to CHF27 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF33 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to a
decrease in loss from foreign exchange rate differences of CHF12 million, partially offset by an increase in
sundry expenses of CHF13 million related to impairment charges and year-end cut-off accruals.

**_Result from operating activities_**

Our result from operating activities decreased by CHF4 million, or 2.8%, to CHF137 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 from CHF141 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons
discussed above.

**_Financial income_**

Our financial income increased by CHF1 million, or 25.0%, to CHF5 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to higher
interest income from related party loans and advances to Lonza Group.

**_Financial expenses_**

Our financial expenses decreased by CHF5 million, or 10.6%, to CHF42 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF47 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to lower
interest expense on related party loans from Lonza Group.

**_Net financial result_**

Our net financial result increased by CHF6 million, or 14.0%, to a loss of CHF37 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 from a loss of CHF43 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the
reasons discussed above.

**_Share of (loss)/profit of associates_**

Our share of (loss)/profit of associates decreased by CHF2 million to a loss of CHF1 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 from a profit of CHF1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

**_Profit before income taxes_**

Our profit before income taxes remained unchanged at CHF99 million for the year ended December 31,
2019 from CHF99 million in the year ended December 31, 2018.

**_Income taxes_**

Our income taxes increased by CHF6 million, or 30.0%, to CHF26 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF20 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to an
increase in current taxes by CHF4 million, partially offset by a deferred tax income deduction resulting
from tax rate changes of CHF3 million that was not applicable in the year ended December 31, 2018. Our
effective tax rate for the year ended December 31, 2019 was 26.1%, compared to 20.9% for the year ended
December 31, 2018, due primarily to changes in the profitability of different legal entities, as well as higher
non-deductible expenses and lower tax-free earnings.

**_Profit for the period_**

Our profit for the period decreased by CHF6 million, or 7.6%, to CHF73 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF79 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, for the reasons discussed
above.

**Liquidity and Capital resources**

**_Overview_**

Following the completion of the Transactions, we expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be cash
flows from operations and drawings under our Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of our Revolving
Credit Facility will be subject to certain conditions.

115


-----

We aim to manage capital to ensure that we can continue to operate as a going concern. Our ability to
generate cash flow from operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn
dependent on general economic, financial, competitive, market and other factors, many of which are
beyond our control. In addition, we anticipate that we will be highly leveraged in the foreseeable future
and our ability to generate future financing cash flows will be limited by the Indentures and the Senior
Facilities, which may have important negative consequences for you. See ‘‘Risk Factors,’’ ‘‘Description of the
_Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness,’’ ‘‘Description of the Senior Notes—_
_Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness’’ and ‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.’’ Any_
additional indebtedness that we do incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available to make
payments on our then existing indebtedness, including the Notes offered hereby, and increase our leverage.

The proceeds from the Offering will be used as set forth under ‘‘Use of Proceeds.’’

_Net cash provided by operating activities_

Net cash provided by operating activities increased by CHF13 million, or 9.3%, to CHF153 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF140 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due
to higher cash generation from operations driven by our resilience and diversification in end markets and
geographies. Our increase in net cash provided by operating activities was also due to higher trade net
working capital requirements in 2020 driven primarily by higher trade payables, and favorable
developments in other net working capital as a result of higher short-term personnel liabilities for our
STIP and an increase in deferred income, which were partially offset by higher interest payments on
related party loans with Lonza Group.

Net cash provided by operating activities increased by CHF49 million, or 53.8%, to CHF140 million for the
year ended December 31, 2019 from CHF91 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due
to adverse movements in other net working capital and movements in other payables, driven by an increase
in other operating receivables and derivatives linked to higher VAT receivables, lower short-term incentive
accruals for our STIP due to underperformance compared to our targets, a reduction in deferred income
and a decrease in other accruals driven by unbilled payables, as well as lower income taxes and lower
interest paid on related party loans with Lonza Group.

_Net cash used for investing activities_

Net cash used for investing activities decreased by CHF4 million, or 4.6%, to CHF83 million for the year
ended December 31, 2020 from CHF87 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to
decreased capital expenditure driven by our efforts to limit expenditure and manage our liquidity during
the Covid-19 pandemic.

Net cash used for investing activities increased by CHF15 million, or 20.8%, to CHF87 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 from CHF72 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to the
purchase of unconsolidated investments in early stage companies.

116

_Net cash used for financing activities_

Net cash used for financing activities increased by CHF137 million, or 2,740%, to CHF142 million for the
year ended December 31, 2020 from CHF5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to
net movements in our intercompany loan positions with Lonza Group.

Net cash used for financing activities decreased by CHF54 million, or 91.5%, to CHF5 million for the year
ended December 31, 2019 from CHF59 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due
repayments of third-party debt and related party loans to Lonza Group in 2018 that did not reoccur in
2019, apart from the refinancing of third-party debt with related party loans with Lonza Group in 2019.

**_Capital Expenditures_**

Our capital expenditures amounted to CHF98 million, CHF93 million and CHF88 million in the years
ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively, and primarily relate to projects that assure current
production levels, efficiency, cost improvements and health and safety and also increase capacity and sales.
A significant position of our capital expenditure each year relates to our Visp site (CHF36 million,
CHF46 million and CHF52 million in the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively)
and included expansion of cyanates, piroctone olamine (POX) plant adaptation, HMBDA and PHMB
production transfers to Visp, N2O abatement and a new fermentation pilot line in Kouˇrim.

Our capital expenditures decreased by CHF5 million, or 5.4%, to CHF88 million for the year ended
December 31, 2020 from CHF93 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, primarily due to lower
capital expenditures during the Covid-19 pandemic, as we managed our liquidity and cash position due to
the uncertainty and limited visibility during the early months of the pandemic.

Our capital expenditures decreased by CHF5 million, or 5.1%, to CHF93 million for the year ended
December 31, 2019 from CHF98 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to lower
capital expenditures at our Mapleton site after large capital expenditure projects were completed in the
year ended December 31, 2018.

Our capital expenditures as a percentage of sales to third parties were 5.6%, 5.5%, and 5.3% in the years
ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively.

increase our growth capital expenditures significantly over the next few years, primarily to invest in our
Hygiene market field. After the expected initial increase in capital expenditure, over the medium-term we
expect our total capital expenditures to return to normal levels of approximately CHF100 million per year.

initiatives. These include increased focus on quarter- and year-end collections, enhanced collections and
billing strategies, product line rationalizations, selling slow-moving or obsolete stock at a discount,
improving the accuracy of sales forecasting, and other related improvement initiatives focused on
optimizing our net working capital balance and smoothing working capital requirements. A third-party due
diligence report commissioned by the Sponsors in connection with the Acquisition has identified working
capital optimization potential that could lead to estimated higher balances of cash and cash equivalents of
up to CHF136 million within an 18 to 24-month period.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management**

We are exposed to financial risks, in particular in the form of credit and liquidity risk as well as to market
risks from movements in foreign currency exchange rates and market prices that affect its assets, liabilities,
and forecasted transactions. These risks have historically been managed at the Lonza Group level and our
overall risk management policy aims to limit these risks through operational and finance activities.

119


-----

The analyses and amounts discussed below that are determined by means of sensitivity analyses represent
hypothetical, future-oriented data that can differ from actual outcomes because of unforeseeable
developments in financial markets. Moreover, non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business
risks, are not considered here. Credit risk, liquidity risk and market risk are described below and in more
detail in Note 22 of our 2020 Financial Statements.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk (default risk) is the risk of financial loss if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument
fails to meet its contractual obligations, and mainly arises from our receivables from customers.

Our exposure to credit risk is influenced mainly by the individual characteristics of each of our customers.
We assess the credit quality of our customers, taking into account their financial position, past experience
and other factors. In monitoring customer credit risk, customers are grouped according to their credit
characteristics, including geographic location, industry, and existence of previous financial difficulties.

Purchase limits are established for each customer, which are reviewed regularly. For customers domiciled
in specific countries with high risk, we have credit risk insurance covering the maximum exposure. The
maximum credit risk is equal to the carrying amount of the respective assets. There are no commitments
that could increase this exposure to more than the carrying amounts. In general, we do not require
collateral in respect of trade and other receivables but use credit insurance for country risk where
appropriate.

We have a history of low credit losses on accounts receivable. Credit losses that occurred in the past were
primarily related to very few customers. Furthermore, none of our operations had a heightened exposure
to credit losses in the past and based on our best estimate, this is not expected to change in the foreseeable
future.

Consequently, the allowance for credit losses represents primarily the credit risk of specific customers.

For more information on our credit risk, see Note 22.2 to our 2020 Financial Statements.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet our financial obligations as they fall due. Our
approach to managing liquidity is to ensure that we will always have sufficient liquidity to meet our
liabilities when due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or
risking damage to our reputation. We maintain flexibility in funding also using bilateral and syndicated
credit lines.

To counter this risk, cash inflows and outflows and due dates are continuously monitored and managed.
Cash requirements are primarily met by cash generated from operations and bilateral and syndicated
credit lines. As December 31, 2020, we had cash and cash equivalents of CHF124 million, and we had cash
and cash equivalents of CHF159 million and CHF205 million as at December 31, 2018 and 2019,
respectively. As a result, there were no material concentrations of liquidity risk in the years under review.

We intend to continue to mitigate our liquidity risks by rolling liquidity planning and maintaining adequate
liquidity reserves in the form of cash. For more information on our liquidity risk, including future
undiscounted cash outflows, see Note 22.3 to our 2020 Financial Statements.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices will affect our income or the value of our holdings of
financial instruments. We are exposed to market risk from changes in currency exchange and interest rates
and commodities. The objective of market risk management is to manage and control market risk
exposures within acceptable parameters, while optimizing the return on risk.

_Foreign Exchange Risk_

We operate across the world and are exposed to movements in foreign currencies affecting our financial
result and the value of our equity. Foreign exchange risk arises because the amount of local currency paid
or received for transactions denominated in foreign currencies may vary due to changes in exchange rates
(‘‘transaction exposures’’) and because the foreign currency denominated financial statements of our
foreign subsidiaries may vary upon combination into the Swiss franc-denominated carve-out financial

120


-----

statements (‘‘translation exposures’’). In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, 57%, 61%
and 65%, respectively, of our total sales to third parties were generated by operating subsidiaries with a
functional currency other than the Swiss franc. Foreign exchange risks arise primarily on transactions that
are denominated in USD and EUR.

In managing our exposure regarding the fluctuation in foreign currency exchange rates, Lonza Group has
entered into a variety of currency swaps and forward contracts on our behalf. These agreements generally
include the exchange of one currency against another currency at a future date. We adopt a policy of
considering hedging for all committed contractual exposure and the planned exposure is hedged within
certain ranges. Hedge ratios are determined by the risk committee and depend on market expectation, risk
bearing ability and risk appetite.

For more information on our foreign currency risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 22.4
to our 2020 Financial Statements.

_Interest Rate Risk_

Historically, our principal interest-bearing liabilities were comprised of the loans payable to the Lonza
Group and financial debt in the form of bank borrowings and lease liabilities. As most of these borrowings
bear variable interest rates that are based on inter-bank indices, we are exposed to interest rate risk.
Interest rate instruments can result in cash flow risks, opportunity effects, as well as interest rate risks
affecting the statement of financial position and earnings. Refinancing and variable-rate financial
instruments are subject to cash flow risk which expresses the uncertainty of future interest payments.

Borrowings under the Senior Term Facilities will be variable rate debt. We may consider entering into
certain derivative agreements, for hedging all or a portion of our exposure to fluctuations in the interest
rate of these liabilities. We have not yet completed our analysis and procedures to determine the
accounting treatment of such potential derivative agreements.

For more information on our interest rate risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 22.4 to
our 2020 Financial Statements.

_Commodity Price Risk_

We require LPG and LVN as raw materials for our cracker in Visp. Butane, naphtha or propane can be
used as feedstock for the cracker. The raw material ultimately used depends on its availability and
specifications. The annual demand is approximately 100,000 metric tons. In order to minimize the risk of
higher raw material prices, we hedge part of the commodity price risk via swaps.

For more information on our commodity price risk exposure, including a sensitivity analysis, see Note 22.4
to our 2020 Financial Statements.

**Critical Accounting Policies**

The financial information presented in our Financial Statements does not necessarily reflect the net assets,
financial position, results of operations and capital structure that would have occurred if we had existed as
a separate, standalone group in the reporting periods under consideration. The fact that we did not
historically exist therefore limits the validity of such financial information. It also means that the Financial
Statements cannot be used to forecast the future development of our operations that have been carved-out
in our formation.

In preparing the Financial Statements, our management made additional assumptions and estimates,
particularly in connection with operating activities to be transferred and allocable expenses for
administrative services provided by remaining Lonza Group companies. These assumptions and estimates
affect the amounts and the reporting of recognized assets and liabilities, income and expenses and
contingent liabilities. The actual amounts may vary from these estimates.

The significant accounting policies are included in Note 1 to the 2020 Financial Statements (including
(i) scope and principles of combination, (ii) investments, (iii) intercompany transactions and transactions
with related parties, (iv) revenue recognition, (v) other operating income and other operating expenses,
(vi) net financial result, (vii) foreign currencies, (viii) hedge accounting, (ix) property, plant and
equipment, (x) leases, (xi) intangible assets, (xii) goodwill, (xiii) inventories, (xiv) receivables, (xv) financial
instruments, (xvi) cash and cash equivalents, (xvii) impairment, (xviii) deferred taxes, (xix) employee
benefits, (xx) defined benefit plans, (xxi) provisions, and (xxii) share based compensation).

**_Revenue Recognition_**

We have recognized revenues for sales of goods to customers who have the right to rescind the sale if the
goods do not meet the agreed quality. We believe that, based on past experience with similar transactions,
the quality delivered will be accepted. Therefore, it is appropriate to recognize revenue on these
transactions during the respective period. Revenues are recognized only when, according to management’s
judgment, performance obligations are satisfied, control over the assets have been transferred to the
customer and no future performance obligation exists. For certain transactions, recognition of revenues is
based on the performance of the conditions agreed in particular contracts, the verification of which
requires evaluation and judgments by management.

**_Intangible Assets_**

We consider the trademarks acquired in 2011 through the Arch Chemicals business combination to have
an indefinite useful life, as they are well established in our respective markets and have a history of strong
performance. We intend and have the ability to maintain these trademarks for the foreseeable future. The
assumption of an indefinite useful life is reassessed whenever there is an indication that a trademark may
have a definite useful life. In addition, intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for
impairment on an annual basis.

We are a leading global provider of microbial control solutions across various consumer and industrial
markets. We also offer specialty chemical products and services covering composites and specialty
chemicals. Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit is a market-leading trusted and innovative
supplier of microbial control solutions and chemical technologies used in a wide range of industrial and
consumer products to control harmful organisms, including viruses and bacteria. Its product development
and application support is focused on six attractive addressable markets with significant growth potential,
including hygiene, home and personal care, wood protection, paints and coatings, material protection and
crop protection. Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit offers solutions for composite materials
and resin components and resin systems processing additives used in technically demanding industries,
such as electronics and transportation. It also comprises custom development and manufacturing and
provides key performance intermediates and chemicals for many industrial applications.

**Microbial Control Solutions**

Microbial control solutions are used to prevent the development of harmful microorganisms and protect
human health and materials, and are mainly used as disinfectants or preservatives, among other
applications. End markets include Hygiene, Home and Personal Care, Wood Protection, Paints &
Coatings, Material Protection and Crop Protection. Each end market is subject to different underlying
growth drivers and exhibits different growth trajectories. The addressable market (excluding Crop
Protection) is expected to grow at a 4.3% compound annual growth rate (‘‘CAGR’’) between 2019 and
2025. In 2020, the Hygiene market benefitted from Covid-19 related tailwinds, as the need for disinfection
products and awareness of their importance spread. Going forward, this greater shift towards the
application of biocides is likely to persist, supporting further market growth. The overall market is driven
by structural megatrends such as the growing global population and, in particular, middle class,
urbanization and rising living standards. Other trends include changing lifestyle and increasing focus on the
environment and sustainability and safeguarding people’s wellbeing as well as regulation.

The European and North American disinfection markets are mature and highly regulated. In Europe, the
market is governed by Regulation (EU) 528/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of
May 22, 2012 (as amended) concerning the making available on the market and use of biocidal products
(‘‘BPR’’), which sets out rules governing the approval of active substances in biocidal products, authorizing
the supply and use of biocidal products, and the supply of articles, treated with biocidal products. In the
US, the main regulatory body is the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (‘‘EPA’’).

Registrations of anti-microbial formulations is a lengthy and costly process, requiring significant regulatory
and application expertise as well as product know-how. Over the last two decades regulations have become
increasingly strict, leading to approximately 70% to 80% of registered antimicrobials having been phased
out by the EU and a similar number having been phased out in the US (with some differences among
individual U.S. states), resulting in higher development and registration costs. At the same time, regulatory
pressure leads to greater innovation amongst incumbent producers, and as a result, drives the market
towards higher value formulation and higher-end actives. In APAC and the rest of the world, regulatory
frameworks are developing and maturing, with both markets still heavily relying on ultra-low-cost chlorinebased disinfectants.

Currently there is some degree of regulatory pressure on traditional biocides such as zinc pyrithione and
creosote. In general, regulation creates growth opportunities for our alternative biocides.

**_Hygiene_**

_Industry Overview_

The hygiene market was estimated to have grown substantially in 2020, driven by increased demand as a
result of the Covid-19 pandemic. Long-term growth is expected to benefit from evolving regulatory
standard, new consumer habits and greater hygiene awareness, developed over the course of the pandemic.
The two main application areas of disinfection are professional and home care disinfection. The regional
split of the professional disinfection was 35% North America, 24% Europe, 32% APAC and 9% rest of the
world (as of 2020). The regional split of the home care disinfection market was 42% North America, 25%
Europe, 25% APAC and 8% rest of the world (as of 2020).

Our key competitors in active ingredients include Stepan, IFF, Solvay and Nouryon.

_Underlying Market Trends_

Within the Hygiene market, demand for microbial control solutions is primarily driven by demand for
disinfecting products. Between 2015 and 2019, the addressable market grew at a CAGR of approximately
7%, due to increasing awareness and stricter hygiene protocols. In 2020, the Hygiene market experienced
substantial growth of approximately 80%, driven by even higher compliance protocols and panic induced
buying of disinfectants as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic. The fundamental trends are expected to
continue after the Covid-19 pandemic is considered under control, but with varying resilience of the curve
depending on the end-market. As a result of a greater emphasis on hygiene, a shift in consumer behavior,
and evolving regulatory standards, long-term demand is expected to remain well above the 2019 levels.
Overall, the addressable market is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 9.1% between 2019 and
2025.

The European and North American disinfection markets are mature and highly regulated. While
regulation was temporarily relaxed at the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, it is expected to further
tighten post-pandemic.

**_Home and Personal Care_**

_Industry Overview_

Biocides play a crucial role in home and personal care (‘‘H&PC’’) products to prevent spoiling, and they
are the main active ingredient in anti-dandruff products. The H&PC market is expected to grow at a
CAGR of approximately 2.4% between 2019 and 2025.

The H&PC market can be divided into three sub-segments: hair care, personal care preservation and home
care preservation. The regional split of the hair care sub-segment was 24% North America, 22% Europe,
38% APAC and 16% rest of the world (as of 2020). The regional split for the personal care preservation
sub-segment was 25% North America, 24% Europe, 34% APAC and 17% rest of the world (as of 2020).

124


-----

The regional split of the home care preservation sub-segment was 33% North America, 25% Europe, 30%
APAC and 12% rest of the world (as of 2020). All sub-segments have significant regional exposure to
APAC, benefitting from increasing demand from rising disposable incomes and population growth.

Our key competitors in active ingredients include Clariant, IFF and Ashland.

_Underlying Market Trends_

Rising disposable income levels, a greater emphasis on personal grooming and a greater focus on personal
health and wellness are the key drivers of growth in the market.

There are several factors affecting future penetration of biocides in H&PC markets, including increasing
consumer sensitivity, increasing attractiveness of ‘‘chemical-free’’ products, growth of natural preservatives,
biocide reduction through boosters and growing usage of solidified and concentrated products.

In personal care and home care, the desire of consumer goods companies to appeal to customer’s
eco-friendly demands, is shifting the balance away from traditional biocides. This is particularly the case
for ‘‘indie’’ brands and start-ups, though these represent less than 5% of the market. However, biocides
remain critical to their applications, and market penetration of these natural preservatives is modest due to
their inadequate efficacy and significantly higher cost. Biocides represent a limited share of the overall cost
of end products. Limited potential cost savings from reducing concentrations or replacing active
ingredients, reduces the incentive for companies to make a change away from traditional biocides, due to
the potentially severe reputational impact from a mistake in new chemical formulations. However, there is
strong pressure to reduce concentration levels through blends and boosters. In North America and
Europe, due to increasing demand for concentrated products with lower water content, there is less
breeding space for microbes and a reduced need for biocidal active ingredients.

The H&PC market is highly regulated, due to the potential impact on consumers and the environment.
Europe is the most heavily regulated region, followed by North America and APAC.

**_Wood Protection_**

_Industry Overview_

In the wood protection (‘‘WP’’) market, biocides are used to protect and enhance wood with innovative
technologies to improve its useful life and expand its applications. The underlying market is expected to
grow at a 3.5% CAGR between 2019 and 2025, primarily driven by global construction demand. The WP
market is split into residential treatment (approximately 60%) and industrial treatment (approximately
40%). On a regional level, the US is the largest market as a result of the high level of wood usage and high
level of biocide penetration.

Our key competitors include Koppers, Wolman, Rutgers, Viance and Obermeier. Our strong customer
relationships are a key success factor in this industry.

_Underlying Market Trends_

Wood is a climate neutral and sustainable construction material. The increasing use of wood as a
construction material and greater use of wood in buildings (such as decks), are the key drivers of growth in
residential treatment. In the industrial treatment, demand is primarily driven by growth in utility poles and
railway lines.

Biocide penetration is expected to remain stable, with limited threats of substitution. The increasing need
to protect wood in contact with mud and other exposed environmental conditions drives penetration in
residential treatment. However, the acceptance of wood alternatives (such as utility poles made of
concrete, steel or composites) is reducing overall demand growth in industrial treatment. Additionally,
alternative technologies, such as thermally modified (i.e. heat treated to prevent fungal decay),
furfurylation modified (i.e. wood density increased by impregnation with furfuryl alcohol to reduce
moisture levels) and acetylation modified (i.e. chemically modified wood by the acetylation process, no
longer presenting an attractive food source for fungi) wood, present alternatives to biocides. These are,
however, niche alternatives, which generally remain too expensive for commercial application.

The market is highly regulated, with each region characterized by its own set of regulations. One product
in particular, which is facing a high degree of regulatory pressure globally is creosote, a tar-based
preservative whose oil borne system improves wood’s resilience. Creosote is under review in Europe

125


-----

because it meets the BPR’s exclusion criteria, due to its classification as a category 1B carcinogen and it
may be banned in Europe. A final decision is expected within a matter of weeks on whether or not it will be
phased out, or its permitted usage will be extended by three to five years. A substitute for creosote by other
biocides represents a significant growth opportunity for us and other incumbent players. There are no
potential bans expected in North America or APAC, where it is currently widely used due to the lack of
alternatives. We do not produce creosote-related products, so we do not expect a ban on creosotes to harm
us or that any replacement would cannibalize our existing sales.

**_Paints & Coatings_**

_Industry Overview_

In the paints and coatings (‘‘P&C’’) market, biocides are responsible for the prevention of microbial
spoilage. The market is expected to grow at a 4.5% CAGR between 2019 and 2025, driven by underlying
growth in the automotive, construction and general industries, with a focus on developing regions such as
India, China and South East Asia.

The addressable market is split between dry in-can, dry-film and marine antifouling applications. Examples
of in-can applications include traditional architectural paints and coatings, whereas dry film relates to
coating on a cured surface, for example, in industrial and infrastructure applications. Marine anti-fouling
coatings are used to prevent attachment of organisms to ship hulls, which can otherwise increase fuel
consumption by up to 7% to 10%.

On a regional basis, the addressable market is evenly distributed across North America, Europe and APAC
for both in-can and dry-film applications. However, approximately 74% of the antifouling market is based
in APAC, due to the large size of the shipping industry in this region.

Our key competitors include Thor, Troy, Lanxess and IFF. The market is commoditized, resulting in some
pricing pressures, with differentiation and value being created by matrix formulation innovations, such as
boosters that allow reduced biocide content or other improved properties such longer use time, as well as
the level of services offered.

_Underlying Market Trends_

In-can applications experienced strong demand growth, with demand from architectural paints growing
approximately 3% in 2020. In particular, there has been an increase in do-it-yourself demand as consumers
have renovated their homes during Covid-19 related lockdowns and this trend is expected to continue into
2021. The underlying market is expected to grow at approximately 4% between 2021 and 2025. Within
dry-film and marine antifouling applications, the underlying market growth is driven by stricter regulatory
requirements that demand increasingly complex products, which are less harmful, but still very effective.
The dry-film market remained flat in 2020, but is expected to grow approximately 4%, between 2020 and
2022. Marine anti-fouling has been impacted by a slowdown in global trade in 2020, however, this is
expected to pick-up with the underlying market growing approximately 1% to 2% going forward through
2022.

Overall, biocide penetration is expected to remain broadly stable, driven by a mixture of headwinds and
offsetting tailwinds. Structural growth drivers include the shift from solvent-based to water-based coatings
(driven by environmental concerns presented by volatile organic compounds) and the shift to
high-performance coatings in developing markets. The switch to water-based coatings is driving biocide
penetration, because water provides a breeding ground for microbes and, thus, an increase in water-based
coatings drives greater demand for biocides. This trend has particular headroom in APAC.
High-performance paints and coatings also require higher levels of biocides, and thus a greater use of these
paints drives biocide demand. These positive penetration trends are expected to continue over the next
three to five years. On the other hand, there is growing regulatory pressure to reduce the amount of
biocide use in paints, such as the recent phase out of methylisothiazolinone (‘‘MIT’’), (which we do not
produce) and increasing consumer demand for ‘‘green’’ labels, which guarantee more stringent biocide
thresholds, reducing market penetration. Furthermore, increasing use of boosters and functional additives
can reduce the need for high biocide concentrations.

The industry is highly regulated, with regulatory changes typically led by the EU, with the US and APAC
often following suit. The main regulatory bodies heavily restrict both the amount and usage of biocides
within paints and coatings, as well as active ingredients for use in formulated products. For in-can
applications, MIT is being phased out, particularly from DIY/consumer paints, because the EU now

126


-----

requires hazardous re-labelling for MIT due to its strong skin sensitizing properties. For dry film
applications, there will potentially be negative impacts from the reclassification of zinc pyrithione in March
2022, which may lead to unfavorable regulatory labelling. In marine anti-fouling, there are concerns over
the use of heavy metals such as zinc and copper. However, the introduction of a regulatory framework in
China will provide an opportunity for a significant degree a reformulation.

**_Material Protection_**

_Industry Overview_

In the material protection (‘‘MP’’) market, biocides are required to improve performance, aesthetics and
anti-corrosion properties of metals, plastics and other materials. The addressable market grew at a 5%
CAGR between 2015 and 2019. Going forward, the market is expected to grow at a CAGR of
approximately 4.2%, between 2019 and 2025.

The majority of activity in the MP market takes place in Asia, accounting for approximately 40% of the
addressable market, followed by Europe and North America, accounting for approximately 25% each. The
key segments of the market are polymers and textiles (approximately 30%), oil and gas (approximately
25%), plastics (approximately 20%), metal working fluids (approximately 15%) and leather protection
(approximately 10%).

The market is fragmented in terms of competition, largely due to the diverse requirements across the
various applications. Our key competitors include Thor, Troy and Lanxess. There are significant entry
requirements, such as a high degree of formulation know-how.

_Underlying Market Trends_

The underlying market growth is primarily driven by delivering biocides and additives for plastics,
polymers, metals and other industrial applications, as well as by serving oil and gas suppliers (fracking
solutions). This is a service-driven industry with high demand for in-depth expertise to support customers
in product composition, regulation and production.

The market is focusing on alternative and environmentally friendly materials (for example, replacement of
traditional plastics with alternative composite materials). The rising demand for services and innovations
for new compositions is expected to benefit players with a focus on active ingredients and a strong
established service and R&D offerings.

Regulations regarding the ban of plastics also lead to a rise in demand for innovative solutions (new
compositions) to use for alternative materials. The regulatory impact for market leaders is assessed to be
limited, due to their broad portfolio.

**_Crop Protection_**

_Industry overview_

The addressable market in crop protection (‘‘CP’’) includes molluscicides, selected pesticides (herbicides,
fungicides and insecticides) and adjuvants, which aim to protect crops (such as fruits, vegetables and nuts)
from pests leading to increased yields. We are only present in selected segments of the market (for
example, molluscicides) and regions (for example, Brazil). The overall crop protection market is expected
to grow at a 4.0% CAGR, from 2020 to 2025.

Our key competitors are global agrochemical producers including Corteva, BASF, Syngenta, Bayer and
FMC.

_Underlying Market Trends_

The growth of the crop protection market is primarily driven by megatrends, including the growing
population, rising disposable income per capita and increasing consumption of meat, as well as the
rejuvenation of product portfolios (partially driven by regulation, as the EU is putting pressure on older
molecules). However, there are risks of potential limitations or bans on selected ingredients, for example,
metaldehyde (a key ingredient in molluscicides) due to the long-term risks to birds and mammals. As a
result, the crop protection market for consumers is increasingly shifting towards biopesticides, although the
crop protection market for professionals continues to prefer traditional pesticides due to their higher
effectiveness.

127


-----

**_Specialty Chemicals Services_**

Our specialty chemicals businesses include Performance Intermediates and Chemicals, Composite
Materials and CDMO and address a broad range of industrial and consumer end-markets. The
addressable market is expected to grow in correlation with GDP growth.

**_Performance Intermediates and Chemicals_**

_Industry Overview_

The PIC market field offers a broad range of chemistries, which serve a wide array of end-markets. Within
this market, at our Visp site we produce ketene derivatives, diketene derivatives, and HCN derivatives,
primarily used as intermediates across end-markets. We also produce cracker products such as niacin
(vitamin B3), methylbutynol (‘‘MBI’’) and acetylene, for animal feed, human nutrition, and cosmetics
end-markets. At our Nanjing, China, site, we produce PMDA, which is primarily used for films in high-end
electronics and insulation. Our hydrazine solutions and propellant products are produced in our site in
Lake Charles, USA and are also used in a wide range of applications such as agriculture, pharmaceuticals,
water and the space industry.

_Underlying Market Trends_

Acetylene and MBI are intermediates used in animal feed, human nutrition and cosmetics applications,
primarily for the production of vitamins A and E as well as in the flavor and fragrance industry. Acetylene
is not transported in large volumes from the point of production, making supply proximity key. MBI is a
derivative of acetylene, with additional applications in agricultural and industrial applications. The key
end-market drivers include livestock population growth, human population growth and supplement
penetration.

Vitamin B3 is an ingredient used primarily in the animal feed, human nutrition, and other chemical
intermediate end-markets. Vitamin B3 is less differentiated in its use in animal feed applications, while
human nutrition applications require a greater degree of specialization due to health and safety
regulations. There are two variants of vitamin B3, niacin and niacinamide, which are produced through
separate value chains, but serve the same end-markets. We are a leading player in vitamin B3.

The key end-market drivers for vitamin B3 include livestock population, human population growth and
supplement penetration. From 2017 to 2020, the vitamin B3 market grew at an approximately 0.7%
CAGR, primarily due to increasing usage of supplements in animal food, global population growth and
increasing consumption of meat and fish, partially offset by livestock population decline in APAC due to
African swine fever. From 2020 to 2025, the vitamin B3 market is expected to grow at an approximately 3%
CAGR, driven predominantly by a bounce back in the livestock population in APAC after the expected end
of the Covid-19 pandemic and increasing protein and supplements consumption, both for animal feed and
human nutrition, due to health trends.

Ketene and diketene derivatives have various applications as intermediates across different end-markets.
Due to the limited shelf life of ketene, which turns into diketene soon after production, consumption
typically occurs close to the point of production. Both products are unlikely to be substituted, given the
essential nature of the intermediates in the value chain, the diversified end-markets in which these
products are used, and the capital expenditures required to build new production capacity.

In terms of volume, our main ketene derivative product is acetic anhydride, which is an intermediate with
applications across consumer, pharmaceutical, vitamin and wood applications. Acetic anhydride is also
used in cellulose acetate filters.

Our main diketene derivative products are CAAEt and AAEMA, which are more specialized niche
derivatives. CAAEt is primarily used in L-Carnitine for animal feed and human nutrition, as well as
various pharmaceutical and therapeutic intermediates, with additional applications in agricultural chemical
intermediates. AAEMA is primarily used in resin formulations as an additive for paints and coatings
applications, to increase durability and stickiness of coatings, with additional other applications as fillers,
sealants, and adhesives. We are a leading global provider of CAAEt and AAEMA.

Growth across the addressable ketene and diketene derivative markets is expected to be neutral-to-positive
depending on markets and applications. Growth in acetic anhydride is expected to be stable, largely
dependent on key market segments. In CAAEt, growth is expected to be positive, driven by nutrition,

128


-----

pharmaceutical and agricultural markets. Overall, growth is expected to be stable, with global ketene and
diketene consumption expected to grow at approximately 2% to 3% from 2019 to 2025.

HCN is a highly reactive chemical compound produced from ammonium and methane. HCN is not
transported and is generally consumed at the production site. We primarily produce cyanogen chlorides,
which are niche specialty HCN derivatives. Cyanogen chlorides make up a small fraction of the overall
HCN market, accounting for approximately 3% of consumption in 2020, with the remainder of the
consumption volume split between other chemical derivatives, such as adiponitrile, methionine and
analogs, sodium cyanide and methionine.

Our main cyanogen chloride products are malonitrile (‘‘MDN’’), chlorosulfonyl isocyanate derivatives
(‘‘CSI’’), cyanate esters and sodium dichloroacetate (‘‘NaDCA’’). MDN is primarily used in
pharmaceutical, vitamins, and pesticide applications. CSI is primarily used as intermediates for active
pharmaceutical ingredient syntheses, and polymer production. Cyanate resin is primarily used for
composite materials. NaDCA is primarily used as active ingredient in the hygiene and water business. With
these HCN based products, we have a global leading role. Growth in overall HCN consumption has been
flat from 2015 to 2020. From 2020 to 2025, overall HCN consumption for existing products is expected to
grow at an approximately 1% CAGR, with consumption of niche cyanogen chloride derivatives expected to
grow slightly above HCN growth.

**_Composite Materials_**

_Industry Overview_

Composite materials are the product of combining two or more constituent materials into a singular
‘composite’ matrix, which provide unique functional properties different from that of the individual
materials. Within the composites value chain, we produce resin components and resin systems, which are
incorporated in the composite for critical, high-temperature resistant applications, primarily for the
electronics, aerospace, and industrial end-markets. Combined, the addressable market is expected to have
top-line growth of 6.8% from 2019 to 2025.

_Underlying Market Trends_

For the Electronics end-market, we produce Primaset� resins, which are used as a high-performance raw
material, mostly for printed circuit boards (‘‘PCBs’’) for telecommunications infrastructure, with some
applications for integrated circuits. Within PCBs, cyanate ester resins are utilized in high-end lamination
and encapsulation processes, where superior dielectric and thermal performance is required.

The key market growth drivers for this end-market are primarily telecommunications and IT infrastructure
spending, including applications in servers and base stations, with growth also driven by 4G/5G radio
access network spending. Spending for core IT and network infrastructure is expected to grow at a 4%
CAGR from 2020 to 2024, with rapid increases in networking, cloud computing, and other data-intensive
functions, driving higher technical requirements for high-speed servers, where cyanate ester resins are used
today. Growth is also expected in high-end electronic devices, where innovative technology continues to
develop.

For the Aerospace end-market, we produce Primaset� resins, used as a high-performance raw material, as
well as high-end hardeners (Lonzacure�), used as a curing agent primarily for epoxy resins, that are used in
composite materials for commercial and military aircraft. Composite materials are increasingly used in
aircraft bodies, wings, and turbine blades, to reduce weight and improve fuel efficiency.

The key market growth driver for this end-market is new aircraft builds, both commercial and military,
with some growth also driven by maintenance, repair, and overhaul. The new commercial aircraft build
market is expected to experience a strong rebound in growth, following 2020 troughs driven by Covid-19
related interruptions, returning to pre-Covid-19 levels over the next four to five years, with an
approximately 6.4% CAGR expected from 2019 to 2025. In new military aircraft builds, demand has
remained robust, and is expected to quickly recover from Covid-19 lows over the next year, with an
approximately 2.3% CAGR expected from 2019 to 2025. Overall, commercial and military aircraft
production is expected to see growth of approximately 5% from 2019 to 2025.

For the Industrial end-market, we produce DETDA80, a curing agent primarily for polyurethane and
polyurea resins, serving a wide range of industrial applications, including wheels and rollers.

129


-----

The key market growth driver for this end-market is the global polyurethane market, which is expected to
grow in-pace with industrial output. Polyurethane production is expected to grow at a rate of
approximately 3.3% from 2019 to 2025, driven by a fast rebound from Covid-19, which resulted in a 5%
decline from 2019 to 2020 as a result of factory closures in the initial stages of the Covid-19 pandemic.

**_CDMO_**

_Industry Overview_

Contract development and manufacturing organizations (‘‘CDMOs’’) are businesses which partner with
customers as a way to outsource product research and manufacturing and de-risk projects by leveraging
third-party capabilities. CDMO partners usually offer development and manufacturing capabilities that
allow their customers to add missing technological skills or forgo making their own investments while
shortening time-to-market. As a result, they typically provide expanded production platforms, often more
efficient cost bases and reduced time-to-market. In this industry, we have historically provided CDMO
services in the agricultural chemical and biotech / fermentation industries. Of these, we have primarily
served the agricultural chemical CDMO end-market, which is expected to grow at a 2% to 3% CAGR
from 2019 to 2025. Since 2020, we have broadened our target market with some success and are actively
exploring opportunities in non-traditionally served market fields. For example, we became the partner of
choice for an industrial application in novel batteries.

_Underlying Market Trends_

For the agricultural chemicals CDMO market, we primarily synthesize intermediates or agricultural
chemical active ingredients for large agricultural companies. The applications for these active ingredients
fall into three principal categories: herbicides for the control of weeds, insecticides for the control of
insects, and fungicides for the control of fungi and molds. These products are mainly used for the
protection of various crops, including fruits and vegetables, cereal, soybeans, rice, cotton, and rapeseed.

The agricultural chemicals CDMO market is primarily driven by the underlying agricultural chemicals end
market, which defines the underlying customer base for the agricultural chemicals CDMO market, and the
universe of molecules to be outsourced to CDMO partners. The key growth drivers for the broad
agricultural chemicals market are primarily structural, such as demographic changes alongside farm
economics. From 2015 to 2019, the agricultural chemicals market has grown at a 1% to 2% CAGR, driven
largely by crop oversupply lowering crop prices and increasing distributor inventory levels. From 2019 to
2024, the agricultural chemicals market is expected to grow at a 2% to 3% CAGR, primarily due to
continuing population growth and increasing meat consumption, as well as improvement in farm
economics following inventory de-stocking and the impact of trade wars. The shift toward eco-friendly,
precision agriculture and increased usage of bio-technologies driving more efficient production, is also
expected to contribute to broad agricultural chemical growth.

Other factors driving agricultural chemicals CDMO market growth include the rise of generic players with
limited degrees of CDMO outsourcing, as well as the share of outsourcing by large agricultural chemicals
players. From 2015 to 2019, as farm economics weakened, low-cost generic agricultural chemical producers
increased pressure on large agricultural chemical producers, taking share as farmers sought to cut cost.
Share of outsourcing among large agricultural chemicals companies has remained stable over time, with
increasingly complex molecules driven by crop yield requirements and growing regulation requiring the
technology and expertise of CDMO partners.

Overall, broad agricultural chemical market growth, as well as stable share of outsourcing in the large
agricultural chemical producers, have contributed to a 1% to 2% CAGR in the agricultural chemical
CDMO market from 2015 to 2019. From 2019 to 2025, the agricultural chemical CDMO market is
expected to grow at a 2% to 3% CAGR, driven primarily by improving farm economics and increasing
pressure on crop yields, as the need for efficient production continues.

In this general context, companies based in higher-cost regions in Europe may not offer a superior cost
structure to companies with operations in lower-cost geographies. Customers typically use European
suppliers when IP protection is more relevant than cost. However, in a limited overall market with limited
growth, companies must explore new, higher-growth market fields. We have therefore broadened our
offerings to other industrial segments.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading global provider of microbial control solutions across various consumer and industrial
markets. We also offer specialty chemical products and services covering composites and specialty
chemicals. Headquartered in Basel, Switzerland, we are building on more than 120 years of the business’
history as a trusted specialty chemicals supplier.

With more than 670 individual products and services, we focus on attractive end markets with significant
growth potential. We serve more than 5,300 clients worldwide, and our products are deeply imbedded into
the value chains of our key customers, with many of whom we have long-standing relationships. We have 18
manufacturing facilities, supported by the market-leading expertise of our 13 R&D centers and a broad
network of 35 sales offices across our key geographical regions of EIMEA, APAC and the Americas. We
have what we believe to be a market-leading regulatory expertise, including on the European Union and
the United States markets.

For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we had total sales of CHF1,825 million,
CHF1,747 million and CHF1,716 million, respectively. Our profit for the period was CHF79 million,
CHF73 million and CHF98 million, respectively, for the same periods. Our pro forma Adjusted EBITDA

We report sales to third parties on a business unit level and a market field level. Our operations comprise

Overall, it has broader market presence (in terms of product spectrum) than any competitor in the
microbial control industry. The business unit’s vast portfolio of over 470 individual products and

**Our Competitive Strengths**

We believe that the following are among our key competitive strengths:

**_Fundamental macro trends driving growth across highly attractive end markets_**

Our business focuses on highly attractive end markets that offer significant structural growth potential. We
operate in profitable niche markets within the high-growth microbial control market and attractive niches
within the specialty chemical services market.

The biocides market is supported by a broad range of global trends driving underlying growth across
diversified application areas, such as our customers’ shift to more complex formulated products in
response to consumer preferences and increasingly stringent regulatory requirements. It also benefits from
supportive demand as a result of the critical functions that biocides serve for our customers and their end
customers, which has been further evidenced by the increasing demand for our products due to changing
customer preferences induced by the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly in our Hygiene market field. The
Covid-19 pandemic has increased the need for protection of health and well-being and is creating a ‘‘new
normal’’ in the use of disinfectants, requiring us to stay ahead of the curve, defining and supporting the
‘‘new normal’’ and providing us with a significant opportunity, as well as with the responsibility for
educating customers and the public given our market leading position. Megatrends such as the growing
global population and, in particular, middle class, urbanization and rising living standards and other trends
such as changing lifestyles, increasing focus on the environment, safeguarding people’s wellbeing and
increasing regulation are aligned in favor of the Microbial Control Solutions business unit’s strengths,
creating attractive growth opportunities. In particular, the biocides market requires substantial research
and development investment and is a highly regulated market with lengthy registration processes and
regulatory reviews. We believe that our experience and expertise in this area would be difficult for new
entrants to replicate. Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit is particularly well positioned to
navigate these processes and reviews to capitalize on favorable underlying consumer demand.

Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit is active in high-growth niches, such as composites. We have
a pipeline of innovative products in Specialty Chemical Services, including composite materials and
services related to our CDMO market field (sodium batteries, vegan collagen for cosmetics and nutrition,
other nutritional fermented products, and fragrances ingredients).

133


-----

**_Leading and defendable market positions across an attractive and diversified product portfolio_**

We have well established, leading market positions supported by our attractive product and service
offerings to customers focused on formulation, coupled with a broad product offering and we believe that
this provides us with a sustainable competitive advantage. Further, we continuously evaluate our technical
capabilities, including R&D and manufacturing, to consider potential upgrades and to enable us to
maintain our leading market position and to meet market and customer needs.

Our Microbial Control Solutions business unit is a market leading business across a broad range of end
markets, with the most comprehensive portfolio of active and formulated solutions that provide
application-specific results for our customers. This scale allows us to have a broader end market presence
than any of our competitors across the microbial control industry, particularly in our Hygiene, Paints and
Coatings and Wood Protection market fields.

With 42 actives approved in the United States and 20 actives approved in the European Union, our
manufacturing of actives provides leading scale with the broadest active base in the market and in-house
production of quats and pyrithiones. Our formulated solutions offering is based upon our microbial labs
and research and development capabilities, extensive knowledge of end-use applications and access to our
proprietary registered formulations to our customers. This allows our customers to enter the market with
new products much quicker, avoiding regulatory approval processes of up to seven years and the collection
of relevant field data for specific markets of up to five years. While our customers need registrations to run
their own processes and to protect their products, they are generally not experts in the time-consuming
process of registering biocides.

Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit is focused on niches with high profitability and value
generation potential utilizing our highly specialized chemical and fermentation technologies. We provide
critical products and services to specialty end markets that are characterized by high resilience and provide
us with symbiotic relationships with our blue-chip customer base. In particular, we are a leader in Vitamin
B3 and a leading supplier of cyanate ester resins. We have a highly automated and efficient setup that
leverages complex chemistries and fermentation technologies across various end markets and use
innovative processes and systems focused on process development for exclusive synthesis projects of our
customers and for multi-customer products. Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit acts as a key
enabler for growth in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and we are increasingly finding
applications of the processes developed in our Specialty Chemical Services business unit in the Microbial
Control Solutions business unit.

**_Diversified, long-standing and loyal customer base_**

We operate a service-focused business model that provides a broad range of formulation capabilities and
regulatory support and customized solutions. This has allowed us to form close relationships with many of
our customers that have often lasted for decades.

We provide a highly sophisticated specialty chemicals offering with R&D, process development, regulatory
support and innovation capabilities that can be tailored to our customers’ specific requirements, resulting
in a unique customer proposition. Our 13 R&D centers across the globe allow us to develop new products
to meet the needs of our customers, with the regional set-up of our R&D organization enabling us to
establish close links and a high degree of customer intimacy. In addition, through our technical service
offerings, we offer specialized solutions for customer technology and application specifications and are
able to facilitate end-consumer safety expectations. This close cooperation and the deep integration in our
customers’ value chain has resulted in high customer retention, with several having started more than
50 years ago with one of our key customers being served via a co-located pipeline directly from our
facilities. Our customer base is also diverse, with over 5,300 customers and our top 10 customers

2020, representing 2.9%, 2.8% and 2.1% of sales to third parties in 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively.

**_Well-invested global manufacturing footprint, leveraging multiple technology platforms across the portfolio_**

Our global presence and a well-invested asset base allow us to provide our customers with valuable
benefits from our broad range of technology platforms and skill sets and flexibility in our manufacturing
setup.

We operate an asset-based, process-oriented and efficiency-driven specialty business, with Visp being our
main site of operations, along with other key facilities located in the United States, China and the Czech
Republic. Our unique setup in Visp with its highly automated Cracker Core and the HCN and Ketene/
Diketene networks, is optimized towards high-value niches. The Visp site includes five highly flexible
multi-purpose plants for custom manufacturing of specialty chemicals for various applications and two
multi-product chemical plants mainly serving the Composite Materials market field of our Specialty
Chemical Services business unit.

With our global footprint of 18 manufacturing sites across EIMEA, APAC and the Americas we can meet
the specific needs of customers across the globe. Currently, the Microbial Control Solutions business unit
is focused on and has its strongest sales in the Americas, while the Specialty Chemical Services business
unit is focused on and has its strongest sales in Europe. Given the focus of the sales distribution of these
business units in the US and Europe, we believe that our operations in Asia present a growth area for both
of our business units. We believe that our global presence combined with regional expertise provides us
with a significant competitive advantage, ensuring local, physical proximity to clients, which is a key for
many of the Microbial Control Solutions market fields, such as the Wood Protection market.
