**_Attractive financial profile with strong cash flow generation_**

We have historically delivered resilient cash flows with growing sales to third parties (on a currencyadjusted basis), Normalized Adjusted EBITDA margin and cash conversion. In particular, our business
model, including our recent focus on directing our portfolio towards higher growth and higher margin
products, has proven its resilience during the Covid-19 pandemic, with strong performance in 2020.

Our diverse mix of products, end markets, customers and geographies results in stability through economic
and raw material cycles as demonstrated by our 2020 growth in sales to third parties of 3.5% on a constant
currency basis (decrease of 2.1% on an actual currency basis). We have a strong focus on continuous
operational improvements, for example our recent cost of goods sold improvement program that focused
on fixed cost reduction, alternative chemical routes, debottlenecking and variable cost reduction, and a
demonstrated pricing excellence as well as ability to pass through costs, driving our 2020 Normalized
Adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.4%. Our track record of delivering on productivity and operational
optimization opportunities has led to an attractive financial profile resulting in high cash conversion of
76.6% in 2020 (calculated as (i) Normalized Adjusted EBITDA _less capital expenditures_ _plus change in_
operating net working capital divided by (ii) Normalized Adjusted EBITDA). We believe that our business
has a significant opportunity to drive cost savings and increase profitability margins, particularly through
our new cost savings initiatives related to our Transformation Program and because, as a standalone
company, we will no longer be part of a more pharmaceutically oriented company.

We have a strong financial trajectory, underpinned by a clear portfolio strategy towards our high-margin
Microbial Control Solutions business unit and penetration of attractive Specialty Chemical Services niches.
We have clear strategies and initiatives to grow, optimize and protect our businesses with the Microbial
Control Solutions and Specialty Chemical Services business units, with increased focus on attractive
‘‘growth’’ businesses, such as the Hygiene market field. In particular, as a result of the Covid-19 pandemic
and trends in consumer preferences, we expect that the Hygiene market field will continue to grow as
products in this market field continue to serve a critical function for customers. These growth businesses
offer high and sustainable growth rates with higher margins, which drives overall profitability.

**_Highly experienced management team, leading talented workforce and highly committed financial sponsors_**

Operating Officer, Antje Gerber, joined LSI in 2019 and was appointed as COO in 2020, bringing
substantial experience from previous positions at Venator Materials (formerly Huntsman), HB Fuller and
Evonik. In addition to our management team, we have a lean and efficient organizational structure
powered by talent, expertise and a passion to create real value as a market leader supported by a
well-trained global workforce with high employee satisfaction reflected in long tenures, low turnover and
strong performance.

**Our Strategies**

As a result of our recent carve-out from Lonza, the Acquisition and the resulting organizational changes
and strategy review, we are fully focused on delivering our growth strategy, which builds on four main
pillars:

**_Unlock growth_**

We are confident that we can unlock growth in our business through our numerous initiatives and are well
positioned to address and capitalize on current, fundamental market trends. These trends include
tightening regulatory landscapes, evolving customer preferences, increasing focus on the environment and
sustainability, increasing focus on safeguarding people and resources and growing end-customer base.

The tightening regulatory landscapes around the world, in particular in the United States and Europe, are
creating opportunities for us to utilize our regulatory expertise to grow our business. In particular, we
believe our Hygiene market field is well positioned for growth by expanding our complementary
formulation platform and supplemental registration model in North America and capitalizing on
significant upcoming BPR-related commercial opportunities in Europe.

Evolving customer preferences present opportunities for us to grow our business in new end markets. For
example, we are seeing an increased demand for low temperature laundry applications in Home and
Personal Care and have developed new products to address that market. Additionally, the implementation
of 5G telecommunications systems presents an opportunity for us to develop and market 5G-related
electronics applications within our Composites market field. Further, the increasing global focus on the
environment and sustainability has opened up new R&D-driven opportunities, particularly in our Paints
and Coatings market field, such as marine antifouling, and within our Composites market field for light
weight-related opportunities in aerospace applications. In addition, concerns about safeguarding people’s
wellbeing and resources is creating opportunities in Hygiene through forward integration of ingredients
into ready-to-use formulated solutions and in Wood Protection through demand for replacement
technologies that address environmental and regulatory concerns. For example, upcoming BPR regulations
in Europe will impact the production and use of creosote (which we do not produce) and we expect that
our substitute product, Tanasote, will be well positioned to address these upcoming regulations.

The growing middle class, particularly in South America, is leading to above average growth in consumer
related markets such as home and personal care and hygiene, and we have seen year-on-year growth in our
Microbial Control Solutions business unit in Latin America of greater than 42% in 2020. We expect growth
to continue in these markets and believe we are well positioned through our global manufacturing
footprint and our extensive R&D and regulatory capability to continue to address customer needs in these
markets.

**_Drive innovation_**

Our research and development operations are key to maintaining our sector-leading innovation and ability
to respond to market developments and customer needs and are a core component of our customer
offering. Our ability to anticipate and navigate the regulatory environments in key jurisdictions allows us to
commercialize our products. We have a full pipeline of innovation projects across market fields which we
manage rigorously through a stage-gated R&D process, which was implemented in 2020 to focus more on
market and customer driven innovations. This process aims to continuously evaluate projects to assess
their ability to deliver real value to our customers and ability to successfully make it to market.

Our innovation projects are driven by market and customer needs for applications that make a difference
and are a key driver of revenue growth, particularly for our Microbial Control Solutions business unit.
Many of our projects are joint R&D efforts with our customers, which are sometimes co-funded by our
customers. Some of our innovations use the capabilities of our cross-business unit network, for example,
the development and scale up of new antidandruff products by our Specialty Chemical Services business
unit for a customer need within our Microbial Control Solutions business unit. We expect to continue to

138


-----

invest in our R&D, maintaining similar levels of investment in R&D as in past years and to look for ways
to capitalize on cross-business unit capabilities to enhance our offerings.

Our ability to commercialize the knowledge we have from our years of regulatory experience sets us apart
from our competitors. We work closely with regulators throughout the entire development process to
ensure that we have solutions for upcoming regulatory challenges. We will continue to develop strong
relationships with key regulatory stakeholders and focus on and develop our regulatory expertise to
strengthen our customer relationships through joint projects with our customers.

**_Manage the portfolio_**

We will continue to focus on highly attractive end markets that offer significant structural growth potential
with an aim to expand our operations in profitable niche markets within the high-growth microbial control
market and attractive niches within the specialty chemical services market. We intend to utilize our
strengths in research and development and regulatory expertise to continue to develop and commercialize
new products for these end markets. We continue to actively manage our portfolio, with clear strategies for
each of the business units and market fields, particularly within our higher-growth businesses. We expect
these strategies will lead to topline and profitability increases going forward.

We are experiencing above-market growth rates in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit, which is
expected to exhibit strong underlying end-market growth of 4.3% CAGR over the period from 2019 to
2025, complemented by selected growth opportunities in other attractive market verticals. This market
growth is driven by a shift to more formulated and higher value products as a result of regulatory and
consumer preferences. Our strong R&D initiatives are particularly vital in our Hygiene, Home and
Personal Care, Paints and Coatings and Wood and Crop Protection market fields. We expect growth in end
markets served by our Hygiene market field, which accounted for 16% of our 2020 sales to third parties, to
be 9.1% over the period from 2019 to 2025 and to be largely driven by Covid-19 increasing the need for
protection of health creating a ‘‘new normal’’ in the use of disinfectants and a permanent shift to more
formulated and higher value products due to tightening regulatory landscapes. Growth in end markets
served by our Home and Personal Care market field, which accounted for 14% of our 2020 sales to third
parties, is expected to be 2.4% and is largely driven by increasing customer awareness of preservation
systems and smart formulations to reduce preservative concentrations and Covid-19 positively impacting
the home care market due to higher hygiene sensitivity and demand for cleanliness and germ-free
solutions. Growth in end markets served by our Wood Protection market field, which accounted for 19% of
our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be 3.5% and is largely driven by increasing popularity of wood
construction due to climate neutrality and sustainability and growth in North America due to higher usage
of wood in construction and greater variety in applications. Growth in end markets served by our Paints
and Coatings market field, which accounted for 7% of our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be
4.5% and is largely driven by positive sales mix-effect due to shifts from solvent-based paints to waterbased paints and increasing usage of high-performance paints in emerging markets. Growth in end markets
served by our Material Protection market field, which accounted for 6% of our 2020 sales to third parties,
is expected to be 4.2% and is largely driven by oil and gas exploration by fracking as well as the
fast-growing plastics industry.

For Specialty Chemical Services we are targeting steady GDP-linked growth, driven by fast growing niche
businesses, particularly in the Composite Materials and CDMO market fields. The strong growth in these
areas is largely driven by focused innovation initiatives. Our highly profitable Composite Materials market
field is focused on serving the growing demand in the industrial and electronics end markets, while CDMO
activities are shifting towards higher value products and improved capacity utilization. Growth in end
markets (e.g., base chemicals such as ethylene and acetylene and pharmaceutical and vitamin
intermediates) served by our PIC market field, which accounted for 24% of our 2020 sales to third parties,
is largely driven by a clear focus on the most attractive niches, including high-tech industrial applications,
and serving pharma and vitamin end markets and underlying Vitamin B3 consumption growth, particularly
growth in animal feed and supplements penetration. Growth in end markets served by our CDMO market
field, which accounted for 7% of our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be 2% to 3% per year from
2019 to 2025 and is largely driven by increasing outsourcing of agrochemical players as well as serving
customers across various industries in need for complex chemical processes or fermentation. Growth in
end markets (e.g., electronics, industrial and transportation) served by our Composite Materials market
field, which accounted for 4% of our 2020 sales to third parties, is expected to be 6.8% per year from 2019
to 2025 and is largely driven by growth of high performance composite materials in electronics and
industrial applications.

**_Business transformation and operational excellence_**

Our business plan includes organic initiatives based on sales and innovation projects to drive topline
growth. The portfolio shift towards high-margin Microbial Control Solutions end markets and
development of attractive Specialty Chemical Services niches is anticipated to drive growth and increase
sales to third parties to above CHF2.1 billion by 2025. We have already seen that our increased focus on
these markets in 2020 has contributed to higher growth, notably in areas with above average profitability
(e.g., Hygiene with fully fledge solutions compared to raw material sales). This has already contributed not
only to top line growth but also to substantial margin improvement for our Microbial Control Solutions
business unit in 2020. We believe our organic initiatives will secure our business plan as a standalone
company for the next five years. Additionally, under new ownership we expect to be able to tap into further
growth ideas and M&A beyond the current business plan.

The second part of our business transformation is operational excellence. Existing cost savings initiatives in
operations will continue to gain momentum over the medium term. ‘‘Pivot’’ is an established program
aimed at cost of goods sold improvements, including fixed cost reduction, alternative chemical routes,
debottlenecking and variable cost reduction. Pivot initially started in Visp and has since been rolled out to
other sites and has, for example, enabled our Mapleton facility to implement its Covid-19 related ramp up
in record time. ‘‘Blackbird’’ is a focused program for operational excellence at our four main Microbial
Control Solutions sites in the US with tailored projects for each facility and is already delivering benefits at
our site in Rochester. We began implementing a global supply chain integration and network optimization
in 2019, with a focus on inventory management and plan to increase customer focus supply chain
initiatives. We will also continue to improve our Visp manufacturing site with a focus on automation,
control room and plant consolidation and digitization measures. Finally, there are numerous initiatives in
operations supporting business growth in our Microbial Control Solutions business unit, with the key
initiatives being improving efficiency gains by streamlining our asset footprint and further increasing our
quat production output. Our operations organization has delivered significant gross profit improvements
and we believe it will continue to do so going forward.

In addition, following the completion of the Acquisition, we intend to implement the Transformation
Program, which is focused on cost savings opportunities related to (i) manufacturing; (ii) raw materials
procurement; (iii) indirect spend control; (iv) sales and marketing costs; (v) G&A costs; and (vi) R&D
costs. We expect to realize cost savings of CHF69 million within 18 months after the Acquisition Closing
Date and an additional CHF2 million from IT cost savings, assuming, among other things, that the
program will be implemented beginning on the Acquisition Closing Date and driven by key management.
We expect to incur one-off costs amounting to approximately CHF103 million between 2021 and 2023 in
connection with these initiatives, comprising: (i) approximately CHF58 million in expected one-off costs,
including severance costs, IT costs and program delivery costs, including consulting, financial and legal
advisory fees in connection with implementing our Transformation Program; and (ii) approximately
CHF45 million in expected capital expenditure related to manufacturing savings.

**History**

Lonza’s history dates back to 1897, when Lonza AG Electricity Works was founded in Gampel, Canton of
Valais, Switzerland, on the banks of the river Lonza. The company moved to Visp in 1909 and over the
years expanded into chemical and biotech areas. It significantly expanded in 1969, beginning operations in
the United States and starting a chemical specialties business. In 1974, Lonza merged with Alusuisse, but
de-merged from the combined Alusuisse-Lonza Group in 1999. In 2011, Lonza acquired Arch Chemicals,
a global biocides company providing innovative solutions to destroy or to selectively inhibit the growth of
harmful microorganisms, to create the world’s leading microbial control business.

While our business was historically integrated with Lonza’s operations, Lonza began the separation
process to facilitate the Acquisition in 2013 with the creation of LSI as its separate segment on the basis of
Arch Chemicals’ legacy business. In 2015, LSI acquired Zelam, a New Zealand company, to boost its
agricultural ingredients and wood protection market fields and Diacon, a Canadian business specialized in
the prevention of mold growth on freshly cut wood, and implemented a series of portfolio shifts to enhance
market focus. In 2019, we discontinued our cyanuric chloride business and manufacturing in Visp. In 2020,
our two business units, Microbial Control Solutions and Specialty Chemical Services, were formed.

**Microbial Control Solutions**

**_Microbial Control Solutions business unit_**

The Microbial Control Solutions business unit delivers highly specialized and differentiated microbial
control technologies and related applications for consumer-facing and resource protection materials. The
vast product portfolio of microbial and chemical technologies offers quality products backed by expert
technical and regulatory know-how. The business unit’s regulatory expertise and extensive data packages
allow it to support customers globally with solutions that are compliant with the applicable regulatory,
environmental and safety standards. A number of products developed by the Microbial Control Solutions
business unit have been approved for use against Covid-19.

This business unit includes the following six market fields focused on end market applications, in order of
margin contributions: (1) Hygiene; (2) Home and Personal Care; (3) Wood Protection; (4) Paints and
Coatings; (5) Material Protection; and (6) Crop Protection. The chart below sets out the contributions of

_Hygiene_

As a global leader in registered biocides, preservatives and antimicrobial formulations, our Hygiene
market field offers solutions for disinfecting and sanitizing surfaces in industrial and institutional settings.
This includes schools, food-processing plants, restaurants, grocery stores, hospitals, operating theaters and
health clinics. In addition, the Hygiene market field offers products for household use, including sanitation
and disinfection of bathrooms and kitchens and washing, disinfecting wipes and hand sanitizers.

Hygiene products are available in a range of formats, including concentrates and formulations for
ready-to-use liquids, wipes, and solids. Its global registrations portfolio includes the EPA, the BPR, the
China and Japan Ministries of Health, as well as many other regulatory agencies around the world.

This market field also provides regulatory and toxicology expertise, supporting compliance with regulatory
regimes across the globe. Its robust data packages and innovative, market-focused research and technology
offerings enable customers to stay at the forefront of industry developments.

Hygiene customers seek consistent innovation and strong regulatory capabilities, prioritizing the following
key purchasing criteria: (i) innovation in formulations; (ii) regulatory capabilities; (iii) relationships and
partnerships and (iv) quality and reliability, with these criteria prioritized above price or value-added
services.

The Hygiene market field is a global active-heavy leader, with approximately 700 customers. For the years
ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, it generated CHF161 million, CHF170 million and
CHF265 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

142


-----

_Home and Personal Care market field_

This market field focuses on chemical solutions for home care (preservation of customers formulated
products, such as shampoos, face creams and washing detergents), the beauty industry (hair care, including
anti-dandruff agents, and skin care) and food emulsifier ingredients. Within home care, our focus is on
ensuring that homes remain healthy places, by providing new and innovative solutions to keep consumer
products free of bacterial and mold growth. Our R&D programs focus on product and technology
innovations, such as low temperature laundry applications and methylisothiazolinon-free product
preservation systems, aligned with industry-leading regulatory and toxicology expertise, which allows us to
offer convenient and effective solutions to the many microbial challenges people face in their homes. In
addition, this business is a leading producer of dandruff-fighting ingredients. With custom-developed
biological fermentation and technologies perfected for pharmaceutical companies, the personal care team
continues to deliver premium-positioned bio-active functionals, which we believe enhances the consumer
experience and uniquely improves the performance of finished products targeting leave-on skin and scalp
care.

This market field further strengthens our position with well-established and next generation preservation
systems, as well as functional ingredients, across all personal care formulations.

The Home and Personal Care market field is a leader in the anti-dandruff business and serves
approximately 900 customers. For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, it generated
CHF245 million, CHF234 million and CHF238 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

_Wood Protection market field_

The Wood Protection market field delivers solutions to protect and enhance wood with innovative
technologies so that its life is improved and its uses are expanded. Its key products include pressure
treatment solutions for residential, commercial and agricultural use, industrial treatment for heavy duty
applications and a variety of wood specialties, such as solutions for flooring, furniture and cabinetry.

It produces high-quality formulated products that protect wood from mold, insects, fungal decay and fire
to help make the most of wood as a sustainable and adaptable construction material. The business’s proven
preservative technologies extend the service life of lumber, ensuring it can be used as a high-performance
material. Sapstain (also known as ‘‘blue stain’’) and mold control treatments keep lumber clean all the way
from the sawmill to consumers’ doors. Our heavy-duty industrial offerings protect wood in the harshest
environments, including utility, railway, marine and agricultural applications. Our market-leading
formulations for glue line protection of strand and veneer-based engineered wood products secure the
future of wood against alternative materials.

The Wood Protection market field is a leader in wood protection solutions, serving approximately 1,100
customers. For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, it generated CHF320 million,
CHF316 million and CHF313 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

_Paints and Coatings market field_

The Paints and Coatings market field provides solutions that protect coated surfaces from algae, fungi or
fouling or preserve products in storage. It is a global leader in the industry, which includes providing wet
state preservation for waterborne architectural paint and other formulations in the building and
construction market space. Additionally, it plays a critical role in the protection of marine vessels from
fouling and offers best in class technology for paint dry film protection against defacement from algae and
fungi.

The market field is an innovation leader providing effective solutions that are focused on microbial control
versus just biocides. Innovation efforts include offering slow release technologies and an increasing focus
on using inert raw materials to provide efficacy in coating systems.

The Paints and Coatings market field is an active-heavy leader in its segment, serving approximately 700
customers. For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, it generated CHF126 million,
CHF136 million and CHF119 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

143


-----

_Material Protection market field_

The Material Protection market field produces specialty biocides and chemical additives to protect various
materials and increase end product efficiency. Its solutions include anti-microbials, corrosion inhibitors,
lubricants and a variety of other specialty additives.

The Material Protection market field is focused on solutions for the plastics, metals and oil and gas niche
markets and serves approximately 600 customers. For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020,
it generated CHF129 million, CHF131 million and CHF99 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

_Crop Protection market field_

The Crop Protection market field provides solutions to protect premium fruit, vegetables and nuts. It
offers customers a range of agro-chemistry and formulations for global agricultural markets. For example,
it occupies a leading position in the supply of metaldehyde, the active of choice for controlling snails and
slugs. Geographically, the market field focuses on New Zealand, where it is a market leader, and we plan
to expand the successful local Zelam crop protection business into other regions in the future while
focusing on fruits, nuts and vegetables applications. Developed in collaboration with our distribution
partners in different regions, we have an ever-increasing range of products to help farmers maximize the
effectiveness of their crop protection products. We offer crop-protecting fungicides, insecticides,
herbicides, foliar nutrients and additives. To provide full support to the farming community, we also offer
molluscicide to include Axcela pellets, a ready-formulated product for use in a wide range of crops and
offer post-harvest sanitation solutions, such as Frexus.

The Crop Protection market field serves approximately 300 customers. For the years ended December 31,
2018, 2019 and 2020, it generated CHF56 million, CHF43 million and CHF35 million, respectively, of sales
to third parties.

**_Specialty Chemical Services business unit_**

Our Specialty Chemical Services business unit offers solutions for composite materials and resin
components and resin systems as well as for technically demanding industries, such as electronics,
transportation and industrials. It also supplies vitamins, vitamin and pharmaceutical intermediates,
provides custom development and manufacturing services and manufactures key performance
intermediates and chemicals for many industrial applications (such as building blocks, agro intermediates,
food and feed ingredients, cosmetic actives, inks and battery materials all based on ISO regulated
production). Some of the business unit’s output is utilized for the internal needs of our Microbial Control

_PIC market field_

The PIC market field is a trusted supplier of key raw materials and intermediaries for a variety of
industries. Its key offerings include performance intermediates, vitamin B3, PMDA and hydrazine, as well
as integrated services tailored to a single customer. The market field is a partner of choice for our

144


-----

customers, ensuring security of supply with the highest quality in specialty chemicals. We are committed to
the highest environmental, health and safety standards on our state-of-the-art sites in Visp, Nanjing, Lake
Charles and Kouˇrim. Our Cracker Core in Visp is the backbone of a comprehensive, fully backward
integrated chemical network and is the smallest in the world (approximately 20-40 times smaller than
world scale steam crackers). Originating from this enabling technology, we offer a variety of performance
chemicals based on special technologies like HCN, Acetylene-, Ethylene- and Ketene/Diketene- chemistry.

The PIC market field serves approximately 590 customers. For the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019
and 2018, the PIC market field generated CHF403 million, CHF429 million and CHF485 million,
respectively, of sales to third parties.

_Composite Materials market field_

The Composite Materials market field is a leading provider of tailor-made composite solutions for
manufacturers of cyanate ester resins. It develops resin components and resin systems for high
temperature resistant applications in electronics (such as telecommunications infrastructure),
transportation (including aerospace and automotive) and other industries (such as for coating and cast
parts).

The Composite Materials market field serves approximately 450 customers. For the years ended
December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, the Composite Materials market field generated CHF71 million,
CHF89 million and CHF94 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

_CDMO market field_

The CDMO market field is a trusted CDMO partner for the chemical and biotechnological industries as
production partner to outsource various tasks. Our chemical CDMO capabilities are located in Visp, while
our biotech capabilities are based in Kouˇrim. The business has a strong footprint in the realization of
multi-step synthesis of highly complex molecules for modern products. We focus on serving the outsourcing
needs of customers developing personal care products and cosmetic actives, human nutrition products,
flavors and fragrances, agrochemicals, nutraceuticals, inks and battery materials. In particular, the
nutritional benefit from our biotechnical custom development and manufacturing capabilities at our
cutting-edge fermentation plant in Kouˇrim. Our products and services offered to the agricultural markets
derive from our strong focus on customer needs with a high level of expertise in chemical and biological
technology. We support our customers in the production of modern herbicides, fungicides and insecticides,
including biologically derived products, such as biopesticides. We can also offer full life-cycle management
for customers’ products. We have recently focused more on industrial applications where we can either
support start-ups in the growth phase or larger industrial partners who benefit from our feedstock and
backward integration for attractive niche products.

The CDMO market field serves a growing customer base of approximately 20 customers. For the years
ended December 31, 2020, 2019 and 2018, the CDMO market field generated CHF119 million,
CHF143 million and CHF138 million, respectively, of sales to third parties.

The Visp site is our key technology base and the backbone of a multitude of our operations across both
business units (but mostly for our Specialty Chemical Services business unit). The Visp land is leased by the
Lonza Group and the Visp buildings are owned by LSI. It is located in Canton Valais, Switzerland. As at
December 31, 2020, it had 824 full-time employees and a well invested asset base benefiting from an
aggregate capital expenditure of CHF135 million in the period from January 1, 2018 until December 31,
2020. The Visp site holds ISO9001:2015, AS9100, FSSC 22000, FAMI QS, EFfCI GMP and ISO29990
certifications.

The Visp site is centered around three integrated network clusters: Cracker Core, HCN and Ketene/
Diketene, each of which can also be run independently. The Cracker Core is the smallest in the world
(approximately 20-40 times smaller than world scale steam crackers). It is dependent on the availability
of LPG and LVN. The Cracker Core satisfies the highest environmental and safety standards and is
characterized by a high degree of automation. The enabling technology of our Cracker Core allows us to
offer a variety of performance chemicals based on special technologies, like HCN, Acetylene- and
Ethylene- chemistry.

Our operations at the Visp site include five highly flexible multi-purpose plants for custom manufacturing
of specialty chemicals for various applications, including products for our Microbial Control Solutions
business unit, and two multi-product chemical plants mainly serving the Composite Materials market field
of our Specialty Chemical Services operating business unit, as well as Lonza Group with various
intermediates, custom synthesis and base chemicals.

Following the Acquisition, we expect that certain Lonza facilities will remain adjacent to our Visp site. See
‘‘—Material Agreements—Post-Acquisition Arrangements with Lonza—Site Services Agreements.’’ In addition,
certain facilities of one of our key clients are also adjacent to the site. See ‘‘Sales and Marketing-Customer
_Base.’’ Shipments to EU countries from our Visp site are made primarily by rail, with a small portion of_
truck shipments. Overseas shipments from our Visp site are made in full container loads in tank- and
box-containers and taken by train to port.

Our Mapleton site is located on approximately 390,000 m[2] in Illinois, United States. As at December 31,
2020, it had 79 full-time employees and a well invested asset base benefiting from an aggregate capital
expenditure of CHF22 million in the period from January 1, 2018 until December 31, 2020. The Mapleton
site exclusively serves our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and specializes in the production of
quats (antimicrobial actives), amines and amine oxides. The plant is ISO9001 and EFFFCI certified and
operates 24/7, producing approximately 82,000 tons of product annually in batch reactors ranging in size
from 2,000 to 12,000 gallons. The processing vessels are constructed of stainless steel, glass-lined carbon
steel, Inconel, as well as other materials. The facility has its own emergency response team and is
supported by on-site maintenance and engineering, QA/QC and process optimization teams. Shipping both
domestically and internationally, products are packaged and shipped by less-than-truckload shipping, full
container load shipping, intermodal shipping, tank trucks, and rail car. The main markets served by our
Mapleton site are Hygiene, Material Protection, Home and Personal Care, and Wood Protection.

_Williamsport_

Our Williamsport site is located on approximately 202,000 m[2] in Pennsylvania, United States. As at
December 31, 2020, it had 148 full-time employees and a well invested asset base benefiting from an
aggregate capital expenditure of CHF17 million in the period from January 1, 2018 until December 31,
2020. The Williamsport site exclusively serves our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and specializes
in the production of hydantoins, oleochemicals and ethylene oxide derivatives. The Williamsport site is
located close to our customer base and has excellent interstate and rail access. Shipping both domestically
as well as internationally, our Williamsport site produces approximately 45,000 tons of product annually
primarily for the Material Protection, Home and Personal Care, and Hygiene market fields. The site holds
ISO9001, EFFFCI, Kosher, Halal, FSSC 22000, and other certifications. Supporting the plant are on-site
QA/QC, process technology, maintenance and engineering, as well as warehousing and logistics
departments. In addition to the primary production facility, we operate a pilot plant on site at Williamsport
that is used for process optimization, scale up, and other development activities.

As at December 31, 2020, it had 114 full-time employees and a well invested asset base benefiting from an
aggregate capital expenditure of CHF11 million in the period from January 1, 2018 until December 31,
2020. The Conley site exclusively serves our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and specializes in
the production of micronized copper azole and CCA for wood protection applications. The wood
treatment plant produces approximately 59,000 tons of products annually and ships them primarily to the
Southeast and Mid-West regions of the US using LTL and bulk containers. To better serve the customers in

2020. The Rochester site exclusively serves our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and specializes in
the production of NaPT/ZnPT, personal care products and isothiazolinones. The site operates [24]⁄7 and is

process optimization teams. In addition to serving the Home and Personal Care market field, the
Rochester site manufactures industrial microbial control products for the Paints and Coatings, Material

_Nanjing_

Our Nanjing site is located in the Jiangsu province of the People’s Republic of China. The Nanjing site
land and building are owned by LSI. As at December 31, 2020, it had 92 full-time employees. The Nanjing
site serves our Microbial Control Solutions business unit and our Specialty Chemical Services business
unit. It specializes in the production of PMDA, industrial biocides and CuOM Paste and ZnOM Paste. The
Nanjing site holds ISO9001:2015 certification.

The Nanjing site is part of the Nanjing Chemical Industry Park, which is a national-level petrochemical
project in China established in 2001. Our presence on the site itself was established in 2007. As at the date
of this offering memorandum, the site occupies 90,594 m[2] and consists of two main plants: the PMDA
plant and the formulation plant:

- The PMDA plant has (i) two oxidation reactors (hot-spot temperatures of approximately 400�C);
(ii) two gas coolers; (iii) six de-sublimators; and (iv) one waste gas reactor (hot-spot temperatures of
approximately 400�C). It is characterized by advanced production equipment and process control
systems, robust manufacturing process, dedicated production system for PMDA and high quality
product to satisfy customer demands.

- The formulation plant’s main products include (a) industrial biocides (Proxel� range) and
(b) biocides for marine paints (CuOM Paste and ZnOM Paste). It is a multifunction factory with quick
change over and what we believe to be good waste handling practices. Key equipment includes: an
Emerson Delta V system and a total of seven reactors with sizes of two, five, ten and 20 m[3]. For
formulation product manufacturing, the plant uses process temperatures in excess of 100�C and
normal pressure.

_Kouˇrim_

Our Kouˇrim site is located in Central Bohemian Region of the Czech Republic. The Kouˇrim land and
building are owned by LSI. As at December 31, 2020, it had 223 full-time employees. The Kouˇrim site
serves our Microbial Control Solutions and Specialty Chemical Services business units and is the site of our
biotech CDMO run by the Specialty Chemical Services business unit. It specializes in biotech
manufacturing, as well as fermentation development and services. It also performs certain tolling
operations (Carniking) for Lonza Group. The Kouˇrim site holds ISO9001:2015, FAMI QS, FSSC 22000,
Halal and kosher certifications.

The Kouˇrim site occupies approximately 75,000 m[2] and has the following key production lines:

- L1 and L2 lines with 5x50 m[3]. These include two upstream lines with pre-seed, seed fermenters and
main fermenters, as well as two downstream lines.

- KUP15 line with 2x15 m[3]. The upstream line has one 300 L seed fermenter and two 15 m[3] production
fermenters. The downstream line has all required equipment, including a disc stack centrifuge.

- Pilot reactor with 1.5 m[3]. The pilot reactor is built in a modular way in order to allow the broadest
variety of variety of upstream and downstream processing, which enables the development process fit
to later plant design.

There is also a premix facility and a spray dryer plant (with two spray dryers of 100 kg/h and 500 kg/h) on

customers with a license to operate, which enables them to penetrate markets with minimal delay. For
example, we recently supported a major customer with registered formulations for Hygiene. We also have a

_Efficient Procurement_

We seek to enable a competitive cost base, flexibility and supply security for both our business units.
Factors we prioritize to ensure efficient procurement include the separation of strategic and operational
procurement; category management for streamlined sourcing process and optimized spend; local presence
at manufacturing sites and central strategic procurement organizations at regional and global levels;
actively managed interfaces and integrated business processes with product management and pricing; and
risk management by key raw materials and sales / margins impact analysis, given the lack of concentration
in raw materials.

We focus on a continuous and timely supply, with a purchased goods portfolio at optimized cost. Our
on-site procurement ensures fast reaction time and high flexibility for manufacturing and our integrated
procurement processes enable optimized inventory management. We manage volatility of key raw
materials and interface with product pricing at our market fields.

_Dedicated Supply Chain Organization_

We have a dedicated supply chain organization that was entirely reorganized during the Carve-out. The
current structure has been set up with continuous improvement in mind and a particular focus on
complexity reduction, inventory management and customer service. It integrates suppliers and contract
manufacturing partners into our global operations network and separates strategically important global
activities from more operational regional tasks, allowing for efficient processes and enabling further
improvement on key performance metrics.

As at the date of this offering memorandum, this new organization employed approximately 250 full-time
specialists to foster operational excellence in our global supply network. We have a three-fold strategy to
further improve our supply chain: (1) improvement of services, (2) reduction of inventory and
(3) reduction of complexity. Improvement of services involves on time in full delivery, order entry accuracy
and back order management. Reduction of inventory involves reversal of the trend of inventory growth and
the improvement of our inventory management processes. We plan to reduce complexity by reducing
network complexity, product complexity and end market complexity.

We have implemented a Supplier Code of Conduct based on the Principles of the United Nations Global
Compact as well as the Pharmaceutical Industry Principles for Responsible Supply Chain Management.
This code of conduct covers issues including: fair competition and ethics; labor rights; health and safety
and environmental impact. We expect our suppliers to have internal measuring procedures to guarantee
adherence to this code of conduct and to report violations to us. We have integrated this code of conduct
into our contracts and reserve the right to request corrective actions or to terminate contracts if suppliers
do not follow the code of conduct.

_Our Culture_

We believe that our culture is a key differentiating factor on all our markets. We identify the following four
key values of such culture:

- **_Performance. In everything we do, we strive to create real value. In order to achieve that, we (a) say_**
what we do and do what we say; (b) make things better, challenging the way they are done; (c) own
our tasks; (d) make things happen, remaining flexible to seize opportunities; and (e) stick with it and
see things through.

- **_Collaboration. We work and think across boundaries to create solutions that make a difference. In_**
order to achieve that, we (a) work for the greater good, combining our talents to achieve extraordinary
results; (b) seek input, value diverse perspectives, listen and embrace different ideas as if our own;
(c) share workload and credit; (d) trust each other’s motives, experiences and expertise; and
(e) welcome and embrace feedback, communicating openly and directly with others.

- **_Passion. We act with courage on our conviction to make a meaningful impact in the world. In order to_**
achieve that, we (a) take the problems that need solving; (b) ask ‘‘What if?’’ and have the courage to
pursue it; (c) embrace failure as ‘‘success not yet’’, adjust and move fast; (d) are optimistic about our
future and have fun pursuing it together; and (e) celebrate each other and take great pride in our
work.

- **_Care. We believe what we do matters. Therefore, we (a) define our success in terms of impact we have_**
on our team, customers, business, society and environment; (b) go beyond what is required, taking
personal responsibility for safety and quality; (c) treat others as we wish to be treated and care about
their wellbeing; (d) make time to help each other; and (e) assume the best in others, challenging the
idea, not the person.

We continuously invest in our employees and in training and development programs. Additionally, our
business is guided by our code of conduct, which covers a broad range of issues, including: trade sanctions
and export controls; product quality; environment, health and safety; anti-discrimination and equal
employment opportunities; conflicts of interests; anti-corruption and anti-bribery; business gifts; insider
trading; fair competition; use and protection of business assets and confidential information; intellectual
property; accuracy of records; business partnerships; data privacy; data integrity and social media. This is
implemented through an ethics and compliance program designed to support legal and ethical actions
throughout the LSI Business and includes annual education and training for all employees.

_Pension Plans and Retirement_

_Defined-Benefit Pension Plans_

We operate defined-benefit and defined contribution pension plans as well as other employee benefit plans
in various countries. Our major defined benefit plans are in Switzerland, the United Kingdom and the
United States. For pension accounting purposes, these plans are considered defined-benefit plans.

_Pension Plan in Switzerland_

Our Swiss pension plan is governed by the Swiss Federal Law on Occupational Retirement, Survivors and
Disability Pension Plans (BVG), and is funded through a legally separate trustee-administered pension
fund (Pensionskasse der Lonza). The board of trustees is responsible for the investment of the assets, which
cannot revert to the LSI Business. The cash funding of these plans, which may from time to time involve
special payments, is designed to ensure that present and future contributions are sufficient to meet future
liabilities. The plan contains a cash balance benefit formula, accounted for as a defined-benefit plan
according to IAS19. Employer and employee contributions are defined in the pension fund rules in terms
of an age-related sliding scale of percentages of pay. Under Swiss law, the pension plan guarantees the
vested benefit amount as confirmed annually to members. Interest may be added to member balances at
the discretion of the board of trustees.

The risks linked to retirement benefits, including disability and death, have been reinsured until
December 31, 2021, following which we expect to extend such reinsurance. The investment risk is not
reinsured. Our insurance provider guarantees these retirement benefits and bears the investment, death
and disability risks. Retirement benefits are based on accumulated retirement capital (made up of yearly
contributions and the interest thereon), which can either be drawn as a life-long annuity or as a lump-sum
payment or a combination of the two. The board of trustees may adjust the annuity at its discretion subject
to the plan’s funded status including sufficient free funds as determined according to Swiss statutory
valuation rules.

Prior to 2020, our pension plan was sponsored only by Lonza Group without defined benefit liability
allocated to the LSI Business. In 2020, our employees in Switzerland were transferred to a separate legal
entity from Lonza Group, but continue to participate in the same pension plan as Lonza Group’s Swiss
employees. We concluded a specific affiliation agreement in accordance with Swiss law and consequently a
portion of the Swiss pension plan’s liability is now allocated to the LSI Business.

_Pension Plan in the United Kingdom_

We operate the Hickson UK Group Pension Scheme, which is closed to new entrants. In addition, the
scheme is registered under UK legislation, is contracted out of the State Second Pension and is subject to
the scheme funding requirements outlined in UK legislation. The plan is managed by corporate trustee
bodies, which oversee investment strategy and general regulatory compliance. Hickson UK Group Pension
Scheme is the defined-benefit pension plan of the legacy UK Arch Chemicals business. Pensions are linked
to final salaries and service, and statutory increases apply, except where contractually different.

_Pension Plans in the United States_

We currently sponsor three qualified defined-benefit pension plans in the United States. All of the
defined-benefit pension plans are fully frozen with respect to future benefit accruals (with the exception of
a small group of participants). All eligible U.S. employees currently participate in a defined-contribution
retirement plan. Pension benefits for the majority of U.S. pension plan participants are generally based on
final average pay and credited service as of the date of termination or as of the date benefit accruals were
frozen (if earlier), and are payable as a lifetime pension. Participants in the cash balance formula under the
Pension Plan of Arch Chemicals are covered under an account-based formula that is credited each year

159


-----

with interest based on the yield on ten-year U.S. Treasury securities. Participants in these plans may
commence benefit payments upon attainment of normal retirement age or, if applicable, as of an early
retirement age (usually age 55) provided the criteria for early retirement have been met as of the
participant’s termination of employment. Participants in the cash balance plan may elect to commence
benefits upon termination of employment either in a single lump sum or as a lifetime annuity, or they may
defer payment to a later date.

Pension benefit payments from the qualified pension plans are paid from a trustee-administered fund. The
qualified defined-benefit pension plans, whose assets are held in a master trust, are subject to minimum
funding requirements and are subject to further regulations under the U.S. Internal Revenue Code and the
U.S. Employees Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA). Actuarial valuations are completed
each year for each plan to determine the contribution requirement. The plan sponsor may elect to
contribute more than the minimum, in which case the excess amounts may under certain circumstances be
used to offset future funding requirements.

**Sustainability; Environment, Health and Safety**

We are dedicated to providing the highest quality products and services to our customers, while minimizing
our impact on the environment, striving for energy and resource efficiency and helping to improve life
quality.

As part of this commitment, we foster transparency and reporting in line with the Global Reporting
Initiative (GRI) Standards, which represent the industry standard for reporting on economic,
environmental and social indicators.

For the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, our aggregate operational expenses on EHS
concerns amounted to CHF9 million, CHF11 million and CHF15 million, respectively, while our capital
expenditures on EHS amounted to CHF20 million, CHF30 million and CHF31 million, respectively.

_Commitment to Sustainability_

Sustainability is a key consideration for us and we expect it to be an integral part of our strategy moving
forward. We are dedicated to providing the highest quality products and services to our customers, while
minimizing our impact on the environment, striving for energy- and resource-efficiency and helping to
improve quality of life.

As a part of our overarching commitment to sustainability, we are embedding material sustainability
performance indicators as we transition to operating as a standalone business. Long-term environmental
and social changes as well as changing customer preferences are having a significant impact on the
specialty chemicals industry. We recognize the resource-intensive nature of our operations and that
sustainability is a high priority for governments and our customers. By defining sustainability targets early
on in our establishment as a standalone entity, we are communicating our commitment to reducing
environmental impact to our stakeholders.

The five key pillars of our commitment to sustainability are as follows:

- **_Compliance and integrity. Regulatory compliance, integrity and ethical conduct are the foundations in_**
every place we operate.

- **_Vision ZERO. Continuous improvements to our systems and aspiration to achieve ZERO incidents,_**
injuries or emissions.

- **_Our people. We strive to enable employee development. We provide our workforce with safe_**
workplaces, care for employees’ wellbeing and foster involvement and participation.

- **_Our environment. We seek to improve our environmental footprint by continually reducing energy,_**
water and material demand per unit.

- **_Value for society. Value creation through innovative solutions, developing the consumer products of_**
tomorrow. Community engagement where we operate.

160

_Sustainability KPIs_

As part of our commitment to becoming a low-carbon chemicals company, we intend to adopt key
performance indicators (‘‘KPIs’’) to track (i) our greenhouse gas (‘‘GHG’’) emissions and (ii) waste
intensity.

_(i) GHG emissions_

Our GHG emissions result mainly from combustion processes for energy generation, including
incineration of organic waste, and chemically generated CO2. We can manage part of our GHG emissions
by managing our energy consumption and energy sources. To decouple GHG emissions from energy
consumption, we strive to increase the percentage of renewable electricity that we use in our energy
consumption.

We intend to measure our GHG emissions intensity through a KPI measuring direct and indirect emissions
in terms of tons of CO2 equivalents based on total sales (CO2 equivalent tons divided by millions of Swiss
francs in sales). We intend to reduce our GHG emissions intensity by 3% or more per year, and we target a
GHG emissions intensity reduction of 18% or more by 2024 and 36% by 2030, compared to our 2018
baseline of 484 of CO2 equivalent tons per million of Swiss francs in total sales.

_(ii) Waste intensity_

Our chemical manufacturing processes generate hazardous and non-hazardous solid wastes as by-products,
which must be treated and disposed of according to the relevant applicable regulations. We strive to
remain transparent with stakeholders and local communities on our waste management policies and
practices and are committed to increasing input materials efficiency in our production processes, including
reworking out-of-specification production, to reduce waste generation from production, offices and
laboratories. Each of our manufacturing sites maintains a waste disposal operation tailored to its waste
streams for an efficient, environmentally sound treatment and disposal of waste outputs. All of our sites
are committed to our waste reduction principles: ‘‘avoid, reduce, recycle, treat, and dispose.’’

We intend to measure our waste intensity through a KPI measuring waste generated in tons based on total
sales (tons of waste generated divided by millions of Swiss francs in sales). We intend to reduce our waste
intensity by 2% per year, and we target a reduction in waste intensity of 12% by 2024 and 24% by 2030,
compared to our 2018 baseline of 49.5 tons of waste per million of Swiss francs in total sales.

_A Systematic Approach to Sustainability and EHS_

Our approach to sustainability is systematic. We have policies in place to define high-level principles and
an operating model for EHS management and process safety teams working closely with the sites. Our
EHS guidelines include Health Surveillance, Critical Work and EHS. We manage systems and policies on
incident tracking. We have provided for minimum standards to ensure safety of personnel. In addition, we
have plans in place for security and business continuity of each site, as well as construction site policies,
including contractor requirements.

We have a comprehensive set of methodologies, training programs and processes. These include
comprehensive risk assessment methodology and training, global training on causal analysis methodology
for safety incidents and annual safety and sustainability planning, as well as three-year roadmaps for each
manufacturing site.

Our approach to safety is underpinned by the values guiding individual behavior and decision making of
our employees. Each employee is accountable and responsible for labor practices and safe working
conditions.

_Vision ZERO Initiative_

Our Vision ZERO initiative was launched in 2015, focusing on safety and sustainability of operations. Our
aspiration is to achieve zero workplace injuries or illnesses, manufacturing process, environmental and
transportation incidents. We have programs developed for each individual site.

_Other Recent Initiatives_

- **_Recycling and Reutilization of Solvents in Visp. In 2020, we reused 20,000 tons of organic solvents_**
(approximately 40% of total amount used), with all other solvents used as fuel to generate steam and
electricity.

- **_Reduction of Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Visp. We have invested and plan to continue to invest in a_**
catalytic converter at a continuously running plant at our Visp site to reduce our nitrous oxide
emissions at that plant by 98% per annum by the end of 2021. We expect this investment to total
approximately CHF12 million between 2019 and 2022, with CHF6 million of this investment
conducted in the year ended December 31, 2020.

Our EHS function performs regular audits of all our production sites to identify EHS vulnerabilities and
recommend remedial actions. As a result of our sustainability and EHS policies and initiatives, 16 of our 18
manufacturing sites have gone without a lost time injury for more than one year.

**_Visp site_**

Following the Acquisition Closing Date, Lonza Group will remain fully responsible for all ongoing soil,
sub-soil and groundwater remediation initiatives at the jointly used Visp site. These include (i) the ongoing
remediation to address legacy mercury contamination and (ii) the landfill at Gamsenried, which require
remediation of various amines and solvents that may result in groundwater contamination.

**_Rochester site_**

In order to address EHS vulnerabilities identified at our Rochester site, we are installing a groundwater
pump and treatment system beneath the operating site to reduce concentrations of 2-chloropyridine in
wastewater by more than 80%. The aggregate cost of this initiative is currently expected to be
approximately US$830,000.

service desk. In addition, there are two key third-party providers for network services (WAN) to cover all

along with our third-party service providers. We also have local IT teams present at key sites to manage the
services on-site with close business proximity.

Lonza Group currently provides access to such joint IT services under the Global Services Agreements
(see ‘‘—Material Agreements—Post-Acquisition Arrangements with Lonza—Global Services Agreements’’).
We expect to achieve physical separation in selected areas, such as finance (consolidation, tax and
treasury), by the Acquisition Closing Date with remaining separation phases to occur during the life of the
relevant Global Services Agreements. However, we already have a dedicated IT team set up to manage the
IT aspects of the Carve-out, to define stand-alone IT infrastructure and systems and devise a stand-alone
IT strategy for us, as well as manage our business requirements from the IT perspective. In addition, we
have an IT application services organization that has been already separated into two parts, each covering
one of our operating divisions.

Following complete separation of our IT infrastructure and systems from those of Lonza Group, we aim to
radically simplify and harmonize them in line with best industry standards and practices to provide a
modern and secure IT landscape and infrastructure with a high degree of automation capabilities and
pragmatic delivery of IT services. In the stand-alone setup we strive for governing and managing the IT
project portfolio in alignment with the business needs and with focus on core projects delivering most
benefits and highest savings.

With regards to cyber security, our IT security team focuses on identifying and mitigating business risks by
providing around-the-clock active monitoring services on the basis of a risk-based vulnerability
management, emphasizing areas such as identity management, assets, network, organization and external
threat environment.
