**REGULATION**

_As a chemical manufacturer, our activities and the sale of our products are subject to numerous regulations,_
_including those described briefly and non-exhaustively below. Prospective investors and/or their advisers should_
_make their own full analysis of the legislation and regulations which apply in all countries where we operate and_
_of the impact they may have on an investment in the Notes and should not rely exclusively on the content of the_
_following paragraphs._

**Overview**

Our business is highly regulated in all of the jurisdictions in which we operate. Our production facilities
and operations are subject to both national and international regulatory regimes. In the Member States
and the UK, the regulatory environment of our business activities is shaped by EU directives and
regulations, which are either implemented through national legislation or, in the case of Member States,
have direct application to the states or individuals. In the United States, the regulatory environment is
shaped by federal and state laws and regulations. Regulations that affect our operations mostly relate to
areas of environmental protection, product safety and quality, occupational health and safety, industrial
hygiene and plant safety.

EHS laws and regulations govern our facilities and our operations, including: (i) the storage, handling,
treatment and disposal of hazardous substances and waste; (ii) water intake and sewage discharges; (iii) air
emissions (including greenhouse gas (‘‘GHG’’) emissions); (iv) human health and safety; (v) the clean-up
and remediation of contaminated sites; and (vi) the sale and use of the products we manufacture. Many of
our operations require permits and controls to monitor or prevent pollution. We have incurred, and will
continue to incur, on-going capital and operating expenditures to ensure compliance with current and
future EHS laws and regulations, which tend to become more stringent over time, including more stringent
enforcement of these laws and regulations. Our EHS management systems are intended to ensure that we
both comply with applicable EHS requirements and minimize EHS risk by promoting EHS protection
activities and initiatives. We actively address legal compliance issues in connection with our operations and
properties, and we believe that we have systems in place to ensure that EHS costs and liabilities will not
have a material adverse impact on us. Nevertheless, estimates of future EHS costs and liabilities are
inherently imprecise, and the imposition of new or unanticipated EHS costs or obligations could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

**EU and UK Regulations**

**Industry and Product Related Regulations**

_Chemicals Regulations—REACH and CLP_

The use, manufacture and importing of chemicals is regulated in the European Union through
Regulation 1907/2006 concerning REACH, which has been in force on June 1, 2007, and requires that
chemical substances or preparations manufactured, imported or otherwise placed within the European
Union in quantities exceeding one ton per year, be registered by manufacturers and importers with the
European Chemicals Agency (the ‘‘ECHA’’). REACH, as amended, imposes significant obligations on the
chemicals industry as a whole with respect to the testing, evaluation, assessment and registration of
building block and semi-specialty chemicals. Full registration requires the provision of comprehensive data
on the identification, properties, uses, classification and labeling of the relevant substance and exposure
scenarios.

Manufacturers and importers of substances in the European Union must obtain information on the
substances they manufacture or import to assess the risks arising from their use and to ensure that risks are
properly managed. For the use or sale of substances deemed particularly hazardous and specified in
Annex XIV of the REACH Regulation, an authorization will be required. The manufacture and placing on
the market of certain dangerous substances in the European Union is also restricted by REACH.

Following the end of the transition period for the UK’s withdrawal from the EU from January 1, 2021, the
EU REACH Regulation has been brought into UK law under the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018
(save for Northern Ireland, with the EU REACH regime continues to apply). REACH, and related
legislation, have been replicated in the UK with the necessary changes to make it operable in the UK with
the key principles of EU REACH retained. The new domestic regime is known as UK REACH. UK-based
companies can continue to rely on existing EU REACH registrations by completing the ‘grandfathering’

166


-----

process by providing basic information to the UK Health and Safety Executive by April 30, 2021. For cross
EU-UK trade of chemicals, registration requirements of each regime must be met.

REACH works in connection with the CLP Regulation (1272/2008/EC, as amended) to regulate and
standardize the classification, labeling and packaging of substances and mixtures in the EU, and imposes
obligations on manufacturers, importers, downstream users and distributors of certain substances,
depending on their role in this supply chain. CLP has also been brought into UK law under the European
Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (save for Northern Ireland, with the EU CLP Regulation applies).

_Biocides and cosmetics—BPR and Cosmetics Directive_

The BPR establishes a program to evaluate and authorize marketing of biocidal active substances and
products, which in some instances requires developing new safety data and compiling new and existing data
into dossiers to be assessed by the regulatory authorities. Manufacturers work alone and with industry
groups to manage these data requirements and meet relevant deadlines of the program by the submission
of dossiers for active substances. Registration costs, which are incurred through a multi-year period, can be
significant.

The BPR has been brought into UK law under the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018 (save for
Northern Ireland, with the EU BPR regime continues to apply), pursuant to the Chemicals (Health and
Safety) and Genetically Modified Organisms (Contained Use) (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit)
Regulations 2019, as amended in 2020. Existing biocidal product authorizations that were valid in the UK
under the EU BPR at the end of the transition period on 31 December 2020 will remain valid until their
normal expiry date, provided the authorization holder is established in the UK (including Northern
Ireland) by 1 January 2022. Safety data previously provided to the ECHA will need to be provided to the
UK regulator, the Health and Safety Executive, by 1 January 2023. For cross EU-UK trade of biocides, the
requirements of each regime must be met.

The Cosmetics Regulation (EC 1223/2009) regulates the manufacturer and placing on the market of
cosmetic products, imposing a range of compliance obligations, including the preparation of a product
safety report prior to placing a product on the market and notification of products via the EU Cosmetic
Products Notification Portal (‘‘CPNP’’). Lists of substances prohibited or restricted in cosmetic products
are maintained under the regime, as assessed by the EU Scientific Committee for Consumer Safety
(‘‘SCSS’’). Restrictions can be changed over time depending on the evidence available, and this can affect
the ability to manufacture and market certain substances. The Cosmetics Regulation applies to
antidandruff ingredients and claims, including the antidandruff ingredient zinc pyrithione (‘‘ZPT’’) which
we manufacture. The SCSS issued an opinion in March 2020 finding that ZPT is considered safe when
used at a concentration up to 1.0% as an antidandruff agent in rinse-off hair care products, however, the
EU has since notified a draft regulation to the World Trade Organization which seeks to characterize ZPT
a category 1B carcinogen, and proposes to prohibit for use in cosmetic products on the EU market from
March 2022. The proposal remains outstanding, but could prevent sales in the EU of products which
contain this ingredient which we manufacture.

Laws giving effect to the Cosmetics Regulation have been brought into UK law under the European Union
(Withdrawal) Act 2018 (save for Northern Ireland, where EU laws apply to products). The UK
government is not bound to follow the ban of ZPT but is entitled to do so.

_Plan protection products_

Our agricultural products are subject to laws regulating the manufacture, supply and the use of plant
protection products (‘‘PPP’’) in the EU, primarily Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 on the placing on the
market of plant protection products, alongside the CLP and related regulations on the sustainable use of
pesticides. The regime requires that an active substance (any chemical, plant extract or micro-organism
that acts against pests or on plants) in a PPP is approved by a competent national authority in an EU
country before it is placed on the market, and there is a mutual recognition regime enabling requests to
use approvals in other EU countries. Applicants are required to provide the necessary scientific
information to support an assessment as to whether the product has any harmful effects on human health,
including vulnerable groups, or any unacceptable effect on the environment. Authorities may attach
criteria and restrictions when approving a PPP. Approvals were first granted for a periods not exceeding
10 years, and require renewal.

167


-----

The EU PPP regime has been adopted into UK law pursuant to a series of instruments, including the
Pesticides and Fertilisers (Miscellaneous Amendments) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 and the Plant
Protective Products (Miscellaneous Amendments) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019, with certain transitional
provisions (and excluding Northern Ireland where the EU PPP regime still applies). The Health and Safety
Executive continues to be the UK’s national competent authority. Existing active substance approvals and
other authorizations will continue to be valid in the UK until their current expiry date though approvals
due to expire before December 2023 will be extended for three years. The mutual recognition regime no
longer allows UK approvals to be used as a basis for new EU country approvals under the EU PPP, and
vice versa.

**Environment, Health and Safety Regulations**

Our manufacturing sites in Europe and the UK are subject to significant regulation regarding the
operation of chemical plants. Regulation of environmental and health and safety issues is considerable,
including but not limited to waste prevention and control, fire safety, protection against explosive hazards,
storage, transport and use of hazardous substances, air emissions, wastewater management, environmental
liability, integrated permitting, noise and groundwater protection. There are a number of regimes which
impose requirements on operators to obtain permits and licenses for certain activities. EU Directives and
Regulations set common EU-wide standards of operation in several areas, that, in some cases, may be
made stricter by Member States’ authorities. Other areas of law, especially contaminated land regulations,
are largely a matter of domestic Member State law, with limited EU-wide harmonization, regarding permit
granting procedures or enforcement (by way of example, the Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU)).
Fines and penalties for non-compliance with environmental and health and safety issues vary across
Member States and the UK, but most impose a penalty in relation to such non-compliance.

Following the end of the transition period for the UK’s withdrawal from the EU from January 1, 2021,
environmental and health and safety laws (including those detailed below) were brought into UK law
under the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, with necessary changes to make them operable in the
UK with the key principles of EU law retained. These laws may be amended by the UK government in
coming years, and the regimes may diverge.

Examples of the key directives (which are implemented by national laws) and regimes applicable to our
businesses and facilities in Europe and the UK include, but are not limited to, the following:

_Industrial Emissions Directive_

The Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU, as amended) (the ‘‘IED’’), in force from January 6, 2011,
regulates a wide range of industrial installations which operate above certain thresholds in a variety of
industry sectors, including the chemicals industry. The IED’s aims are to prevent or reduce emissions from
industrial installations to air, land and water. It requires, among other things, that installations which fall
within its scope to operate under a permit and such permits are to be conditional on ‘‘BAT conclusions’’.
Best Available Techniques (‘‘BAT’’) conclusions are documents which set out what constitutes the BAT for
a particular activity, including emissions levels, monitoring and remediation. When an installation is closed
the IED also requires that permitting authorities must ensure that steps are taken to avoid any pollution
caused by the closure of the site and that measures are taken to return the site to a satisfactory state. The
IED provides, inter alia, that operators of sites which use hazardous substances prepare a baseline report
setting out information that will enable the state of contamination of soil and ground water at the site to be
compared when the site is closed.

_Safety and Health of Workers at Work Directive_

Directive 89/391/EEC, as amended, on measures to encourage improvements in the safety and health of
workers (the ‘‘HSW Directive’’) aims to eliminate the risk factors for occupational diseases and accidents
by establishing rules for protecting the health and safety of workers. It imposes duties on employers to
ensure the workers’ health and safety in every aspect of their work, including if they enlist external
companies or persons, based on a system of adaptable risk prevention and management, the provision of
information to workers, common protective measures and training, and the provision of the necessary
organization and means for the protection of workers.

168


-----

_Control of Major Accident Hazards Involving Dangerous Substances_

Directive 2012/18/EU, as amended, (and its predecessors) relating to the prevention and management of
incidents in relation to the use, manufacture and storage of hazardous substances (the ‘‘SEVESO III
**Directive’’) aims to prevent major accident hazards involving dangerous substances and to limit the**
consequences of any such accidents if they do occur. It applies to establishments in which certain quantities
of dangerous substances are present (stored, used or manufactured). Operators of such establishments are
required to take all necessary measures to prevent major accidents and limit their consequences on human
health and the environment, including in some cases establishing, obtaining approval for and testing safety
and emergency plans and policies.

_Fire Security and Explosion Hazard Rules_

Minimum requirements for improving the safety and health protection of workers potentially at risk from
explosive atmospheres are imposed by two Directives. Directive 2014/34/EU, as amended, applies to
equipment and protective systems intended for use in potentially explosive atmospheres (‘‘ATEX 114’’),
and Directive 1999/92/EC, as amended, applies to workplaces (‘‘ATEX 137’’).

_Carbon Dioxide Reduction and Emissions Trading Rules_

The EU ETS (Directive 2003/87/EC, as amended) establishes a scheme for GHG emission allowance
trading within the Community (the ‘‘EU ETS Directive’’). It covers many installations in the chemicals
sector, including as a result of operating large combustion installations (20MW or over) such as boiler
houses and generators, the releases of carbon dioxide from the production of bulk organic chemicals, and
releases of nitrous oxide from the production of nitric, adipic, glyoxal and glyoxylic acid. The EU ETS
Directive is split into phases, and we are currently in Phase IV. Operators of installations subject to the EU
ETS Directive are required to monitor all emissions of carbon dioxide from their installation and to
surrender, on an annual basis, allowances in an amount equal to their emissions at these installations.

Free allowances have been provided to operators in accordance with a methodology which decreases over
time, reducing to zero in 2027. In the event of a shortfall in allowances until 2027, and for all allowances
from 2027, we will have to purchase a sufficient number of allowances to make up the deficit. Allowances
have a market price which, at present, is regarded as being low. However, further proposed reforms to the
European carbon market are being contemplated with a view to reducing the supply of allowances.

The EU has set an overall environmental target to reduce GHG emissions by at least 40% by 2030 as part
of its contribution to the Paris Agreement. Current and future EU ETS phases are designed to help
achieve these targets. It is possible that the carbon price will increase over time and, consequently, the
costs of meeting any shortfall for complying with the EU ETS regime could materially increase. It is also
likely that laws which aim to reduce the European Union’s carbon footprint in the areas of energy
efficiency, carbon dioxide emissions allowances trading, renewable energy requirements and construction
requirements for the energy efficiency of buildings will be introduced and strengthened. Compliance with
current or future GHG regulations governing our operations, including those discussed above, may result
in significantly increased capital expenditures for measures such as capital expenditures to install more
environmentally efficient technology or the purchase of allowances to emit carbon dioxide or other GHG.

_Waste Framework Directives_

Our European business is subject to a wide range of waste laws. The Waste Framework Directive
(2008/98/EC, as amended) (the ‘‘WFD’’), as amended, aims to protect the environment and human health
through the prevention of the harmful effects of waste generation and management. It imposes
requirements for the treatment of waste in line with the waste hierarchy which prioritizes how waste should
be managed: prevention; preparing for reuse; recycling; other recovery, notably energy recovery; and
disposal. In accordance with the ‘‘polluter pays’’ principle, the costs of waste management are to be borne
by the original waste producer or by the current or previous waste holders. Any producer or holder of
waste is required to carry out its own waste treatment or have treatment carried out by another
establishment. Hazardous waste is prohibited from being mixed, requires appropriate labeling and
packaging, and also requires storage and treatment in conditions that ensure the protection of health and
the environment.

169

**U.S. Environmental Regulations**

The following is a summary of some of the various U.S. products and EHS regulations that we believe have
a material impact on our business:

**FIFRA**

In the United States, biocide products are regulated under FIFRA, as amended by the Food Quality
Protection Act of 1996, as ‘‘pesticides’’ or ‘‘antimicrobial pesticides.’’ FIFRA is the principal federal statute
governing the manufacture, labelling, handling and use of pesticides. The LSI Companies maintain several
hundred product registrations with the EPA. Registration requires compliance with certain efficacy,
toxicity and labelling requirements and the on-going payment of registration fees. Each state in which
these products are sold also requires registration and following maintenance of product life cycle with
payment of fees for initial registration, change of labelling and registration discontinuance. In general,
states impose substantively similar requirements to those required by FIFRA. However, California and
certain other states have adopted additional regulatory programs, and California impose a tax on total
pesticide sales in that state.

**Toxic Substances Control Act and Green Chemistry Initiatives**

The TSCA imposes requirements on persons and companies that manufacture, process, distribute, use or
dispose ‘‘chemical substances’’ as defined. Among other things, under TSCA the EPA has the authority to:
(i) require testing of chemicals; (ii) undertake pre-market review and impose restrictions upon new
chemicals; (iii) limit or prohibit the manufacture, use, distribution and disposal of chemical substances;
(iv) impose reporting and recordkeeping requirements; and (v) regulate the export and import of chemical
substances.

TSCA was updated in 2016 by the Frank R. Lautenberg Chemical Safety for the 21st Century Act, which
expanded the scope of the EPA’s regulation of existing and new chemical substances. These TSCA
amendments impact testing and analysis of risks, and EPA evaluation costs, for chemical substances in the
United States and provide the EPA with additional tools to manage chemicals of concern. TSCA requires
premarket approval prior to the manufacture in, or import to, the U.S. of new chemical substances.

The EPA may impose civil and criminal liability for TSCA violations.

In addition, numerous state and local governmental authorities and industry groups have implemented or
are considering so-called ‘‘green chemistry’’ or similar chemical-focused initiatives to identify, prioritize,
and restrict the use of existing hazardous chemicals with the goal of preventing pollution before it occurs.
These or other similar future changes to chemicals regulation and best practices in the U.S. could place
additional regulatory burdens on the industry.

**Clean Air Act**

The Clean Air Act (‘‘CAA’’) and its implementing regulations, as well as similar state laws and regulations
governing emissions of pollutants into the air, impose permitting and emission control requirements.
Standards promulgated pursuant to the CAA may require that we install controls at or make operational
changes to our facilities. If new controls or changes to operations are needed, the costs could be significant.
In addition, failure to comply with the requirements of the CAA and its implementing regulations could
result in substantial fines, civil or criminal penalties, or other sanctions.

The regulation of air emissions under the CAA requires that we obtain permits for the construction,
modification, and operation of our equipment, comply with permit requirements, and incur capital
expenditures for the installation of certain air pollution control devices at our facilities. Capital
expenditures may be required to maintain compliance with these and other air emission regulations in the
future.

**Climate Change and Greenhouse Gas Emissions Rules**

Regulation of GHGs in the United States is currently subject to complicated domestic and international
political, policy and economic dynamics.

Our operations result in emissions of GHGs, such as carbon dioxide, and our operations are energyintensive and require the purchase or electricity, the generation of which often results in emissions of
GHGs.

170


-----

Future regulation of GHGs in the United States could occur pursuant to future international treaty
obligations, regulatory changes under the CAA or other existing legislation, or federal, state or regional
adoption of GHG regulatory schemes. This could cause us to incur additional costs in complying with any
new regulations, which may adversely impact our operations and financial condition.

**Management of Hazardous Substances and Contamination**

The present-day generation, handling, and disposal of solid wastes, including certain regulated hazardous
waste, is regulated by the EPA and states pursuant to the federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act
(‘‘RCRA’’) and state-specific regulatory programs. These regulations cover the generation, storage,
transportation, and disposal of solid wastes. Persons may be held liable for cleanup at sites where the past
or present storage, handling, treatment, transport, or disposal of any solid or hazardous waste may present
an imminent and substantial endangerment to health or the environment and at sites where hazardous
waste treatment, storage or disposal operations are subject to permitting requirements and have resulted in
contamination.

Under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (‘‘CERCLA’’) and
analogous state laws, certain persons may be liable at sites where a release or threatened release of
‘‘hazardous substances’’ (including regulated hazardous waste and also other categories of substances and
wastes, but not including petroleum) has occurred or is threatened. These persons can include the current
owner or operator of property where a release or threatened release occurred, any persons who owned or
operated the property when disposal occurred, and any persons who disposed of, or arranged for the
transportation or disposal of, hazardous substances at a contaminated property.

Liability for petroleum contamination, such as contamination from leaking petroleum underground tanks,
is primarily governed state law. Liable parties typically include the property owner and/or operator, and
any other parties in control of the petroleum at the time of the release or discharge.

We are liable for and have related environmental reserves for contamination at certain U.S. sites under
RCRA, CERCLA, similar state laws, and under state petroleum liability schemes, and we could have
additional liability at these contaminated sites and perhaps others in the future.

**Process Safety and Prevention of Major Accidents**

We are subject to OSHA and similar state laws that regulate the protection of the health and safety of
employees. In addition, OSHA’s hazard communication standard, the Emergency Planning and
Community Right to Know Act (‘‘EPCRA’’) and implementing regulations and similar state statutes and
regulations require that information be maintained about hazardous materials used or produced in our
operations and that this information be provided to employees, state and local government authorities and
citizens.

Certain manufacturing facilities are also subject to the EPA’s CAA Risk Management Program (‘‘RMP’’),
which requires facilities that produce, handle, process, distribute or store certain highly hazardous
chemicals to develop a risk management plan and program in the event of an accidental release of such
chemicals.

**Clean Water Act**

The Federal Water Pollution Control Act Amendments of 1972 and subsequent amendments, commonly
referred to as the Clean Water Act (‘‘CWA’’), and comparable state laws impose restrictions and strict
controls regarding the discharge of pollutants into federal and state waters. The discharge of pollutants
into regulated waters is prohibited, except in accordance with the terms of a CWA permit. The CWA also
requires many facilities to develop and maintain plans for preventing and responding to spills of pollutants
(including oil), called Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure Plans, and certain higher-risk facilities
that store and handle pollutants are required to prepare and maintain a more extensive plan called a
Facility Response Plan. Breaches of the CWA can result in administrative, civil or criminal sanctions.

**FDA Antimicrobial Product Requirements and FFDCA**

Various federal laws have been enacted and are administered under regulatory programs implemented by
several federal agencies that regulate certain products we manufacture and sell for controlling microbial
growth on humans, including antibacterial soaps and rubs. In the United States, these requirements
generally are administered by the FDA including via the ‘‘OTC [over-the-counter] Monograph process.’’

171


-----

The FDA codifies regulations for these product categories in order to ensure product quality, safety and
effectiveness. The FDA also has been expanding requirements applicable to such products, including
proposing additional requirements for data necessary to demonstrate the safety and efficacy of
over-the-counter antiseptic drug products.

Some of the ingredients we produce for the formulation of cosmetics and personal care products are also
regulated under the FDA’s implementation of FFDCA requirements, which authorize the FDA to regulate
cosmetic products and their ingredients. The statutory provisions of the FFDCA that address cosmetics
include adulteration and misbranding provisions, including for example, anti-dandruff claims.
Anti-dandruff ingredients are also regulated pursuant to the OTC Monograph process and must conform
to the product and labelling standards set out in the applicable FDA regulations and must be
manufactured in accordance with cGMPs.

On March 27, 2020, the US Congress enacted the ‘‘Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act’’
(‘‘CARES Act’’), which included OTC monograph reform provisions. The OTC provisions change how FDA
regulates drugs marketed under a monograph and further strengthen FDA oversight on OTC products’
safety, quality and efficacy.

**Switzerland**

**_Regulation of Chemical Products in General_**

In Switzerland, chemical products are subject to a comprehensive set of regulations, including the Swiss
Act on Protection against Dangerous Substances and Preparations (‘‘Chemicals Act’’) (Chemikaliengesetz).
The Chemicals Act is supplemented by implementing ordinances, namely the Ordinance on Protection
against Dangerous Substances and Preparations (‘‘Chemicals Ordinance’’) (Chemikalienverordnung), and
the Ordinance on the Reduction of Risks relating to the Use of Certain Particularly Dangerous
Substances, Preparations and Articles (‘‘Chemical Risk Reduction Ordinance’’) (Chemikalien_Risikoreduktions-Verordnung). In addition, the Chemicals Act is supplemented with separate product-_
specific ordinances, such as the ordinance on biocidal products (see ‘‘—Regulation of Biocidal Products’’) or
the ordinance on plant protection products (Pflanzenschutzmittelverordnung).

In order to minimize technical trade barriers, the Swiss legislature and government have largely
harmonized the Swiss regulations on chemical products with those that apply in the European Union (see
‘‘—EU and UK Regulations’’ above). In particular, Switzerland has autonomously adopted parts of the
European REACH Regulation (including modifications up to and including those set out in Regulation
(EU) 2017/706), the CLP Regulation (up to and including the 15[th] adaptations to technical progress (ATP)
as set out in Regulation (EU) 2020/1182), the candidate list of so-called ‘‘substances of very high concern’’
(SVHC) of the European Chemicals Agency as last modified by the decision ECHA ED/71/2020 as well as
the European Biocidal Product Regulation (Regulation (EU) 528/2012; see ‘‘—Regulation of Biocidal
_Products’’). Additionally, Swiss legislation takes into account the recommendations of the OECD on test_
methods and good laboratory practice as well as the United Nations recommendations for classifying and
labelling of chemicals. An overview of the status of the harmonization of Swiss chemicals legislation with
international regulations, including a list of ongoing legislative projects to further harmonize Swiss
regulations with European regulations, is available online at: <https://www.anmeldestelle.admin.ch/chem/
en/home/themen/recht-wegleitungen/stand-der-harmonisierung-mit-internationalen-vorschriften.html>.

The Chemicals Act sets out rules and principles for the handling of chemical substances and preparations.
The general principle under the Chemicals Act is self-regulation and self-control, meaning that a
manufacturer who places substances or preparations on the market is responsible for ensuring that such
substances or preparations do not endanger life or health. Subject to certain exceptions (in particular with
respect to new substances or biocidal products see ‘‘—Regulation of Biocidal Products’’), the completion of
the self-regulation and self-control procedures allows a manufacturer to place substances and preparations
on the market without prior authorization by or notification to the Swiss authorities.

The Chemicals Ordinance governs, among other things, the classification, packaging and labelling of
substances and preparations as well as preparation of exposure scenarios and compilation of safety data
sheets. As discussed above, these regulations of the Chemicals Ordinance closely follow those regulations
of the European Union, in particular the REACH and CLP Regulations. The Chemicals Ordinance also
sets out the procedure for notification and communication of new substances as well as post-marketing
obligations of the manufacturer. For example, manufacturers are required to reassess or further assess

172


-----

substances, preparations and objects containing dangerous constituents and, where necessary, reclassify,
relabel and repackage them under certain circumstances (e.g., if they are to be used in a different way).

The Chemical Risk Reduction Ordinance prohibits or restricts the use of particularly dangerous
substances, preparations and objects (as set out in the annexes to the ordinance) and specifies the personal
and professional qualifications required for the use of certain particularly dangerous substances,
preparations and articles.

Non-compliance with the Swiss legislations and implementing ordinance may result in criminal liability.

**_Regulation of Biocidal Products_**

Biocidal products may only be placed on the market, sold or used in a professional or commercial capacity,
if such products have been authorized, notified or recognized in accordance with the Swiss Ordinance on
Biocidal Products (‘‘Biocidal Products Ordinance’’) (Biozidprodukteverordnung). The authorization has to
be obtained from the Swiss Common Notification Authority for Chemicals (Gemeinsame Anmeldestelle
_Chemikalien). As is the case with regulations of chemical products in general, the Swiss product-specific_
regulation on biocidal products closely follows European regulations, in particular the European Biocidal
Products Regulation (Regulation (EU) 528/2012) (see ‘‘—EU and UK Regulations—Industry and Product
_Related Regulations—Biocides and cosmetics—BPR and Cosmetics Directive’’). More specifically, the_
Biocidal Products Ordinance represents the Swiss autonomous adaptation of the European Biocidal
Products Regulation (as last modified by Regulation (EU) 334/2014), and Switzerland has also
autonomously adapted European implementing acts up to and including Commission Implementing
Regulation (EU) 2016/1802. These implementing acts are set out in the Swiss Implementing Ordinance on
Biocidal Products of the Federal Department of Home Affairs. In particular, Switzerland has adopted the
assessment procedures for biocidal active substances from the European Union, and Switzerland is actively
integrated in the European assessment process of biocidal substances. Biocidal products with active
substances that are not yet fully approved in the European Union (i.e. active substances that are notified
only) require a separate authorization in Switzerland. Conversely, biocidal products that contain only
already approved active substances and that are approved in the European Union can be approved in
parallel also in Switzerland. In addition, the European Union authorization for biocidal products under the
European Biocidal Products Regulation also extends to Switzerland.

Similar to the general regulations applicable to chemical products (see ‘‘—Regulation of Chemical
_Products’’), the Swiss rules and regulation on biocidal products provide for rules on the packaging and the_
labelling of biocidal products as well as the advertisement for such products. For example, the label used
on packaging of biocidal products must not be misleading in respect of the risks from the biocidal product
to human health, animal health or the environment or its efficacy. Additionally, the label must indicate,
among other things, active substances used in a product, the authorization number, the authorized uses
and directions for use, likely side effects and instructions for first aid, references to accompanying
instruction notes, and instructions on the safe disposal of the product and the packaging.

Non-compliance with the rules of the Swiss Ordinance on Biocidal Products may result in criminal liability
under the rules of the Chemicals Act.

**_Regulation of Plant Protection Products_**

Plant protection products are subject to product-specific rules under the Swiss Ordinance on Placing Plant
Protection Products on the Market (‘‘Plant **Protection** **Products** **Ordinance’’)**
(Pflanzenschutzmittelverordnung). The Plant Protection Products Ordinance aims to ensure that plant
protection products are sufficiently suitable and do not cause unacceptable side effects on human, animal,
and the environment when used properly. Moreover, the Plant Protection Products Ordinance’s purpose is
to ensure a high level of protection for human and animal health as well as the environment. Moreover,
the rules of the Plant Protection Products Ordinance also aims to improve agricultural production. More
specifically, the Plant Protection Products Ordinance sets out rules relating to the marketing, (i) the
approval of ingredients used in plant protection products, (ii) the placing on the market (which requires
prior approval of the relevant product), and (iii) the control of plant protection products. Approval
authority for plant protection products is the Swiss Federal Office for Agriculture (Bundesamt f¨ur
_Landwirtschaft, BLW)._

173


-----

**_Other Environmental, Health and Safety Regulations affecting our Operations in Switzerland_**

Our Swiss operations, in particular our manufacturing site in Visp, are subject to a comprehensive set of
regulations (federal, cantonal and local level) relating to environmental, health and safety (including
workplace safety). Relevant regulations include the Swiss Act on the Protection of the Environment
(Umweltschutzgesetz), the Swiss Ordinance on Air Pollution Control (Luftreinhalteverordnung), the Swiss
Ordinance on Noise Abatement Ordinance (L¨armschutzverordnung), and the Swiss Ordinance for Waste
Processing (Verordnung ¨uber den Verkehr mit Abf¨allen). These rules are relevant for our manufacturing site
in Visp, as they govern, among other things, emissions of substances to the air (e.g., emission of hydrogen
cyanide or nitrous oxide), noise and odor emissions (including required technical measures to reduce
noise), and wastewater management (in particular requirements to implement additional installations for
the treatment of wastewater discharge).

In addition, Swiss law provides for rules relating to the remediation of environmental issues such as use of
asbestos in buildings or environmental pollution (in particular contamination of soil or groundwater from
leaked substances). Compliance with these laws and regulations could cause us to incur additional costs
(e.g., for additional installations or safety measures), which may adversely affect our operations and
financial condition. Non-compliance with Swiss environmental laws and regulations or governmentally
imposed remediation measures may lead to civil liability, administrative action by competent government
authorities and/or criminal liability.

**DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS**

**Senior Facilities Agreement**

**_Overview and Structure_**

In connection with the financing of the Acquisition, the SSN Issuer is expected on or prior to the Issue
Date to enter into a senior facilities agreement with, among others, Credit Suisse AG Cayman Islands
Branch as agent, the Security Agent, and Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, UBS AG London Branch,
Credit Suisse International, Credit Suisse (Deutschland) Aktiengesellschaft, Credit Suisse Loan
Funding LLC, Royal Bank of Canada, UniCredit Bank AG, Cr´edit Agricole Corporate and Investment
Bank Deutschland, Niederlassung einer franz¨osischen Soci´et´e Anonyme, Soci´et´e G´en´erale, National
Westminster Bank Plc, Natwest Markets Plc, Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, MUFG Bank, Ltd. and
The Governor and Company of the Bank of Ireland as mandated lead arrangers (the ‘‘Arrangers’’) (the
‘‘Senior Facilities Agreement’’).

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for (i) senior term loan facilities in principal amounts of the
EUR equivalent of CHF806 million under the EUR TLB Facility and the USD equivalent of
CHF1,028.5 million under the USD TLB Facility (together with the EUR TLB Facility, ‘‘Facility B’’); and
(ii) a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of A375 million (the ‘‘Revolving Credit Facility’’)
(Facility B and the Revolving Credit Facility are collectively referred to as the ‘‘Original Senior Credit
**Facilities’’ for the purposes of this description).**

Incremental facilities may also be established under the Senior Facilities Agreement from time to time
(including by way of an increase to any existing facilities or the establishment of new facilities)
(‘‘Incremental Senior Secured Facilities’’ and, together with the Original Senior Credit Facilities, the
‘‘Senior Secured Facilities’’).

**_Borrowers, Currencies and utilizations_**

Facility B may be utilized by the SSN Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the
Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility (including, in respect of the USD TLB Facility,
US Holdco) or otherwise accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of that facility
(the ‘‘Term Facility Borrowers’’).

The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by the SSN Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries
which enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the
Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers (the ‘‘RCF Borrowers’’), in AUD, CAD, CHF, GBP,
JPY, PLN, SEK or USD and certain other currencies readily available in the relevant interbank market
and freely convertible into EUR (subject to obtaining the consent of all the relevant lenders under the
Revolving Credit Facility) by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary
facilities (on a bilateral and/or fronted basis).

**_Purpose_**

All amounts borrowed under Facility B shall be applied directly or indirectly, in or towards (including by
way of on-lending to, or investment in, any other member of the Senior Secured Group (as defined below)
or Target Companies) (directly or indirectly): (i) financing or refinancing the consideration paid or payable
in connection with the Acquisition and/or any other document ancillary to or entered into in connection
with the Sale and Purchase Agreement (including any purchase price adjustments); (ii) the payment of
certain costs relating to the Acquisition and all other fees, costs, expenses and other amounts incurred or
payable by any member of the Senior Secured Group or the Target Companies in connection with the
Acquisition, the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents, the Transactions and/or the repayment,
refinancing, discharge and/or close-out of any existing indebtedness made available to or guaranteed or
secured by any member of the Target Companies; (iii) the repayment, refinancing, discharge and/or
close-out of the existing debt of the Target Companies (including back-stopping or providing cash cover in
respect of any letters of credit, guarantees or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other
arrangements) and paying any breakage costs, close-out costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and
other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such repayment, refinancing, discharge and/or
close-out; (iv) financing any other payments identified in or for any other purpose contemplated by the tax
structure memorandum or the funds flow statement or otherwise arising in connection with the
Transaction; (v) financing other related amounts, including fees, costs and expenses; and/or (vi) financing

-----

or refinancing the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured
Group (including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash over-funding).

Amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility may be applied directly or indirectly, in or towards
(including by way of on-lending to, or investment in, any other member of the Senior Secured Group (as
defined below) or Target Companies) (directly or indirectly): (i) financing or refinancing the general

case, together with related fees, costs and expenses (and including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash

**_Availability_**

Facility B will be available to be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement
to (and including) 11.59pm (London time) on the earliest to occur of (i) the first date on which both the
(a) Acquisition Closing Date has occurred and (b) the first utilization of Facility B has been made (the
‘‘Closing Date’’), (ii) March 1, 2022, and (iii) the date on which the SSN Issuer determines and notifies the
agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement in writing that the Acquisition Agreement has been validly
and conclusively terminated prior to the Acquisition Closing Date in accordance with its terms (and no
new, amended or replacement Acquisition Agreement is entered into within 10 business days and
delivered as a condition precedent to the making of a utilization on the same basis as the original
Acquisition Agreement), or, in each case, such later date as agreed by the Arrangers holding (with their
affiliates) more than 50% of the aggregate commitments in the Senior Secured Facilities (acting reasonably
and in good faith).

The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities
Agreement to (and including) the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility.

Utilizations of the Original Senior Credit Facilities are subject to customary conditions precedent.

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Original Senior Credit Facilities will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to the
applicable floating rate (being the applicable EURIBOR for loans in Euro, LIBOR for loans in USD and
certain other currencies (subject to mechanics to switch from LIBOR to risk free rates or other benchmark
rates in connection with the future discontinuation of LIBOR), SONIA plus a credit adjustment spread for
loans in Sterling, and other applicable rates for other currencies) plus an applicable margin, which in each
case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of consolidated senior secured net
debt to Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the section entitled ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes’’)
(the ‘‘Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio’’).

If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the
EUR TLB Facility or the Revolving Credit Facility (as applicable). If another interbank offered rate,
including LIBOR is less than zero, LIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the
Revolving Credit Facility or the USD TLB Facility (as applicable). Zero floors will also apply (i) to SONIA
(in respect of loans denominated in Sterling) and (ii) to the risk free rates or other benchmark rates
following the switch under the Senior Facilities Agreement of the floating rate applicable to a relevant
currency from LIBOR.

The interest margin applicable to each Original Senior Credit Facility will be subject to a capped
adjustment by reference to achievement against the Group’s sustainability KPI targets for the financial

180


-----

year ending 31 December 2022 and each subsequent financial year, as set out in the Framework, tested
annually by reference to the Group’s sustainability report in respect of the previous financial year, such
that the margin shall be reduced by a certain percentage where both KPI targets were met in the previous
financial year or increased by a certain percentage where neither of the KPI targets were met in the
previous financial year. Where only one of the KPI targets was met, the margin will not be adjusted. In the
event of any material acquisition the fair market value of which (as determined in good faith by the SSN
Issuer) exceeds 20% of the aggregated assets of the Senior Secured Group, the SSN Issuer will either (at
the SSN Issuer’s election, in respect of each such acquisition) (i) recalculate the applicable GHG emissions
intensity baseline level and the waste intensity baseline level to take into account the acquisition or
(ii) exclude the impact of such acquisition when reporting the KPIs for each financial year. Any
recalculation of the GHG emissions intensity baseline level and the waste intensity baseline level will be
reported in a sustainability report and verified by an external verifier.

A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving
Credit Facility from the Closing Date to the end of the availability period applicable to the Revolving
Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. Such
commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears (provided that the SSN Issuer may elect that accrued
commitment fee shall instead be paid on each Quarter Date or the last date of each Interest Period
applicable to a Facility B), on the last day of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit
Facility and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which the
relevant lender cancels its commitment.

A ticking fee will accrue in respect of the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled commitments in the EUR
TLB Facility and the USD TLB Facility allocated to investors in syndication, accruing from the date that
such commitments are allocated (the ‘‘Allocation Date’’) until the Closing Date. After an initial holiday
period after the Allocation Date, the ticking fee will accrue at rates equal to certain percentages of the
initial margin (excluding any LIBOR or EURIBOR floors) applicable to the relevant facility, varying by
reference to the number of calendar days elapsed since the Allocation Date.

Any letter of credit issued under the Revolving Credit Facility shall be subject to such issuing bank and
fronting fees as may be agreed between the SSN Issuer and the applicable issuing bank and a letter of
credit fee equal to the margin that would have been applicable to a cash drawing under the Revolving
Credit Facility in the applicable currency.

Default interest will be calculated as an additional one per cent. per annum on the defaulted amount.

**_Repayments_**

The loans made under the EUR TLB Facility will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the
Closing Date.

The loans made under the USD TLB Facility will be repaid in instalments by repaying on each Quarter
Date (commencing, with respect to each Facility B (USD) Loan, with the last day of the first full Financial
Quarter ending after the utilization date in respect of the USD TLB Facility) an amount which reduces the
principal amount of such loans drawn during the availability period by 0.25 per cent of their outstanding
principal amount from time to time, with the balance to be repaid in full on the date that is seven years
from the Closing Date.

In respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest
period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings subject to the satisfaction of certain
customary conditions. All outstanding amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility will be repaid on the
termination date of the Revolving Credit Facility, being the date falling six and a half years from the
Closing Date. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be
reborrowed, subject to certain customary conditions.

In respect of the letters of credit, each will be repaid on the termination date of the relevant Revolving
Credit Facility, being the date falling six and a half years from the Closing Date (or such earlier date in
accordance with the Senior Facilities Agreement), provided that if any letter of credit has an expiry date
ending on or after the termination date applicable to the applicable Revolving Credit Facility, on such
termination date each letter of credit shall be repaid unless the relevant issuing bank agrees that such letter
of credit shall continue as between that issuing bank and the relevant member of the Senior Secured
Group on a bilateral basis and not as part of or under the documentation for the Senior Secured Facilities.

**_Voluntary and Mandatory Prepayment_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement will permit voluntary prepayments to be made (subject to _de minimis_
amounts) and will require mandatory prepayment in full or in part in certain circumstances, including:

- from certain net cash proceeds received by the SSN Issuer and any of its restricted subsidiaries
(together the ‘‘Senior Secured Group’’) from certain asset disposals, to the extent not otherwise
applied for a permitted purpose and required to be applied in prepayment of the Senior Credit
Facilities and subject to a de minimis amount and other customary carve outs substantially similar to
the Notes as described in the section entitled ‘‘Description of the Senior Secured Notes’’);

- unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the SSN Issuer
shall apply (in each case in such proportions as the SSN Issuer elects (in its sole discretion)) towards
the prepayment or cancellation (as applicable) of any or all of the term facilities (or any available
commitments in respect of any term loans), any other senior secured indebtedness of the Senior
Secured Group (or any available or undrawn commitments in respect of any senior secured
indebtedness of the Senior Secured Group) (or, if such prepayment would comply with the limitation
on restricted payments under the Senior Facilities Agreement, any other permitted indebtedness), for
each financial year (commencing with the first full financial year following the Closing Date), a
percentage of excess cash flow in the event that excess cash flow exceeds a minimum threshold
amount (subject to certain adjustments based on anticipated debt service, distributions to be paid to
minority shareholders and certain other expenses, restricted payments, debt repayments, acquisitions,
investments, disposals, restructuring costs, group initiatives and capital expenditures in the relevant
financial years committed or designated to be undertaken in the next 24 months being deducted after
applying the applicable percentage(s)), which percentage decreases as the Senior Secured Net
Leverage Ratio decreases (an ‘‘Excess Cash Flow Prepayment’’); and

- upon the occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement which
follows terms substantially similar to the Notes as described in the section entitled ‘‘Description of the
_Senior Secured Notes’’)), at the SSN Issuer’s option, unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders,_
either (i) each lender and issuing bank shall be entitled to require prepayment of outstanding amounts
and cancellation of its commitments within a prescribed time period or (ii) all outstanding undrawn
commitments of each lender shall be immediately cancelled and outstanding drawn commitments
shall become due and payable together with accrued interest and other amounts accrued or owing to
each lender. A change of control shall include: (i) any person or group of related persons (other than
one or more permitted holders) becoming the beneficial owner of more than 50% of the total voting
power of the voting stock of the SSN Issuer (other than in connection with a transaction or series of
transactions in which the SSN Issuer shall become the wholly owned subsidiary of a Parent Entity (as
defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) so long as no person or group other than a permitted
holder, holds more than 50 per cent of the total voting power of the voting stock of such Parent
Entity); (ii) the SUN Issuer ceasing to directly own 100% of the total issued share capital of the SSN
Issuer (or any successor entity as a result of certain mergers permitted under the Senior Facilities
Agreement); or (iii) on a sale, lease, transfer, conveyance or other disposition (other than by way of
merger, amalgamation, consolidation or other business combination transaction), in one or a series of
related transactions, of all or substantially all of the assets of the Senior Secured Group taken as a
whole to a person, other than a restricted subsidiary or one or more permitted holders, in each case,
subject to certain exceptions.

The Revolving Credit Facility shall not be entitled to any mandatory prepayment proceeds (other than a
mandatory prepayment as a result of a Change of Control or illegality).

In the event that it becomes unlawful for any lender to perform its obligations under the Senior Facilities
Agreement, the borrower shall repay that lender’s participation in the utilizations made to that borrower
to the extent necessary to comply with applicable laws on the last day of the interest period for each
utilization occurring after the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement has notified the SSN Issuer (or
if earlier, the date specified by the lender in the illegality notice). Any available commitments of such
lender will be immediately reduced and cancelled to the extent necessary to comply with applicable laws.

If a lender waives its right (such right shall be at the SSN Issuer’s request only) to receive its share of any
prepayment of the Senior Secured Facilities (‘‘Waived Amounts’’), such Waived Amounts may (at the SSN
Issuer’s option) be retained by the Senior Secured Group for any purposes not prohibited by the Senior
Facilities Agreement (including restricted payments), may be offered to any lender(s) selected by the SSN

substantially all of its assets located in its jurisdiction of incorporation (subject to customary exclusions,

_Release of Guarantees and Security_

Group, (ii) on a pro forma basis taking into account such release, the Guarantor Coverage Test will

greater than 50% of the total commitments under such facilities consent to such release; or (v) the
resignation of that guarantor is contemplated by the tax structure memorandum or the Intercreditor

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain representations and warranties (subject to certain agreed

in evidence, (vi) governing law and enforcement, (vii) filing and stamp taxes, (viii) information

Certain representations and warranties shall be made on the Closing Date and will be repeated on the date
of each utilization, on the first day of each interest period and at certain other times.

**_Springing Financial Covenant_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains a springing senior secured net leverage financial covenant
(‘‘Financial Covenant’’) solely for the benefit of the lenders participating in the Revolving Credit Facility and
any applicable Incremental Senior Secured Facilities (together the ‘‘Financial Covenant Facilities’’), set at
a flat ratio whereby the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio as set out in the relevant compliance certificate
delivered to the agent under Senior Facilities Agreement shall not exceed 9.20:1

The Financial Covenant will be on a last twelve months (‘‘LTM’’) basis as at each financial quarter date on
or after the first testing date (a ‘‘Test Date’’), provided that the Senior Secured Group will only be required
to test the Financial Covenant if as of 5.00 p.m. (in London) on a Test Date, the amount of: (a) all loans
under the Financial Covenant Facilities (excluding: (i) loans to fund any original issue discount or
flex-related payments with respect to Facility B and any Incremental Senior Secured Facility which is a
term facility; (ii) loans made on or prior to the Closing Date; (iii) loans used to fund any acquisitions,
capital expenditure or other investments (and, in each case, any rollover loan in respect thereof)) and
(iv) (for the avoidance of doubt) any amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility by way of
ancillary facilities and letters of credit (or bank guarantees)); minus (b) any cash and cash equivalent
investments of the Senior Secured Group, exceeding 40% of the aggregate of: (i) the total commitments of
the Revolving Credit Facility as at the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement; and (ii) the aggregate of all

184


-----

commitments under any Incremental Senior Secured Facility which is a revolving facility and a Financial
Covenant Facility established after the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement, (disregarding, in each case,
any reduction in such commitments following the establishment thereof) (the ‘‘Test Condition’’).

The Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio is based on the definitions and adjustments in the Senior Facilities
Agreement, which may differ from similar definitions in the Indentures and the equivalent definitions
described in this Offering Memorandum.

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains an equity cure provision enabling the SSN Issuer to cure or
prevent breaches of the Financial Covenant (an ‘‘Equity Cure’’) by the contribution from its shareholders
or any other person to the Senior Secured Group of additional equity, assets and/or subordinated loans
(‘‘Cure Amount’’) to (i) increase the Consolidated EBITDA under the Senior Facilities Agreement,
(‘‘EBITDA Cure’’), (ii) decrease consolidated senior secured net debt as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement (‘‘Net Debt Cure’’), or (iii) prepay loans under a Financial Covenant Facility (‘‘Prepayment
**Cure’’) so that the Test Condition is no longer satisfied. An EBITDA Cure may be exercised on no more**
than five occasions during the term of the Senior Facilities Agreement and no more than two EBITDA
Cures may be made in any three consecutive relevant periods. Any such Equity Cure must be exercised
prior to the date falling 20 Business Days after the date on which the compliance certificate is required to
be delivered.

There shall be no obligation to use any Cure Amount (other than with respect to a Prepayment Cure) in
prepayment of the Senior Secured Facilities. There shall be no cap on the amount of any cure and
over-cures are permitted.

If the Financial Covenant has been breached, but is complied with when tested on any subsequent Test
Date or is otherwise not required to be tested due to the Test Condition not being met on any subsequent
date, then, the prior breach of such Financial Covenant or any event of default arising therefrom shall be
deemed cured unless the requisite super majority of the lenders under any relevant Revolving Credit
Facility (the ‘‘Super Majority Revolving Facility Lenders’’) have exercised their acceleration rights to
declare all or part of the loans under that Revolving Credit Facility to be immediately due and payable.

The SSN Issuer may elect to recalculate the Test Condition or Financial Covenant for any period at any
time based upon any financial statements (including the latest internally available financial information for
an LTM period) and, if (taking into account such recalculation) the Test Condition is not met or the
Financial Covenant is complied with at such time (due to prepayments of the Revolving Credit Facility,
cash or cash equivalents on balance sheet or otherwise), the Financial Covenant shall be deemed complied
with and any prior breach of such Financial Covenant or any Event of Default arising therefrom shall be
deemed cured. For any such calculation, the SSN Issuer may give pro forma effect to all applicable
transactions (and permitted adjustments to any Applicable Metric (being any financial covenant or
financial ratio or incurrence-based permission, test, basket, or threshold, whether any default, event of
default or other relevant breach of the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents has occurred, is
continuing or would result or any other metric, condition or permission) in connection therewith) for
which the applicable transaction date has occurred following the end of the applicable period or any
subsequent relevant period as if such applicable transaction had been consummated on the first day of
such applicable period or relevant period (as applicable).

**_General Undertakings_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants, information undertakings and
related definitions (with, in each case, certain adjustments), including (i) limitations on indebtedness;
(ii) limitations on restricted payments; (iii) limitations on liens (which includes the ability to designate
certain credit facilities and/or hedging obligations secured on the Collateral as Super Senior Liabilities (as
defined in the section entitled ‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement’’) if,
prior to such designation, Facility B has been refinanced in full (ignoring any participation (x) of a lender
which has been rolled over in a refinancing (or otherwise) of Facility B and/or (y) in respect of which a
lender has declined prepayment) and the original Revolving Credit Facility (to the extent not fully and
finally discharged) has been designated as Super Senior Liabilities (as defined in the section entitled
‘‘Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement’’))); (iv) limitations on sale of
assets and subsidiary stock; (v) limitations on affiliate transactions; (vi) designation of restricted and
unrestricted subsidiaries (vii) merger and consolidation undertakings with respect to (x) the SSN Issuer
(y) US Holdco and (z) the guarantors of the Senior Secured Facilities; and (viii) additional intercreditor
agreements.

-----

In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement also requires the SSN Issuer and certain of its restricted
subsidiaries to observe certain other customary positive and negative covenants, subject to certain
exceptions and grace periods, including covenants relating to: (i) authorizations and consents;
(ii) compliance with laws; (iii) _pari passu ranking; (iv) taxes; (v) centre of main interests; (vi) guarantees_
and security; (vii) further assurance; (viii) anti-corruption law and sanctions; (ix) release condition;
(x) ratings; (xi) compliance with ERISA; (xii) compliance with Swiss non-bank rules; (xiii) no flowback to
Switzerland of proceeds from the USD TLB Facility and certain Incremental Senior Secured Facilities; and
(xiv) certain post-closing undertakings (including granting the post-Closing Date security described above).

The Senior Facilities Agreement also requires the SSN Issuer to comply with certain customary
information undertakings, including delivery of financial statements, sustainability reports and
accompanying compliance certificates, provided that the obligation to deliver financial information and/or
sustainability reports may differ from similar requirements in the Indentures and as described in this
Offering Memorandum.

It is intended that certain agreed covenants and other provisions of the Senior Facilities Agreement will
fall away upon the satisfaction of certain release conditions, being (i) (with permanent effect) the
occurrence of a listing of any member of the Senior Secured Group or a holding company which does not
constitute a Change of Control and in respect of which the Senior Secured Group’s Senior Secured Net
Leverage Ratio does not exceed 4.25:1; (ii) (while the release condition remains satisfied) the SSN Issuer
or any holding company of the SSN Issuer having a long-term corporate credit rating equal to or higher
than BBB-, Baa3 or BBB- (as applicable) or higher according to any two of Fitch Ratings, Inc., Moody’s
Investors Service, Inc. or Standard & Poor’s Investors Ratings Services or, in each case, any of its
successors or assigns that is a nationally recognized statistical rating organization.

**_Events of Default_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for substantially the same events of default as under the Notes.
In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to customary
materiality qualifications, thresholds, grace periods, and excluded matters including (i) breach of the
financial covenant, provided that (A) in the event of such breach, only the Super Majority Revolving
Facility Lenders may exercise acceleration rights as a result of such breach and (B) if the Super Majority
Revolving Facility Lenders have exercised such acceleration rights as a result of such breach, the remaining
lenders shall have a right of cross-acceleration; (ii) misrepresentation; (iii) invalidity and unlawfulness of
the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents; and (iv) material failure to comply with the
Intercreditor Agreement.

**_Governing Law_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with
it, are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in accordance with English law
although the restrictive covenants, events of default and related definitions scheduled to the Senior
Facilities Agreement will be interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact
that the Senior Facilities Agreement is governed by English law).

several creditorship or similar structure for the benefit of all the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured
Parties), in each case, in respect of the Topco Independent Secured Obligations. In the case of a Topco
Independent Obligor which is a member of the Senior Secured Group and a direct shareholder of a Topco
Borrower, such security shall be (i) limited to shares in and receivables owed to it by the relevant Topco
Borrower which are not required to be subject to the Transaction Security pursuant to the Finance
Documents and (ii) granted on a limited recourse basis. Topco Independent Transaction Security shall
secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of each Topco Independent Obligor to the Topco
Secured Parties under the Topco Finance Documents.

‘‘Topco Shared Security’’ refers to security at any time which is created, or expressed to be created, over any
of the following (i) the shares in the SSN Issuer held by any direct shareholder of the SSN Issuer and
(ii) all receivables owed by the SSN Issuer to a Topco Investor (as defined below), Subordinated Creditor
or other holding company or shareholder of the SSN Issuer (including any Topco Proceeds Loan and the
Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities, as applicable) (iii) the shares in any Topco Borrower which is a member
of the Senior Secured Group, (iv) all receivables owed by a member of the Senior Secured Group under
any Topco Proceeds Loan (or, in the case of a Topco Borrower which is a member of the Senior Secured
Group, any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan), and (v), any other assets not falling within limbs (i), (ii),
(iii) and (iv) of this paragraph of a Topco Borrower and (to the extent that the SSN Issuer has confirmed to
the Security Agent that the granting of such security in favor of the Topco Shared Security Secured
Obligations is not prohibited by the terms of any applicable prior ranking financing agreements) any other
member of the Senior Secured Group, in each case designated as Topco Shared Security by the SSN Issuer
(in its discretion) in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or if such
trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favor of all the Secured Parties or in favor of the Security
Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). Topco Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and
present and future obligations of each Topco Borrower that is not a member of the Senior Secured Group
and each of its Subsidiaries other than Unrestricted Subsidiaries (as defined in the documents governing
the relevant Topco Notes or Topco Facility (as the case may be)) (the ‘‘Topco Group’’), each Debtor and
any Third Party Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Secured Debt Documents.

‘‘Transaction Security’’ refers to security (from the Senior Secured Group, any Third Party Security Provider
and Topco Shared Security (but excluding, for the avoidance of doubt, Topco Independent Transaction
Security)) in each case which, to the extent legally possible and subject to any Agreed Security Principles
(as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement (i) is
created, or expressed to be created, in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured
Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) in respect of the applicable Secured Obligations; or (ii) in the case of
any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favor of the Security Agent as agent or
trustee for the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties), is created, or expressed to be created, in
favor of (x) all the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) in respect of the applicable Secured
Obligations or (y) the Security Agent under a parallel debt and/or joint and several creditorship or similar

structure for the benefit of all the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) in respect of the
applicable Secured Obligations. Transaction Security which is not Topco Shared Security shall secure all
liabilities and present and future obligations of the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the
Secured Parties (other than the creditors under the Topco Liabilities (as defined below) (the ‘‘Topco
